SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-1. deplores-

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, by referring to the statement on health that was brought down by the Minister for Health the week before last, and particularly to page 4 thereof, on which the Government, having set out what are called general objectives in relation to health, goes on to enunciate a number of what are called in the statement 'firm measures' to bring those general principles into effect. I refer particularly to firm measure No. 2, which states that all Australians should become far more responsible for their own health care and more aware of the full costs of health services available to them. I ask: In view of the recent reversal in relation to health funding for the State of Queensland, to what extent does the Government have principles in relation to health care? How far is there a firm commitment to the principles that the Government has announced, and is there in fact to be a differentiation amongst Australians, on the basis of the geographical area in which they live, in relation to the application of this Government's health care principles?

—The Government did announce new arrangements for public hospital funding and a new basis for the Commonwealth and States to share the responsibility for such funding. It is a fact that the new arrangements will result in more responsibility being taken by Australians and their becoming more aware of the costs involved. What the honourable senator has failed to pick up in his question is that the State of Queensland was able to demonstrate the particular problems which it had and that, as a result, an arrangement was made to cope with them. There is no question of anyone moving away from principles. I am surprised at the question.

—I wisk to ask a supplementary question. Is is not a fact that the particular circumstances are that Queensland has been able for a number of years to provide free hospital services for its citizens. In light of the philosophy expressed in the statement of the Minister for Health, I will rephrase the question and ask: In Fraser Government terms, is it a fact that there is no such thing as a free lunch or free health care unless someone happens to have been getting free lunches for a long period?

—The State of Queensland will have to undertake considerable change, and there will be a problem of rate of change as a number of Queensland people undertake health insurance. That is the reason for the particular problems which Queensland faces. They are perfectly understandable problems. In no way has the Government moved away from the principles of the arrangement.

—I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister for Communications, by congratulating the members of Comskill within Telecom Australia, who voluntarily developed the telephone access dialler to assist handicapped persons within our society to enjoy their lives more fully. I refer to the device which is on display within the Parliament today. I ask: Can the Minister give an indication of when this device will be available for use, and on what basis it will be marketed?

—It will be necessary for me to take the matter up with my colleague, the Minister for Communications. I will endeavour to obtain the information that the honourable senator seeks before Question Time concludes today.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CIVIL DEFENCE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COMMISSION PROGRAM

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he has seen, or had brought to his attention, the Australian Broadcasting Commission's television program 'If the Bomb Drops', which shows the inadequacy of the civil defence of Australia in the event of a nuclear attack. Is it true that no adequate Federal plans exist to meet such an attack and that State schemes are patchy and ineffective? Is it also true that civil defence against a nuclear attack has been downgraded in Australia over the past several years compared with defence against natural disasters, which I commend the Government for upgrading? Does he accept the assessment of the Department of Defence that the possibility of a nuclear attack against Australia cannot be ruled out? If so, is the Government behaving responsibly in exporting large quantities of uranium without at the same time having adequate safeguards in the event of our uranium being returned to us in the form of nuclear weapons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take the last part of the question first. The Australian Government subscribes to and is a signatory to the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Under that Treaty Australia will not manufacture atomic weapons, nor will it assist in any way any other nation so to do. In its supply of uranium for peacetime electric power generation it subscribes to the International Atomic Energy Agency and to all the auditing of that Agency. Through its own Australian Safeguards Office it monitors the movement of its own uranium and its products throughout the world so that, with the assistance of the International Atomic Energy Agency and of its own monitoring, it can quite safely assure that it will not be providing uranium for fissile weapons of an aggressive or offensive nature. We are implacably opposed to contributing at all to the amount of fissile material for war purposes, although I have to say sadly to Senator Chipp that the volume of existing material, such as plutonium, held by major powers is quite enormous and that additional amounts as far as they are concerned are almost irrelevant. The danger in that regard would be from terrorists or others.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I did not see the program referred to in the honourable senator's question. I will make some inquiries about it. I do not have details in particular about our present civil defence facilities. They do not come within my responsibilities, so I will seek out the details. I am not aware that the facilities have been downgraded. In fact Senator Chipp commended the upgrading of the natural disasters program. The two programs are co-partners-one marches with the other. Senator Chipp may shake his head, but I have been on the receiving end of such things. I know that both natural and man-made disasters often have basically the same sorts of consequences. That is not to say that one should not do better. I would not comment on any assessment by the Defence Department or by others of the probability of war, nuclear or otherwise. The whole of history is strewn with people who have made assessments and predictions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not mention war; I simply mentioned nuclear attack by terrorists.

—I simply say that one would have to say that there exists in this world some possibility, whatever its degree, that nuclear weapons could be used. Therefore, quite clearly there must be within a community a capacity to understand that and to attempt to cope. Because I do not know the details of our civil defence, I will refer the matter to the relevant Minister and seek an appropriate response.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister accept that I am not trying to score political points? I am simply asking him, as a senior Minister in this Government, whether, in the event of nuclear weapons being landed on Australia, he is satisfied that Australia's capacity to cope with a nuclear attack, whether it be from a power or from terrorists, is or is not adequate. Or does he not know?

—That kind of judgment is one about which both the expert advisers to the Government and the specific Minister must know best. That is why I have hesitated. Although I accept the collective responsibility of Cabinet, I do not believe I should simply make a personal comment. I will seek out the information and, if necessary, we can pursue the details of it further when it comes to hand.

—I direct my question to either the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs or the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, whichever is appropriate. Has the Minister noted the Industries Assistance Commission report on trade trends in which the Commission again draws attention to the heavy cost borne by efficient industries because of the high level of protection afforded to Australia's less efficient high cost industries and warns that unless the Australian system of protection is changed adjustment pressures will be borne most heavily by the country's most efficient industries? The IAC report particularly noted the motor car industry and the clothing, textiles and footwear industry as industries receiving particularly heavy protection. Will the Government take note of this further warning by the IAC of the adverse effects on the Australian economy and on our competitive export potential if the Government persists in granting high levels of protection to these industries?
—Senator Sim has again, as he has on many occasions, brought to our attention the views of the IAC on matters in connection with--
—Which I share.

—And his own views which he has expressed in this place on many occasions in connection with the degree of protection given to Australian industry. He makes the point that unless we seek to shift towards a more liberalised industrial structure which is based on market trends rather than on high levels of protection we will suffer damage in the longer run. I think it is evident from the progress which this Government has made on various issues-I believe it is evident from some legislation dealt with in this chamber last night in regard to the Customs tariff legislation-that there are movements towards a liberalisation of our protection in various areas. It was mentioned last night--
—It is not a move to liberalise protection. It just changes the distribution of--

—Senator Walsh may learn, if he cares to listen-perhaps he was not in the chamber last night-that there was a discussion about the alleviation of the quota system in regard to textiles, clothing and footwear to which Senator Sim particularly alluded. In that situation I believe the Government is moving in the direction which is consistent with the degree and rate of change which this country can stand rather than adopting the slap-dash method of the previous Australian Labor Party Government in 1973 when it introduced the across the board tariff cut.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister whether he can clarify for this chamber the situation which appears to have arisen in what seems to be the continuing State-Commonwealth financial arrangements. In view of statements by the Prime Minister yesterday that the Commonwealth had exhausted its financial responsibilities to the States and that there was no further money-not one cent-available for the States, and the later revelation that he had, in fact, attempted to make a private financial arrangement with the Premier of Queensland to the extent of a further $16m, can the State Premiers, including Mr Bjelke-Petersen, still continue these negotiations with the Commonwealth to arrange more funds under special circumstances or is the situation as the Prime Minister said earlier in the day, that the Commonwealth has exhausted its financial responsibilities to the States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —What, in fact, the Prime Minister has said is that during the Premiers Conference discussions occurred on two main matters-the tax sharing arrangements and the new hospital and health financing. As to hospital and health financing, Queensland made a very strong claim that because of its past financing system for hospitals it was going to get by way of the Commonwealth's return of funds very considerably less per capita than other States and something like half of what Western Australia would get. Queensland asked that consideration be given to that. The Commonwealth indicated that the Minister for Health would be meeting on the Friday with State Ministers and the whole matter could be looked at. At the Premiers Conference the Commonwealth concluded its decisions on tax sharing and that is the right, the responsibility, of the Commonwealth so to do.

ANSWER.PARA: So it is correct to say that the Commonwealth had reached its decisions to set tax sharing at 9 per cent plus the other absorptions. It is equally correct to say that at the Friday meeting of the Health Ministers Queensland further advanced its cause and indicated that because of its very low base for hospital charges it would take a very considerable time for Queensland to achieve the kind of statistics that the Commonwealth was seeking and that other States might reach in time, and that what was necessary for Queensland was to have adequate bridging funds in that time. It also indicated quite clearly that it supported in principle the health program of the Commonwealth Government, that it wanted to reach the goals as quickly as it could but that it would need a particular amount of money.

The Commonwealth therefore decided as a once-off measure to provide $16m which would, when compared with the disbursements to the other States, give Queensland no preference at all, but a reasonable status amongst the other States. I remind the Senate that four out of the six States have made it abundantly clear that they agree entirely with the principles of the health scheme.

The Commonwealth has also indicated that whilst it believes it is possible for the States to recover at least 60 per cent of their present moneys out of the imposition of fees to those who can properly pay fees, there will be a review of this capacity towards the end of the next financial year, and the matter will be discussed again. The States generally accept the principle. They now have the undertaking that there will be a review. A particular disbursement was made as a once-off situation to Queensland on the very equitable grounds that Queensland had very special factors that no other State had.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. May I take it from the Minister's answer that he is asserting that the Queensland Government, represented in this case by Mr Bjelke-Petersen and Dr Edwards, agree with the Commonwealth's policy that it should cease providing free hospital beds and in fact charge people for entering hospitals?

—I have neither been asked to say that nor have I responded as such. What I have said is that my understanding is that the Premier and Dr Llew Edwards have said-unless I am mistaken, Dr Llew Edwards said it in an AM broadcast-that they support the principle of the Commonwealth's health scheme. Therefore, quite clearly, they will endeavour to carry it out.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. Is it a fact that the Federal Government has decided to make available to ethnic schools a sum of $15 a pupil for the purpose of cultural education? If so, will the Minister inform the Senate which schools throughout Australia have been so designated and would therefore be eligible for the extra grant? How many pupils attend these schools? What will be the total cost to the Australian taxpayer of the grant? Who designated the schools ethnic schools or did they apply for the title?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision to provide support for ethnic schools arose from a recommendation in the report of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs-Review of Multicultural and Migrant Education, September 1980. The program is being implemented this year and will provide up to $30 per student per annum to approved ethnic schools providing instruction on a part time basis in community languages and related cultural material. Grants will be made through the Schools Commission on the basis of applications from ethnic school authorities. The program is intended to provide support for such authorities which are at present ineligible for other forms of Commonwealth education funding.

ANSWER.PARA: A survey conducted by the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs last year indicated that approximately 100,000 students were enrolled in part time ethnic schools. The estimated cost of the program is therefore about $3m this year. The legislation giving effect to the program, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, completed its passage through this Parliament very recently.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney whether he recalls that in November 1979 Chief Judge Wheelan of the Victorian County Court said, in convicting a Melbourne doctor for Medibank fraud-a well publicised case-that the penalties under the Commonwealth Crimes Act for such frauds were grossly inadequate. Does he further recall that following that case, on 27 November 1979, over 18 months ago, he or a spokesman from his office said that there would be a review of the legislation under which the doctor had been charged? In light of the current controversy surrounding the Canberra doctor, William Vincent Russell, who has chosen to go to gaol for six days as an alternative to paying $27,800 in fines, does he agree that the penalties for Medibank fraud are still grossly inadequate? Can he explain the extraordinary delay in the Government doing something about it?

—In the case of Dr Russell, I understand that there were charges under the Health Insurance Act as well as the Crimes Act and also, I think, under the Poisons and Narcotic Drugs Ordinance. There was a variety of charges. I think the problems that have arisen in that case do not arise directly out of the adequacy of penalties under the Crimes Act. However, Senator Evans has found his question a useful vehicle to jog my memory of what I said in November 1979. I do recall the question arising then. I will endeavour to ascertain as soon as possible just what progress is being made in the review of penalties under the Crimes Act.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and relates to Australia's response to the current events in Northern Ireland. Is the Irish Republican Army an illegal organisation in both Ulster and the Irish Republic itself? Are the methods of the IRA totally outside the ambit of legitimate democratic processes, being confined wholly to the use of terror and indiscriminate murder of both British soldiers and ordinary citizens? Do the majority of the citizens of Ulster clearly want to retain their historical and political links with the United Kingdom? Is there freedom of democratic political activity in Ulster, with fair representation of all its citizens in the Parliament at Westminster? Have all the current group of hunger strikers been duly convicted, by appropriate legal means, of crimes of exceptional violence, including murder and various firearm offences? Are they in fact simply vicious criminals and in no way either prisoners of war or political prisoners? Will the Australian Government, therefore, indicate clearly to the Government of Great Britain that it supports its unyielding stance in the face of terrorism and recognises that any deviation from the current policy in relation to the IRA--

—I raise a point of order. The honourable senator is obviously using the device of asking a question at length to make a statement, a statement which ought to be debated in this place. It is a highly controversial statement on the part of the honourable senator, and one which I think is very much open to question. The honourable senator has given far too much information. He is making a statement as part of a question, and the question ought to be ruled out of order.
—I do not sustain the point of order, but I ask Senator Puplick to be as brief as he can. The question is too long to give other honourable senators an opportunity of asking questions.

—I was asking whether the Australian Government would therefore indicate clearly to the Government of Great Britain that it supports its unyielding stance in the face of terrorism and recognises that any deviation from the current policy in relation to the IRA would be simply to encourage and legitimise the use of terror, both domestically and internationally. Will the Minister directly reject those calls being made by various elements in Australia for concessions to the IRA which amount to nothing more than a surrender to murder and terrorism?
—I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick.
—Surely, in the concluding stages of the honourable senator's so-called question he proved that it was out of order and therefore it should not be answered by the Minister.
—I call the Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is utterly capable of being both asked and responded to in terms of facts without raising political emotions or heat. The first part of the question asked: Is the Irish Republican Army illegal? The answer to that question is emphatically yes. The second part of the question asked: Are its members outside the ordinary democratic process and do they act as terrorists? The factual answer to that question is yes. The third part of the question asked: Do the majority of Ulster residents desire, historically and politically, to live in a democratic state which has the qualities that the British Government strives for? The answer to that question, as is demonstrated in the ballot box, is yes. The question also asked: Do they have freedom and are they represented? The answer is yes. I cannot answer whether all the hunger strikers are convicted terrorists or convicted criminals because I would need to have a complete list of people involved and to know who they are. I raise no emotions regarding those who lamentably have died. Let us calm our emotions in respect of this aspect. I have seen many people die from starvation, so I know something about the ugliness and sickness of that translation from this earth. I take no joy in the fact that people are using that form of protest, having walked somewhat along that journey in my day. So I do not seek to raise any passions. I am not able to say how many of the hunger strikers are convicted criminals. It is true that the British Government and the courts that have convicted these people say that they are criminals because they have acted--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is obvious that the Minister is reading from a prepared document. I am not sure whether the Standing Orders now provide that Ministers, before they are asked questions without notice, must be given a copy of the question. I think that that is contrary to Standing Orders.
—I say quite emphatically that the documents on my desk are a note, some statistics on post-graduate studies and a reply to Senator O'Byrne's question.
—There is no point of order.

—Of course this technique is an old one. If a point of order can be sustained, the question can be tampered with, and one ought to understand that. I had no prior notice of this question. However, from time to time Labor senators give me notice of questions and when they do I am proud that I am able to get them decent answers. I have done that in the past, when I have been given prior notice, even though that has been denied.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact of the matter is that Labor senators frequently give me notice of questions that they wish to ask. I deviate when I say that because--
—You are shaking again.
—Order! Honourable senators will cease interjecting.

—If I may respond, Mr President, it so happens unhappily that the movements of my hands are the result of toxic neurosis brought on by semi-starvation. Perhaps it would be better ethically for Senator Walsh not to seek to make fun of something that has another explanation. Perhaps in the future Senator Walsh may need to understand that neurotoxic conditions can be caused in Australians as well as in people in Northern Ireland. Let us keep that in its perspective. The larrikinism that goes on each day with Senator Walsh does no credit to his party. I am sorry I have had to be personal on that.

ANSWER.PARA: As to whether I would respond for the Australian Government, I will pass the question to the Minister concerned. I will invite him to pursue it. I do not know whether the Government will judge that it will convey a message to the British Government. That is a matter of policy. I will invite the Minister to study the question and to consider whether he will accede to the request.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that during the last election campaign the Government Information Unit suggested to the Prime Minister's office that the Government should encourage a rumour that the ethnic radio station 3EA would be closed down if it persisted in an alleged anti-Government stance? If so, does this indicate that the GIU has become part and parcel of a dirty tricks department which is opposed to the freedom of speech and thought in Australia?

—I saw a statement in, I think, the Age today. According to the advice that I have sought, because I had no knowledge of this matter, the answer is no, it is not true; they are unfounded rumours. The Government is committed to the continuation of ethnic radio through the Special Broadcasting Service stations 2EA and 3EA and by subsidisation of ethnic programs on public radio stations in many cities.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to Press reports relating to an open letter written to the Prime Minister by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, the body representing all Australia's foreign aid organisations, which proposes measures to increase Australia's contributions to foreign aid. Is there any truth in the Council's allegation that Australian aid as a proportion of gross national product has fallen faster than aid from any other country in the past four or five years? Does the Minister agree that Australia, as one of the world's most prosperous nations, must lend all possible assistance in helping to bridge the gap between rich and poor countries? If so, I ask the Minister: Firstly, what action will be taken by the Government to honour its commitment to the United Nations to increase the amount set aside for economic aid to 0.7 per cent of gross national product? Secondly, will consideration be given by the Government to the proposal put forward by the Council for Overseas Aid that Australia should move for a United Nations study of the possibility of introducing an international tax, including a tax on arms production, to raise funds for economic development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I recall seeing some public comments on the matter raised by Senator Missen and some of the claims that were made by the Council for Overseas Aid. I note that the reduction in Australian overseas aid as a percentage of gross domestic product was mentioned but I have no information that would verify the statements that were made. I note that Senator Missen has asked what action will be taken to honour our commitment on overseas aid. For the forthcoming Budget, aid to other countries will be, as it always is, considered very seriously. I think it is understood that we have an ongoing commitment on aid to Papua New Guinea, which is a very substantial one. At the same time we look at aid that is required by other countries, in particular those that are in our region. I can only say that in this forthcoming Budget whatever is able to be done in the giving of assistance through our aid program will be given a high priority by the Government. I have noted the other matter mentioned by Senator Missen with regard to an international tax. I would need to refer that to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see whether he has any response and whether he would wish to raise that as a matter for consideration for the forthcoming Budget.

—My question which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health deals with preventive medicine. I remind the Minister of the reply given to me by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle last year in which she stated that it was government policy to encourage the development of preventive medicine for the purpose of cutting medical costs. Therefore, I ask the Minister: Is it true that health insurance funds do not cover preventive medicine? Does this mean that the Government's new health scheme will make no attempt to prevent illness but simply to give partial financial support after the illness has occurred?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly true that a whole range of preventive activities has an important role in a proper, balanced health system. It is also true that of the many millions-I think it is 60 million-of patient-doctor contacts each year in Australia a number are in fact preventive in nature. I draw the honourable senator's attention to the immunisation programs, a number of counselling procedures, checks on well babies and ante-natal care. This is the normal kind of preventive care for well people. I think it would be wrong to assume that all the transactions that take place through the normal health care system are necessarily other than preventive.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, the honourable senator is correct. I think there needs to be some special preventive activities. I am not certain that it is entirely correct to say that health insurance funds preclude the funding of such activities. I will refer those parts of the honourable senator's question to the Minister for Health to see whether that information can be obtained.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RESOURCES BOOM: STATEMENTS BY MR JOHN HALFPENNY

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for National Development and Energy been drawn to some quite remarkable statements by Mr John Halfpenny at the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference? The statements allege a grab of revenue by the Western Australian and Queensland governments from their own natural assets. Is there any truth in those statements? Is it true that Mr Halfpenny has sought the introduction of legislation to ban the resources boom on the grounds that it will cause prosperity for all?

—Mr Halfpenny is not regarded by me as required reading. There is some kind of paradox in associating what Mr Halfpenny may say with an Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference. So I have not read what Mr Halfpenny said. Against that background, I am not able to comment, but it is fair to say that a number of extremely militant union leaders in this country today, by their actions, are weakening--

—Surely that answer is now out of order. I am raising a point of order about the answer. The Minister said that he had no knowledge, then he said 'but' and proceeded to make a political answer. For that reason he is out of order.
—The Minister is in order. He referred to a certain part of the question to which he could not reply. The Minister may continue.

—The fact is that day by day a certain number of extremely militant union leaders are denying to the Australian people the growth and prosperity that in fact the resources boom should be giving to them.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SENATE COMMITTEES: APPEARANCE BY MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to you, Mr President. I ask whether you endorse the assertion in Odgers Fifth Edition of Australian Senate Practice at page 562 which states:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the Executive Government enjoys no privilege which puts it above Parliament . . .

Are you aware of Standing Order 360 of the House of Representatives which empowers that House to authorise a member to attend before a Senate committee only if the member thinks fit-that is, it is a completely voluntary attendance? Does this Standing Order allow Ministers of the Crown, who are members of the House, to refuse to be accountable to the Senate or to its committees and thereby contradict Odgers? Do you agree that a Minister should or can refuse to appear? If so, on what grounds?

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that Mr Odgers's reference on page 562, to which Senator Walsh referred, is a correct assessment. I have no know- ledge of Standing Order 360 in the House of Representatives. I have no knowledge of the Standing Orders of that place. Those which apply to this place are the ones to which I give my attention.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I realise that a considered answer probably cannot be given immediately, but would you consider studying that Standing Order and its implications, especially when juxtaposed to Odgers's assertion which you have endorsed, and give me and/or the Senate a reply in writing.
—It is not within my province to interpret the Standing Orders of another place. That question would have to be directed to the appropriate person in another place.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the reported statement by the Minister for Housing in Tasmania, Mr Baldock, that because of Federal Government cutbacks Tasmania is unable to allocate any welfare housing to homeless youth? Has any restriction whatsoever been imposed by the Federal Government which would prohibit the Tasmanian Government from allocating some of the welfare housing money to homeless youth? As Tasmania received from the Federal Government $37 per head of population for welfare housing compared with $15.19 by Queensland and $17.22 by Victoria, is there any excuse for Tasmania this year not accepting its responsibility in that regard?

—My attention has been drawn to that statement by Mr Baldock, who claims that because of Federal Government cutbacks he is unable to meet his responsibilities with regard to homeless youth. I do not think the Federal Government would accept that proposition in the light of the facts which have been outlined by Senator Walters in her question, and particularly in the light of the recent housing agreement between the Commonwealth and the States, which I believe is supported by the States. The figures which Senator Walters gave for the relativities between the States are a significant factor in assessing the capacity of Tasmania to meet its responsibilities in this regard and clearly demonstrate that it should have the resources to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer to the new proposals about health insurance which were announced last week. Is it true that the average family presently with health insurance will be between $4 and $9 a week worse off? Will those without health insurance be between $12 and $23 a week worse off? Will the changes benefit only private hospitals, health insurance funds and a few medical specialists?

—I have had a chance to study the statement put out last week when the new changes were announced and such figures as I could examine. There is no reason at all to think that the figures given by the honourable senator are anywhere near the truth. There is no reason to believe that the average family will be between $4 and $9 a week worse off, or that the uninsured family will be between $12 and $23 a week worse off. What will emerge from these changes is a greater responsibility being taken up by the States for matters within their constitutional ambit. There will be a greater take-up of responsibility by people who can afford to share in the costs of health care. There is no question that the amounts involved will be anything like those suggested by the honourable senator. If he has some kind of analysis which would support his extraordinary statements, I would be delighted to see it.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the recent increase awarded to electorate legislative assistants. The Minister indicated that the increase would amount to approximately 11.5 per cent. On what basis has the Public Service Board directed that the increment level for assistants be adjusted without regard to years of service and, in some cases, effectively reduced by two levels. On what basis is it deemed that retrospective increases in salaries do not apply to overtime performed during that period as has been the case with the recent increases for legislative assistants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a brief which may go some way to responding to Senator Kilgariff.
—That's a coincidence!

—No, it is no coincidence at all. It is my habit to get together a brief each day on each of the subjects and departments for which I am responsible in the hope that all honourable senators, except Senator Cavanagh, will want factual replies. I am advised that the Public Service Board approved certain arrangements relating to increments for electorate assistants and that these were consistent with the approach adopted recently for electorate secretaries and personal secretaries and were not inconsistent with the practice adopted in category reviews undertaken in the Public Service. The arrangements adopted should be seen against the usual practice adopted when individual positions in the Public Service are upgraded, that is, the position is declared vacant and the previous occupant has to compete for promotion to the new position. If successful he or she goes to the minimum of the new range if that is higher than the previous salary, notwithstanding his or her length of service in the job at the previous level.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that in the case of electorate assistants and electorate secretaries the Board decided, because of the across-the-board nature of the increase, that more generous arrangements which give some recognition to length of service should be applied. I am advised that the general practice when salary is adjusted retrospectively-such retrospectivity is granted only in special circumstances-is that extraneous payments such as overtime and shift penalties are adjusted with prospective effect. I am also advised that in addition to national wage increases electorate staff have received the benefit of the 4 per cent interim work value increase, which was awarded by the Full Bench last August and which was backdated to 22 May 1980, and also the increase which took effect on 19 November 1980. The staff will receive any further increases awarded by the Full Bench in the Public Service clerical administrative case. If Senator Kilgariff has further questions on the matter I would be happy to seek information for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to a statement made by him on 29 April in answer to a question from Senator Gietzelt. He said that the first he had heard about the doubts the Esso company held on the proposed Rundle shale oil project was on 18 January 1981. Was the Minister aware that in September last year Mr Jim Kirk, the Chairman and Managing Director of Esso, told a meeting of the Securities Institute of Australia in Brisbane that serious technical problems had been experienced with the project, that the estimated cost of stage 1 had increased to $1,500m and that Esso was not even sure that it would be able to sell the products because of their likely high price? If the Minister was aware of the reservations held at that stage by Esso, did he have them investigated? If he did, what advice did he receive in response? Will the Minister acknowledge that there were good grounds for doubt about the future of Rundle in September last year and that the subsequent talking up of the project against Esso's advice was only to promote the electoral advantage of the Government?

—As I indicated to the Senate in answer to a question-Senator Button may well be aware of it; it is recorded in Hansard-I discovered only several months ago that Mr Kirk had made roughly the kinds of statements that Senator Button has indicated. I said that a number of statements, including my own, had been made over that period urging caution. The fact is that on a number of occasions I drew attention from public platforms to the magnitude of the enterprise and the huge amounts of money involved. Many a time honourable senators have heard me indicate in this Senate that the proposal was to do something that was unprecedented-to shift one million tonnes of rock a day-and that that in itself offered huge challenges. So, over that period, a considerable amount of warning was given. The fact is that in that period, following Mr Kirk's statement-as I now know, and it may or may not be related-there was a much increased trading on the exchange. I have been able to show this Senate many times that both the Australian partners' shares halved between that time and the days before I went to Rundle. So, in fact, there was no talking up of shares. The shares were being successively, day by day, reduced in value over the whole period. I have shown that the heavy volume of trading was ahead of my own visit and that what I said was absolutely true-that I had no reason to believe there would be any change in the timetables or the volumes that Esso would produce until in fact I was given the briefing. Until then I had not received from anyone any such information. As soon as I received it, the Government and I acted on it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and refers to the bank mergers now being attempted throughout Australia. One reason that has been given is that larger banks will be better protected against foreign banks. Therefore I ask: Why does Australia need, and allow, foreign banks within the country? Is it true that the public would be better served by more competition between banks rather than less? Thirdly, what is the Government's attitude towards the bank mergers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that the Treasurer issued a Press release on 11 May with regard to bank mergers. I believe that in that statement he noted that any merger of banks in this country was subject to the provisions of section 63 of the Banking Act, which requires the consent of the Treasurer before banks may enter into amalgamation arrangements or effect a reconstruction. However, the Treasurer pointed out that the section also provides that the consent of the Treasurer shall not be unreasonably withheld. We should consider the questions raised by Senator Townley against that background. Many people would argue that more competition between banks is desirable, particularly when that can give greater service, consistent with the security that people require of a banking system in this country. We ought to note also that in recent years there have been many changes in the financial arrangements in this country, with the growth of credit unions and the development of other facilities. Therefore, when we are talking about banking facilities we are not simply talking about a number of major banks. There are also within the States the State banks, and perhaps a much wider range of assistance can be given by the use of their resources. I will ascertain whether the Treasurer has any direct comment to make on the matters raised and, if so, I will advise the honourable senator.

—I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, by stating that it is not com- plementary to the one that was asked a short while ago by Senator Puplick but is in line with a question that I asked a couple of weeks ago. I ask: Now that the second Irish hunger striker, Frankie Hughes, has died, will the Minister reconsider the suggestion I put forward previously, that this Government approach the British Prime Minister, Mrs Thatcher, in an effort to save the lives of the remaining three hunger strikers. If this suggestion is considered to be unacceptable, will the Government approach the United Nations with a view to examining the possibility of having the British troops repatriated and their role taken over by a United Nations peacekeeping force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The latter situation would be, of course, in defiance of the whole question of natural sovereignty. The United Nations would not consider it. There is no question at all about the sovereignty of Northern Ireland. It is in general well accepted that the internal affairs of a country are sovereign matters for that country. The British Government has a direct and sovereign responsibility for peacekeeping in Northern Ireland, and in fact Northern Ireland is part of its democratic responsibility. I do not want to inflame this matter in any way. I have said that here previously. The British Government has taken the view-I believe the correct view-that the persons who have been gaoled have been gaoled for criminal offences and not for political offences. That is the first thing. They have been gaoled for acts of armed aggression. I think Bobby Sands was gaoled for armed robbery and subsequently for being in possession of arms. These are crimes in this country, as they are in any democratic country. The ordinary processes of law take place and then the ordinary course of punishment takes place.

ANSWER.PARA: What is happening-it is a lamentable situation-is that a number of people are seeking to make a political point by committing suicide. One deplores that, but that is their choice. I said that I would refer a previous question to the Minister in another place. I will do so. I acted before in such a reference. The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom has made the intentions of her sovereign Government quite clear. Her Government has set a standard for the world in observing the rule of law. I am utterly sure that it will observe the rule of law there as it does elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, follows the thrust of the question asked earlier by my colleague Senator Townley. Will the Minister not agree that the Australian trading bank system with its unique system of overdrafts and branch banking has served Australia well? As the only justification for further amalgamation, recognising the high rate of profitability of banks, is for them to shore themselves up against foreign competition, will the Government assure the Senate that adequate protection will be given to the staff of the banks and that foreign banks will not be allowed to pick all the ripe plums out of the financial system, thus leaving the Australian banking system with two major banks-one government bank and one private enterprise bank? Further, will the Government extend its existing heavy controls over the banking system to cover the important aspect of ownership?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As with the previous question, I will refer this question to the Treasurer for specific comment. But again I draw attention to the section of the banking legislation which provides that consent of the Treasurer shall not be unreasonably withheld should proposed mergers, amalgamations or reconstructions be put before him. The Treasurer said in his recent statement that he would not wish to prejudice the outcome of specific consideration of a particular application that may be the subject of some public discussion at present. He also stated that his general view is that strong national interest considerations would need to be involved before the Government sought to interfere with normal commercial processes. Part of Senator Watson's question related to guarantees and protection for the staff of banks. I have no comment to make on what would be one of the commercial processes if there were changes through amalgamation or reconstruction. But I will refer the two parts of the question to the Treasurer to see whether he wishes to make any further comment on the specific matters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I refer to an interview reported in the West Australian of Wednesday, 6 May, by Allan Veal with Sir Philip Baxter, one of the founders of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission set up by the Menzies Government in 1953. In that interview Sir Philip is reported to have said:

QUESTION.PARA: We need to develop our armed forces and our systems of defence using the most scientific methods that are available-nuclear weapons, chemical and bacteriological warfare.

In view of the Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production and Stockpiling of Bacteriological (Biological) and Toxin Weapons and on their Destruction, ratified by Australia on 5 October 1977, will the Minister clarify the Government's position on this important matter? As Sir Philip Baxter is a person of some note in our community and is even held in high regard by some, will the Minister consider making a public response to his statements to assuage the fears of a large section of the Australian community that we may indeed be committing this country to the future use of such abominations?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer that question to the Minister for Defence. I will submit to him the proposal from Senator Coleman.

—Can the Minister for Finance explain why interest rates which have reached a record level-I believe overdraft rates are now 16.4 per cent-are showing no sign of easing? How does she consider the statement made by a prominent banker that interest rates will not drop? Can she give any indication of when these massive interest rates, which are a heavy cost on the community and a fuel to inflation, are likely to drop?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I speak on behalf of the Treasurer, and I am sure he would say that no Minister of the Government should add to the speculation with regard to interest rates. I think people understand the reasons why interest rates are at the present level. I certainly would not speculate on behalf of the Treasurer on the rate of change or the likelihood of change in interest rate levels.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Colston inquired about the effect of the Government's decision to reintroduce fees for certain categories of students, that is, on students who enrol in the second semester this year in a second degree or post-graduate course. The Minister for Education indicated in his media release of 8 May this year:

ANSWER.PARA: The fees for second and higher qualifications in universities and colleges of advanced education will apply only to those enrolling in these courses for the first time in 1982.

Thus students enrolling in and commencing these courses in the second semester 1981 will not be required to pay fees for the duration of their courses. However, students commencing such courses in 1982 will be required to pay fees, if not otherwise exempted. I emphasise that students enrolled in recognised combined courses and higher degree students for the Commonwealth university or college of advanced education post-graduate award will not be required to pay fees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator O'Byrne drew attention to a question asked of me at the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference held earlier this week and to my reply that I thought a majority of post-graduate students would be covered. I said that I would seek information and I sought to do so. In 1980 there were an estimated 21,000 higher degree students in Australia of which 7,000 were full time students and 14,000 were part time students. Of the full time students, approximately 4,000-or a majority of the full time higher degree students-had either Commonwealth Government awards or awards from universities and colleges of advanced education. This figure excludes, of course, private overseas students who are required to pay a levy in lieu of fees. In 1980 there was also a significant number of students enrolled in recognised double degree and diploma combinations. Students enrolling in these courses will be exempt from the payment of fees.

ANSWER.PARA: No figures are available to indicate the number of students in receipt of awards other than Commonwealth or university post-graduate awards. A considerable but inestimable number of part time post-graduate students are employed by universities or CAEs and would probably continue to receive free tuition. Many of the 14,000 students studying part time for higher qualifications are teachers studying for specialist qualifications which will be exempt from tuition fees as they are a recognised double degree or diploma combination. I should add that the commencing figures for post-graduate studies in 1980 are as follows: Total enrolments in new post-graduate studies for masters and doctor of philosophy degrees only, 5,000; total enrolments for new post-graduate diplomas, 19,000. It will be seen that a significant number of students in the post-graduate area have support programs from one source or another.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Grimes asked me a question about the indexation of the weekly income limits for low income groups under the new health arrangements for the disadvantaged. I replied to that question at the time but I wish to amplify my reply. I stated that the figure, which is presently $160, will vary twice a year. That is quite correct, but the full figure of $160 will not be indexed. In other words, it has a component which will be indexed and other components which will not be indexed.

ANSWER.PARA: The weekly limits were specified on the basis of the cut-out point for unemployment benefit for a married couple without children. That is the level of private income at which entitlement to unemployment benefit ceases. At the May 1981 married rate of benefit of $111.10 a week, this cut-out point is $139.10. The weekly income limit for a married couple without children or a sole parent with one child is $20 above this cut-out point, rounded up to the next whole dollar. That is the figure of $160 which I gave yesterday, and which applies to the current rates of benefit.

The weekly limit for a person without dependants is 60 per cent of this amount, that is, $96. When the married rate of unemployment benefit is increased each May and November in line with movements in the consumer price index in the preceding December and June quarters respectively, the cut-out point for unemployment benefit increases by the same amount and therefore the weekly income limits under the health arrangements will also automatically increase. The six-monthly indexation of the married benefit rate will obviously not lead to a full CPI increase in the weekly limits for disadvantaged status as a low income family. That is because certain elements-for example, the $20 and the earning limits-are not automatically indexed. The Government will have to review the limits on a regular basis, as it reviews other non-indexed benefits.

For each child of a married couple or each child of a sole parent after the first child, the basic weekly income limit increases by twice the rate of additional benefit for children, which is currently $10 a week each. That is an adjustment of $20 for each child. This additional benefit rate, which determines the additional component for children in the weekly income limit for disadvantaged status, is also subject to review.

That may all sound terribly complicated, but from the point of view of those who wish to seek the benefit of this provision it is straightforward that the present income limit for a married couple is $160. It will rise on a twice-yearly basis by amounts which will be announced at the time. An additional amount of $20 a week is allowed for each child. That amount will vary when and if there are additions to the benefits which are provided for children. So the position of potential beneficiaries is quite straightforward. The income limits will be clearly laid down and beneficiaries will know where they stand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Bonner asked a question concerning a dialler for disabled people which has been on display in the Parliament. I undertook to try to get some advice for the honourable senator during Question Time. The device is known as an access dialler. I note that it was developed by a voluntary group working within Telecom Australia. I think it is worth paying tribute to the Telecom operators who have done this.
—They would be trade unionists. You usually can them.

—I do not know why the honourable senator is interjecting. I am trying to pay tribute to a group of Telecom workers. I do not know what Senator Primmer has against these people. I am saying that this group of people within Telecom has worked to develop this device for the advantage of disabled people. Knowing Senator Bonner's interest in this matter, we have been able to get some advice for him. Telecom hopes to call tenders for the manufacture of the unit withind a month with a view to the unit being manufactured in 1982. Depending upon the cost of the unit-at this stage we can only guess, but Telecom believes that it may be less than $400 a unit-it will then be distributed by Telecom on a sale or rental basis, the final method being determined to some extent by the final cost of the units.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH LEGAL AID COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission Act 1977.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Ryan proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damage to the Australian education system resulting from the ad hoc, ill considered decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise this matter of public importance today because of the crisis situation we have reached with regard to the Government's decisions concerning education. Honourable senators will note that it is the whole of the education system which we believe will be damaged by the ill-considered and ad hoc decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, otherwise aptly known as the razor gang report. I assert that the education decisions in that report are indefensible. I do not believe that any Government senator speaking after me in this debate will be able to defend any of those decisions on the grounds of financial responsibility, or of administrative efficiency, and certainly not on the grounds of their doing anything to improve access to education or creating more equality in this society. In fact the overall effect of all of the Government's education decisions will be directly to the contrary, that is, to deny access to an increasing number of Australian citizens and to ensure that access to higher education, in particular to higher degrees and post-graduate work, will be the domain of an elite. It will not be an elite based on ability-a situation, of course, which is defensible-but an elite based on the ability to pay, which is in the interests of nobody and is certainly not in the interests of this country. The razor gang's attack on education is not just an attack on education options for individuals; it is an attack also on research and development in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I say at the outset that we are not an over-educated community. That is a claim which is sometimes made by Government senators and by other people outside this place, but it is totally unable to be substantiated. It is a myth perpetrated by self-seeking politicians and anti-intellectual elements of the Press. We are, in fact, an under-educated community. We are failing to keep pace with Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. I quote the figures from the 1976 census with regard to the measurement of higher education in this country. I quote from that census because they are the most recent figures available. When we look at the population aged 15 years and over we find that only 1.97 per cent of people have bachelor's degrees, only 0.42 per cent of people have graduate diplomas and only 0.35 per cent of citizens have higher degrees. In the face of statistics like those, I do not think anybody can argue with any sense that we are an over-educated community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is much higher in recurrent terms. It is double that.

—If Senator Teague has statistics that can show a more favourable view, I hope he will bring them forth, but they are the latest figures available from the census. I think it is worth emphasising too that the enrolments of students in the secondary system are very low-dangerously low-if we compare them with enrolments in OECD countries. In relation to full time school enrolments of 15 to 19 year olds, Australia inauspiciously ranks No. 14 on an OECD table of 23 nations with only a 45 per cent involvement in contrast to comparative figures of 74 per cent for the United States of America and 70 per cent for Switzerland.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation regarding the Australian Research Grants Scheme, which was, of course, the major means by which the Federal Government supported research in this country, is also very seriously damaged by administrative and financial recommendations of the razor gang. I should like to quote from a document on the Australian Research Grants Scheme prepared by the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations in April 1981. The document points out that in 1981 the ARGS was allocated only $16m, which of course is considerably less in real terms than its initial grant in 1966. So, in terms of Federal involvement in research, Federal support for research so vital to Australia's economy, we have actually been going backwards since 1966. The document goes on to point out:
Unless Australia's research capability and its human resources are developed together with its physical resources, we will become a quarry for other nations which develop both.
The Australian Research Grants Committee has made a number of pertinent comments. It said:
The reduction in the average grant in real terms means that the Committee is unable to recommend sufficient support to enable the best investigators to achieve their research potential.
The Committee further said:

The extent of the withdrawal of support for worthwhile projects can be gauged from the increased number of proposals judged by the Committee's external assessors to be of good quality which could not be supported. In 1980 there was 112 such cases; in 1981 this figure has risen to 296.

The ARGS is having to reject an increasing number of the highest standard research projects which would, of course, be of great benefit to our economy and our society. Again, overseas comparisons put us in a very poor light indeed. An overseas comparison done by the ARGC points out that Australia ranks thirteenth among the developed countries in terms of research spending, far below countries such as the United Kingdom, France, Sweden, Japan, Belgium and Canada, and ranks equal to Finland, Ireland and Italy. Only Ireland, New Zealand, Spain and Portugal spend a smaller percentage of their gross domestic product on research and development.

It seems that the Fraser Government is unprepared to support in a way that even compares modestly with other OECD countries any sort of serious effort in research and development in this country. I remind honourable senators that this is at a time when the structure of the Australian economy is totally inappropriate to meet current economic problems and when we are falling behind in every area of advanced technology, planning, entrepreneurial skills and any other ability which would enable the economy to be revived. It seems that the Fraser Government prefers to put people on the dole rather than allow them to develop their skills and knowledge in tertiary institutions.

One of the reasons for the very high rates of youth unemployment in Australia, when we compare our rates with countries such as Austria, West Germany, Holland, Sweden and Japan, is that we have such low participation rates in post-secondary education. The Tertiary Education Commission's recent report on rates of participation in tertiary education, of that section of the population aged between 17 and 29 years, found that only 4.4 per cent of the population are in universities, in colleges of advanced education only 4.9 per cent, and in technical and further education institutions only 16.5 per cent. When we compare those figures with the exceptionally high figures of youth unemployment for the same age bracket-for example, we have 25 per cent of young girls unemployed in some parts of Australia-we can see what is happening. Instead of allowing and facilitating the movement of young people from school into higher education or vocational training, we are simply putting them on the dole, forcing them to join the unemployment statistics. How any government can defend that action is completely beyond me.

The Fraser Government and the razor gang are selling Australia short by these latest decisions on education. They are depriving us of a prosperous economic future by depriving us of new skills and new solutions to current economic problems. I speak for those on this side of the chamber when I say that we do not want Australia to be merely the world's quarry. Australia ought to be a world leader in relevant aspects of new technology-for example, solar energy, agricultural technology, medical technology, irrigation technology. These are all areas in which Australians have achieved very distinguished breakthroughs in research in the past, but they are areas in which we are now falling behind. We will fall further behind now that the most talented and motivated people will be denied the opportunity to pursue a higher degree.

After Question Time today Senator Carrick tried to defend his claim that there are enough post-graduate awards to cover the able post-graduate students. I was interested to follow the figures that he put forward, but those figures do not answer our criticism. Our criticism is that the vast majority of people currently engaged in post-graduate study do not have access to a post-graduate award or degree. Many of those people, we are informed by their representative organisations, will have to withdraw from post-graduate study. The statistics from the Tertiary Education Commission's triennial report show that in 1980 there were 21,629 students at higher degree levels in universities and colleges of advanced education, of which 14,277 were part time enrolments; that is, some 66 per cent of the total. Of course no scholarships are available for part time students. So already two-thirds of students at higher degree levels have no access to any sort of post-graduate fellowship. In relation to 1980 commencing students, there were 5,589 new enrolments for higher degrees in universities and only 1,148 were receiving an award. This latter figure represents about 20 per cent of the total. So if we extrapolate from those figures-we have no more precise figures available-we can say that between 15 and 20 per cent of higher degree students have awards of some description. I ask Senator Carrick: What will happen to the other 80 per cent? It seems to me, from representations that I have received from student bodies and from staff associations, that a vast majority of that 80 per cent of students will not be able to pursue their post-graduate studies. Why are we wasting four-fifths of the able post-graduate students' abilities by having this ludicrous new system of imposing fees and student loans?

One of the worst aspects of the Government's education decisions is that they have been taken contrary to the advice and experience of those people who ought to advise the Government, namely the Vice Chancellors and the staff associations. I will quote briefly from a letter written on 11 May by the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations to my colleague Mr Dawkins. The letter is signed by Dr Darvall, the President, who states:
I refer to the government's decision to introduce fees for post-graduate students.

I draw to your attention the close link between research and post-graduate work in Australia's universities. An attack on post-graduates is an attack on research, indeed an attack on the whole basis of Australian universities as they now exist.

Many post-graduates-particularly those engaged in research degrees-are supporting themselves only by part-time work and many could not afford the fees. The direct effect of the government's decision will be to decrease post-graduate enrolments at a time when we most need to invest in our human resources.

Why is not the Government taking note of the people who are involved and who know what is happening? Why instead does it pursue with its ideological fanatacism, an attack, an onslaught on wider access to education within our community?

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Government educates us too much we might start asking for other information.

—I think there is a sinister explanation which Senator Coleman has suggested. I think that the Fraser Government feels that it will not profit by having a community in which education, understanding and the ability to criticise are prevalent. The Fraser Government believes that its best interests are served by keeping people ignorant, frightened and able to be manipulated. Why has the Government decided to put this unnecessary obstacle in the way of people seeking higher degrees? Certainly financial savings for the public purse, which is supposed to be the rationale of these decisions, cannot be regarded as a satisfactory explanation. The amount of money gained by the imposition of fees will represent a minimal amount of the education budget-less than half of one per cent. Most of that amount can be cancelled out by the administrative costs of gathering the fees. So there is no financial reason for these changes. There must be an ideological reason. It appears that the Government is determined that higher education, along with first class health care, will be accessible only to the affluent in our community. This is a drastic and tragic reversal of national educational policies which have been developed by all Federal governments since the end of the Second World War. The effect on individuals as well as our society generally will be disastrous.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to restrict eligibility for the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, to introduce a student loans scheme and to impose tertiary fees, in contradiction of an unambiguous election promise, will together exclude the majority of able and motivated students from higher education. One group of people in our society which particularly benefited from the expansion of higher education and from the abolition of tertiary fees by the Whitlam Government was that group comprising female students. Enrolment figures in all of our tertiary institutions show a marked increase in the number of women students who were able to enrol following the abolition of fees. Many of these women are mature age students who are taking up an opportunity which was denied them earlier for financial reasons. They have proved to be excellent students and successful graduates and many of them are now engaged in post-graduate studies or contributing to the work force, particularly in areas such as teaching. That is a development which I hope all honourable senators will applaud.

Mature age women with children to support will simply not be able to pay fees nor will they be able to burden the family budget with a student loan. So their opportunity to improve themselves, to raise the standard of living of their families and to make a contribution to society, will be destroyed. Many post-graduate students from modest backgrounds are married and in the age group in which it is most desirable to begin a family. It will be impossible for post-graduate students, with family commitments, to avail themselves of a loans scheme or to pay fees. So again post-graduates' families will be penalised heavily by the new arrangements.

The decision further to restrict eligibility for TEAS is a decision to restrict a scheme which is already grossly inadequate as a form of financial support for students without wealthy parents. The conventional methods of supplementing tertiary assistance, namely part time jobs in the general work force or part time tutoring within universities, have both virtually disappeared. When we look at the most disadvantaged group of people in our society-the Australian Aborigines-we find that their participation in higher education is so low as to be statistically insignificant. I believe that the future of Aboriginal people depends to a very large extent on a significant number of Aboriginal people acquiring skills in areas such as medicine, law, administration and so on so that they will be able to deal with the enormous problems which face their communities and with the prejudice that resides in the white community. The imposition of fees and the burden of having to take on a loan is totally oppressive and totally out of the question for this group.

The Curriculum Development Centre, which is also the subject of attacks by the razor gang and which may disappear if the States are not prepared to foot the bill, has made a major contribution to Aboriginal education by developing for the first time, in consultation with Aboriginal communities, national programs of English and mathematics instruction. I believe it will be a tragedy for the future of Aboriginal people in this country if that particular education program, which is currently being developed by the Curriculum Development Centre, goes under because the Government is not prepared to foot the bill to the tune of a couple of million dollars.

Denying students access to our tertiary education makes no economic sense. On the contrary, it is the squandering of a public investment which has already been made. We have an impressive network of publicly funded tertiary institutions throughout Australia. The facilities are there, the staff are there and the students wish to study. By depriving the students of the opportunity to use the facilities already established the Government is creating a situation of waste and instability within those institutions.

If we look at the current trends in tertiary education, which have been documented by the Tertiary Education Commission, we find that in higher education there have been increased enrolments in part time and external studies but a decline in full time enrolments. There has been an increase in the proportion of older students studying but a decrease in the number of younger students studying. Within all three sectors of tertiary education there has been an increase in the number of women students. If we examine those trends, which were established before the decisions of the Lynch committee, in terms of the decisions of the Lynch Committee we can see how absolutely destructive those decisions are because all of these trends demonstrate that prevailing assistance for full time study is totally inadequate and that full time enrolments are declining even without allowing for the razor gang's decisions.

The appropriateness of a loans scheme, which may in some instances apply to wealthy students undertaking medical or legal studies although I would be critical of such a scheme even in respect of such groups, is entirely dubious when it is applied to the increasing proportion of older students and to women students. Students in either of those groups, as I have pointed out, are not in a financial position to take on the economic burden of a loan and of course they will simply drop out. The growth that we badly need in our tertiary institutions will stop. The decline in enrolments by younger students is already a serious problem and that will increase. The main reasons for the decline in enrolments by younger students are that the financial support for their studies is so inadequate and part time jobs are not available. So they will be condemned to unemployment at public expense while lecture halls, libraries and laboratories are left empty; again at the expense of the public purse. The whole situation is irrational and discriminatory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: — This debate is predicated on a number of assumptions which have been made by Senator Ryan and various academic unions and groups none of which, of course, we are asked to believe have any self-interest in this matter. These responses are to the decisions which have been announced by the Review of Commonwealth Functions. I therefore think it is important to understand something about the background of what exactly that review was seeking to do. The decisions taken by that Committee of Review were not made with education as the sole target of its inquiries, nor were the decisions that were made about education taken in isolation from all the other decisions announced about the structure, the role of and the services to be provided by the Commonwealth Government. Clearly the background to the Review of Commonwealth Functions was the desire in the community for the Federal Government to be in a position to be able to offer lower rates of tax and for there to be less general imposition on Australian citizens while at the same time preserving and continuing to supply the services regarded as necessary and proper for a Federal government to be providing. That desire can be achieved in any number of ways. It can be achieved by a better delivery of the services that are to be provided; it can be achieved by more efficiency in the provision of services to be offered; or it can be achieved by avoiding unnecessary waste and duplication where there is more than one party to the provision of any particular service.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been clear from the outset-it has been clear from the time of the 1974 and 1975 elections at least-that this Government has had a commitment to a genuinely federalist system of government based on a reallocation of resources and responsibilities between Commonwealth and State governments that had got so badly out of kilter not only in the period 1972 to 1975 but also in the period prior to 1972. It should therefore have been no surprise to anybody that the relocation of functions and the reallocation of resources between the Commonwealth and the States take place across the board and that no special exception would be made for the education sector. This discussion today invites the Senate to apply three tests to the decisions made by the committee of review.
