The three tests-all explicit in the terms of Senator Ryan's proposal-are: Has the decision on education damaged the system? Was the decision ad hoc? Was the decision ill-conceived? I propose to deal with a number of the decisions announced in the Lynch committee report and test them against that background.

The first relates to the abolition of the Curriculum Development Centre. All State governments have within their education system extensive curriculum development operations to meet their own requirements because whether we like it or not State education systems in many respects are still different and distinct from each other. We eventually acquired an overriding Commonwealth Curriculum Development Centre. The Government has said that clearly it is duplicating a number of the functions currently being performed by the curriculum development bodies in the States. After all, the Commonwealth itself virtually no longer provides direct education which could be influenced by Curriculum Development Centre recommendations other than in the Australian Capital Territory. If the States themselves believe they could get benefit out of the work of the CDC all they have to do is to undertake to pay between them half of the costs of the CDC. That is not an unreasonable statement to make. We have said that if the States are prepared to pay half of the costs of the Centre we will keep it in operation. We have also said that where there are significant national undertakings of a curriculum development type, we will ensure within the Commonwealth Department of Education that appropriate research is undertaken on them. Therefore the specific matter mentioned by Senator Ryan, that of the Aboriginal education program, is one that will not disappear because the CDC may not continue to exist. Clearly it is one that will be capable of being picked up within the other resources that the Commonwealth will make available-I will come to this later-under the question of research and the allocation of funds for research. Thus the CDC arguments put forward by the Labor Party do not stand up.

I come now to the abolition of the Education Research and Development Committee. We have simply said that instead of having a separate committee the Commonwealth Education portfolio will be provided from the Budget with a total amount for its research activities; they will be earmarked for research and they will be capable of being used by the Commonwealth Department of Education for research on whichever projects it happens to regard as worthy of funding or being in need of additional research. It can be seen from the statement put down yesterday in the House of Representatives by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) entitled 'Science and Technology 1980-81' where, across the whole broad spectrum of Commonwealth Government research activity, research is taking place into educational matters. It is not simply confined to the Commonwealth Department of Education.

I come now to the introduction of the system of student loans. I will say very little on this because my colleague Senator Teague will be discussing this at some length. I simply say that in May 1977 the Butcher Committee on Student Loans was established to examine the desirability and feasibility of introducing a system of loans for Australian post-secondary students. The first recommendation of that committee was:
A system of loans for needy students at the post-secondary level of education should be established as a supplement to existing grants schemes.

Where is the ad hockery, where is the ill-conceived nature of a decision which is based on a recommendation made by an expert committee to a government in fact some four or five years ago? What is ad hoc about responding to a committee established by the Government to investigate a particular matter and which recommended a system of student loans? When the Government gets round to saying 'Yes, we will pick that up. We in fact will have a system of student loans', Senator Ryan says: 'That is an ad hoc and ill-conceived decision'. The Government has made a clear statement on what it intends to do as far as the rationalisation of the position of Colleges of Advanced Education is concerned, and that is to ensure again that we get greater value for the education dollar while in no way depressing the quality of education available. I quote from the report of the Tertiary Education Commission for the 1982-84 triennium. It states:
The Commission proposes to adopt the following policy objectives in relation to higher education for the 1982-84 triennium:

(a) Resources to be reallocated from teacher education to other activities. This reallocation should be completed by the year 1984. To achieve these objectives, the Commission will be recommending in Volume 2 levels of funding for 1984 for CAEs involved in teacher education which will reflect their decreased teaching responsibilities; it will be recommending increased levels of funding for those institutions which are expanding their effort in the technologies and business studies.

(b) Institutions which are predominantly concerned with teacher education to be consolidated into larger units by their incorporation into multi-purpose or multi-campus CAEs or by integration with neighbouring universities.

The test that Senator Ryan wanted to put forward was that the decision of the Government was ad hoc and ill-conceived. The fact is that the Tertiary Education Commission, which from time to time is used as one of the great touchstones of Labor Party debates on education, clearly in its triennial report to the Government has recommended a reallocation of resources from teacher education institutions and a consolidation of institutions. Unless it be thought that any swifties were being pulled regarding the institutions to be affected, I draw attention to the supplementary report of the Tertiary Education Commission entitled 'Summary of Recommendation on Guidelines'. In paragraph 9.46 on page 269 will be found the list of institutions which the TEC recommends ought to be rationalised, merged and integrated. That is the same list as appears in the Lynch committee report. That is neither ad hoc nor ill-conceived. It gives effect to a recommendation made to a government by its own principal and primary expert body advising it on post-secondary education-the Tertiary Education Commission. Therefore, that as a decision negates all of the tests-damage, ad hockery or ill-conception-that Senator Ryan has sought to put forward in her matter of public importance. To say that this was done without the benefit of expert advice flies in the face of the clear and demonstrable evidence that the Government's primary advisers have suggested this course of action.

I should like to refer to what we are proposing for tertiary education in Western Australia. Grants to the Murdoch University and the University of Western Australia will be dependent upon closer integration of the resources of those two institutions. Again, that is in response to an earlier comment by the TEC and indeed the Williams Committee about the integration of universities in Western Australia. Again, that comment will be found in the latest volume of the Commission's report. Its recommendation has been picked up.

I am glad that the Opposition Whip, Senator Robertson, has come into the chamber at this stage, because the next decision made by the Lynch committee was not to proceed with the funding of a university in the Northern Territory in this triennium. It is amazing that that was not criticised by Senator Ryan. After all it is not a matter that only I have raised. Senator Button, Senator Ryan and Senator Robertson have clearly indicated that the Labor Party is not in favour of the establishment of a university in the Northern Territory. That point has been made by honourable senators on this side of the chamber. That is one of the decisions which was made by the Lynch committee and announced in its report.

The Opposition's matter of public importance says that it is concerned about damage to education or about the decisions being ad hoc or ill-conceived. What in fact it means is that it does not agree with some decisions announced by the Lynch committee. Those decisions with which the Opposition does agree are excluded by it from the categories of being damaging, being the result of ad hoc decisions or being ill-conceived. Therefore, presumably parts of the Lynch committee recommendations on education are not damaging, not ad hoc and not ill-conceived but, indeed, are to be welcomed by the Australian Labor Party.

I turn now to the Schools Commission. The Government has indicated clearly on page 22 of the report of the Lynch committee that the role of the Schools Commission, in terms of its direct involvement at a State level, is to be wound down. The report states:

There will be a reduction in the Schools Commission's direct involvement in program administration and information collection. Accordingly, the activities of the State offices of the Commission will be scaled down and the Buildings Unit in the Central Office disbanded.

It is absolutely right and proper that responsibility for the structuring, building, administration and development of schools within the separate States is a matter for the separate States to pursue in a way in which they consider appropriate and their electors consider appropriate, and in line with their clear constitutional responsibilities. The Government has said in the Lynch committee report that it intends to integrate the Education Program for Unemployed Youth with the school to work transition program. The two-volume report entitled 'An Evaluation of the Education Program for Unemployed Youth' prepared for the Commonwealth Department of Education by G. D. Hubbert contains recommendations that are in no way incompatible with recommendations which the Lynch committee has made on the integration of the EPUY scheme with the more broad, general and comprehensive school to work transition program.

I now turn to the matter of fees. I know that my colleague Senator Teague will be saying something about this matter also. I think it was mischievous for Senator Ryan to trot out the sort of figures which she did about who will be disadvantaged at a post-graduate level. She said, for instance, that part time students are not eligible for post-graduate awards. What she disguised was the fact that a very large proportion of those part time students are part time students because they are also part time employees of the university concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—I will come to that in a moment. If Senator Ryan can contain her impatience everything will be revealed to her. It is entirely fallacious to lump together all part time students as if they had no means of support or assistance from their own institutions. If one looks at the intake of master and doctor of philosophy students in 1980, one finds that approximately 2,000 of the initial 5,000 students who commenced studies in 1980 were in one respect or another holders of post-graduate awards or awards through universities as a result of which they would be exempt from the payment of fees under the scheme which the Government has announced.

SPEECH.PARA: I ought to make clear four points about tertiary fees. First, from the beginning of 1982 fees will be introduced only for second and higher qualifications in universities and colleges of advanced education. No fees will be imposed for undergraduate students. Secondly, fees will apply only to those enrolling for the first time in 1982. In other words, those continuing in their studies should not be affected. Thirdly, fees will not apply to recognised double degree and diploma students. Many part timers are in fact doing double degrees and recognised diploma combinations-for instance, those who have their original degree in education who are taking diplomas which relate to special education, education of the handicapped or education of the blind. Fourthly, students in receipt of Commonwealth Government or university post-graduate awards will be exempt. From that point of view, the hysterical outburst on behalf of the various union and academic groups engaged-as numerous lobby groups are as a result of the Lynch committee recommendations -in an exercise of self-preservation of their own particular bailiwick, of the things that are particularly important to them regardless of the overall contribution that this situation will make, is not surprising.

For a general response to the matters raised by the Opposition I turn to the comments made by Dr John Bremer, the editor of the 'Higher Education' supplement in the Australian. He is a person who has been quoted in the past by honourable senators on both sides of the chamber. It has been accepted that he is a person whose knowledge on higher education is such that his comments should be taken seriously and be carefully weighed. In the 'Higher Education' supplement in the Australian of 6 May 1981, Dr Bremer wrote:
Firstly, the Prime Minister must be praised for having finally forced some decisions upon the tertiary education sector.

The inability of higher education to come to terms with such things as deadlines, budgets, society needs and power is notorious. The health of higher education has been deteriorating but little has been done-or even proposed-except the usual prescription of more money.
This is the standard Labor Party prescription. He continued:

That is simply unrealistic. Institutions and State co-ordinating bodies have shown little ability to reform themselves, and even the restricted attempts at change have caused turmoil and chaos. No wonder they have not got very far.
But the Prime Minister has finally laid it on the line, and he deserves full marks for courage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the second part of his article.

—If Senator Tate has the opportunity to read the rest of the article he will see that it states that there are probably more restrictions coming in terms of financial responsibility. That is a good thing too. Dr Bremer went on to indicate that he has a view about the Tertiary Education Commission. I have discussed that. Clearly the decisions that were announced in the Lynch committee report followed recommendations made by the Tertiary Education Commission itself in relation to a number of matters. These include college reorganisation, the situation in Darwin, the situation at the university of Western Australia, and the provision of earmarked funds-$5m,-in each of the next couple of years to facilitate what the Commission has recommended as a transition to get a greater degree of business studies and appropriate courses into universities and colleges. These recommendations, made by the Tertiary Education Commission, were picked up in the Lynch committee report and were enunciated in statements by the Minister. Dr Bremer went on to indicate that he has criticisms of what he regards as some of the 'rhetorical fluff' that goes with the statement. That may well be a fair enough criticism but it does not in one jot detract from the central proposition that making post-secondary education in Australia face up to its financial responsibilities is a good thing in itself. One should not be surprised that vice-chancellors, the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations, the Australian Union of Students or the Federation of College Staffs, or whoever it happens to be, see their own self-interests and positions threatened.

SPEECH.PARA: The tests which Senator Ryan has sought to put to the Senate this afternoon to show that it will damage the education system can be demonstrated to be false. The decisions were not ad hoc when one can demonstrate-whether by way of the Butcher Committee, the Tertiary Education Commission or Dr Hubbert's study of the EPUY-that there was nothing ad hoc in the responses to reports and recommendations that had been before the Government either in the couple of months immediately prior to the presentation of that response, or for a longer period of time. To state that they were ill-conceived when they are clearly part of what Dr Bremer and others recognise is an overall attempt to introduce some rationality into the post-secondary education system, in Australia, demonstrates that each of the three tests which Senator Ryan herself erected in her motion by accusations fails when weighed up against the facts and the decisions properly and rightfully made by the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the proposition brought forward by Senator Ryan because I believe it brings into the Senate chamber much of the dismay and the protest which has reverberated around Australia, not only at meetings of tens of thousands of students over the past 10 days or so but also, I believe, in many homes in Australia as families have begun to realise the impact which these decisions will have on the opportunities for their children whom they hoped would be succoured and helped by the Australian Government rather than be hindered, obstructed and impeded, which will be the effect of these proposals. Senator Puplick accused those who speak in this way of merely fostering some sort of hysterical self-interest, but what he failed to point out was that the former Federal Minister for Education, the senior Minister in this place, sat quietly in the chamber right throughout the debate. Of course, he put Senator Puplick up on the chopping block because Senator Puplick will be departing from this chamber in two or three weeks' time. Not a Minister has entered the debate to defend the razor gang's degradation of the Australian educational system. Instead we have people of the calibre of Senator Puplick, whom the electorate rejected, making a few rhetorical flourishes in a last desperate attempt to gain preselection in some future round.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall make some general points because Senator Puplick has very selectively referred to certain editorial and journalistic opinion. What comes through from any fair-minded reading of the criticism of the razor gang's foray into the educational system is the fact that it has quite missed its mark. In the name of smaller government the Cabinet has come up with a recipe for even more bureaucracy in the educational system. States and Territories will have to duplicate, triplicate, septlicate, if there is such a word. It will fragment and create a situation of political dependence throughout the States and Territories. At least before we were approaching what I believe was a real hope within the Australian community that we could create a national education policy in the sense of an education policy which indeed was for the whole Australian nation and which provided equality of educational opportunity for all Australians. But that hope, I believe, has been overborne and extinguished by the razor gang mentality which, as Senator Ryan has pointed out, really will create another elite within the Australian nation. When we discussed the overseas student fees legislation in this place some two years ago it was quite apparent that it would benefit the elites from overseas rather than the ordinary overseas person seeking the benefits of our education system. There has been a slow dismantling of that hope and aspiration of the Australian people which reached its fruition in the setting up of the Tertiary Education Commission and such bodies in the Whitlam years. This has been done without a mandate from the Australian people.

This is the real political point which honourable senators on the opposite side of this chamber have to answer. It is all right for Senator Puplick to say that reports came into being about four or five years ago. They languished in the Government's archives until an opportune moment arrived, as it did a few weeks ago. They have been dusted off and decisions have been made, ostensibly to save a few dollars, placing some reliance on those reports. But six months ago when the Government faced the electors at no stage was there any mention that families would have to bear the cost of raising loans for their children who perhaps had to travel to distant centres for tertiary education. At no point in that election campaign were post-graduate students told that they would have to find perhaps $1,500 to $3,000 a year to pay for attaining their second degree. At no stage has the Government obtained from the Australian electorate a mandate for this dismantling of the Australian educational system. Of course, in exactly the same way-the analogy is perfect-it dismantled Medibank and created medibungle No. 5 only a matter of weeks ago without a real mandate from the Australian people.

If Senator Puplick were correct in saying that all that one had was the hysterical outburst of a few student groups, perhaps one could understand the line he took. Not only do we have student, university and college of advanced education groups speaking in this way, but we also have the President of the Queensland branch of the Young Liberal Movement saying that the education cutbacks would guarantee the Government's defeat at the next election. Even more distinguished than that comment is that coming from Professor Bruce Williams, the Vice-Chancellor of Sydney University, whose remarks have been quoted to us time and time again, particularly when Senator Carrick was Minister for Education. He said that the terms of reference of his famous Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training instructed it to have regard to the Government's policy commitment to a widening of educational opportunities. This week, as a result of the razor gang's decisions, he said:
This Government has not lived up to its declared commitment.
He further said:
I oppose the fee scheme, for example, because it is a bad scheme. It will restrict opportunities and distort the allocation of resources.

That is the opinion of perhaps the most eminent academic who has conducted an inquiry into the Australian education system in recent years. To get down to the nitty-gritty of the situation, the imposition of fees for post-graduate tertiary studies has already been rebuffed by the very universities which will have to play an administrative role in collecting these fees. One finds, for example, that the University of Adelaide Council, which I would not have thought to be one of the more radical bodies within the Australian community, stated last week that it will refuse to administer the loans scheme as proposed by the Lynch committee on the grounds that it will deter disadvantaged students from tertiary study and diminish equality of opportunity. This is not merely a body of academics. Half of the members of the University of Adelaide Council, as with most councils, come from the general community.

I can assure honourable senators on the opposite side of this chamber that it is the whole community which is upset and dismayed at the way in which the Government is requiring those universities to divert their resources from teaching and to undertake administrative functions which will prove unbearable for those institutions. One has to think only of the simple mechanics of trying to recover bad debts to have some glimpse of the inordinate administrative strain which universities and colleges will be put under in trying to help to administer the Government's proposal. It is well known, for example, that two major banks in California have refused in recent times to grant student loans on the ground that the cost of chasing up defaulters has proved unbearable and unworkable.

We have no indication from the Government of how the loans scheme is to work. For example, we have not been told whether sheer market forces will operate in this field. If a person is to obtain a degree which promises some certainty of employment, of high earning power-such as in the fields of engineering and medicine-will the rate of interest he pays be lower than that paid by a student entering a field with poorer prospects of employment or salary levels that are only average? Who will guarantee the repayment of the loan? The Government makes a lot of the fact that the potential earning power of the student will form the guarantee for the loan, but what banker would loan money to a student before he had succesfully completed his first year of studies, before there was any evidence that the particular degree could be successfully undertaken by him and the potential earnings thereby realised?

What I found most objectionable in Senator Puplick's tirade was the implication that the opposition, the groups outside who were making a noise about this matter, were acting only out of self-interest, out of some hysterical attachment to their own ivory towers, to their own pursuit of a comfortable academic existence. What they are concerned about, and what I am particularly concerned about, is the effect on this nation's future capacity to deal, for example, with the resources boom. Senator Thomas, the Deputy Government Whip, would well know that the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, in its examination of alternatives to Australia's petroleum-based fuels, and in its inquiry into the aluminium industry, time and again has received evidence from engineering institutes, from the major corporations concerned and from government departments, that Australia is facing a critical shortage of the technologists, engineers and post-graduate trained personnel needed to make accelerated resources development, and the benefits that that will bring to Australia, a reality.

There can be no doubt that the decisions taken by the razor gang will stem rather than accelerate the flow of such qualified people into the work force. There is no doubt, as is made clear in submission after submission and letter after letter flowing into our offices, those decisions will reduce the supply of the properly trained scientists and technologists needed for these resource-led projects. I hold in my hand a letter from Dr Scott, the Dean of Science at the University of Tasmania, who makes the following point:

The fees are likely to be beyond the means of many students who now successfully undertake higher degrees in our Faculty without scholarship support, and who then go on to make valuable contributions to the development of this country.

That is surely the point-that the national research effort is dependent upon a regular movement of trained research personnel from the universities and colleges into the work force. The fact that the post-graduate research programs are now to be put in jeopardy by this Goverment seems also to put in some jeopardy the whole future of Australia's economic development.

I wish to indicate very briefly the deleterious effect which the imposition of the requirement that a student should supplement his Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance-if he is lucky enough to get one-or substitute for it a loan, will have on the participation rate of persons who live in centres away from the cities which house our tertiary education institutions. If one considers, for example, the position on the north-west coast of Tasmania, an area with which I am familiar, and the 1980 enrolments at the University of Tasmania, it becomes clear that whereas quite ordinary suburbs in Hobart such as Glenorchy and Bellerive send some 62 and 109 students respectively to the university, towns on the north-west coast, such as Devonport or Burnie, send in the region of 90 and 53. In fact, whereas Hobart's suburbs contribute some 1,100 students to the University population, only some 250 come from the whole of the north-west and west coasts of Tasmania. I predict that as families find it more and more difficult to raise the money to send their children to Hobart or Launceston to engage in tertiary studies, that disparity in numbers will become even more apparent. That is what the Government seems to fail to understand.

I still believe that there is some chance that the Government will see reason and modify its proposals, but if they are implemented there is no doubt that they will help to create within Australian society an elite of people whose access to health care will be dependent upon their financial resources and whose access to educational opportunity will equally be dependent on the financial resources that they can muster. That seems to represent an idealogically motivated attack on the education system. It is ad hoc. It is certainly without a mandate from the Australian people and it deserves the condemnation that has been expressed in this chamber and in dozens of meetings throughout Australia in the past week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a proposition by honourable senators opposite that some educational damage flows from the recently concluded Review of Commonwealth Functions, which is popularly known as the report of the razor gang. The report has focused on three main areas: The impact of proposed amalgamations of colleges of advanced education, the introduction of loans and some fees for tertiary students and, thirdly, the Schools Commission and the Curriculum Development Centre. I propose to touch on those three areas but, principally, to discuss the introduction, for tertiary students, of a system of loans and the payment of some fees.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I return to the direct mandate given by the people of Australia to the Fraser Government to implement a review of government functions. In 1975, 1977 and 1980 the people of Australia endorsed the Fraser Government's election program, whose consistent aim was to reduce government expenditure, reduce Commonwealth functions in favour of some of their returning to the States where appropriate or being administered by private enterprise. Government supporters offer no apology for the full-bodied pursuit of those programs, so clearly and continuously announced and advocated in the election context throughout the 1970s. The Review of Commonwealth Functions was one of the first tasks of the newly re-elected Fraser Government and a committee of five Ministers was set up to carry it out. That has been done carefully, comprehensively and fully over the last six months. The Governor-General, in opening this Parliament, said:

My Government will give particular attention to encouraging the growth of the private sector and to increasing the freedom of choice of taxpayers in spending their own incomes. It will be an important policy objective to continue to restrain public expenditure so as to provide scope for reducing the burden of taxation.
At another point, the Governor-General said:

But my Government does believe profoundly that it is vitally important that the power and functions of the State should be limited and contained. It does believe that the state is likely to be in many ways an inefficient and wasteful provider and that many services can be better supplied in other ways. And it does believe that the expansion of private enterprise is the best means to achieve the well-being and health of a society.

There is no apology for the Review of Commonwealth Functions. Indeed, any government so elected would be lacking in meeting its obligations to the people if it did not carry out periodic reviews in order to make sure that dead wood was cut away; that inappropriate functions were abolished; that efficiency was introduced and savings made. The Australian people continue to urge the lowering of taxes. That can be achieved only by a review of expenditure. There were some 400 decisions in the review announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) a fortnight ago. A handful of them related to education. As there have been reassessments in all areas of government, it is appropriate to find some areas of education that may be looked at. I believe the responsibilities and the funding programs of the Commonwealth were lightly touched in the review. In the process all Ministers were carefully consulted and other opinions were sought. The public knew that the review was being conducted. It ran its race for six months and it was far from being an ad hoc or lightly thought through process.

Whether it be with regard to loans or fees, the amalgamation of colleges of advanced education or the Schools Commission, the charge that the Opposition has made that the decisions are ad hoc cannot be sustained. The proposed loans scheme flows directly from the report of the Butcher committee which was brought to this Parliament four years ago. The amalgamation of CAEs is a direct fulfilment of the report of the Tertiary Education Commission which was brought to this Parliament only a month ago and which was widely commended and happily received by both the Government and the Opposition. The review of the Commonwealth's involvement in schools and in the Curriculum Development Centre was made after the fullest consultation with the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) and his Department. So the decisions are not ad hoc, are not damaging to education and are not lightly considered.

The details of the loans scheme, which is to operate from 1 January next year, have yet to be determined by the Government, but it is clear that the guidelines of the scheme will follow the findings of the Butcher report of four years ago. The scheme will be supplementary to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, which will not be abolished. It will be retained and the loans scheme will be added on to it. Senator Ryan said in her opening remarks that that would restrict access to education. I believe a supplementary scheme-supplementary finance-for tertiary students can only improve access to education for tertiary students. At the moment a number of students are quite ineligible for tertiary allowances. They are students who fail subjects, post-graduate students without awards and students from wealthy families.

I administered a loans scheme when I was employed at the University of Adelaide. I had six years of very careful experience of not only some superintendence of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme but also of student loans. In those years I was happy to see hundreds, even thousands, of students assisted to be successful in their studies through even small loans. Students who fail, post-graduate students who want to continue their studies without awards and students who may receive no support from their parents because of a disagreement but who are ineligible for TEAS support because of the means test on the income of their wealthy parents will welcome a loans scheme for tertiary students. All those categories of students will have new access to finance which will enable them to complete their studies. If the Butcher guidelines are to be followed, up to $8,000 may be borrowed. Repayments will be made over 15 years. There will be one year after graduation when no moneys will be required to be repaid.

Students from lower income families, who the Opposition says will now be denied access to education, will have the same ability to borrow. Their loans will be guaranteed not by their parents, by banks or by tertiary education institutions but by the Government. Such students will be required to pay back any loans that are necessary to meet their needs while they are students during a period when they are employed and when they have an income. Whether they come from low income families or from high income families, when in employment they will have the same means to repay the loans which helped them to get that employment. The Opposition is being pessimistic and alarmist because it has not taken up the quite generous terms of the Butcher committee report on student loans. I believe it is unfortunate that tertiary students have been given an exaggerated and pessimistic outlook of their prospects. I maintain that the addition of a loans scheme can provide additional finance to tertiary students and will give them very real benefits.

I believe it is unfortunate-Senator Tate referred to this-that the Council of my old university, the University of Adelaide, reacted recently in the context of that alarm and exaggeration by saying: 'We will not administer such a loans scheme. We will not raise these fees'. The alternative would be for the loans scheme at Adelaide University to be administered by the Department of Education whereby students would not have the same access to it and would not have the same speed of decision and the same service. I believe the University of Adelaide, through its Council, should reconsider the very quick decision it made and should make sure that it is able to serve its students.

One of the staff of the University of Adelaide, Professor Prescott, a man I admire and a member of the physics department, wrote a letter to me in which he said that the recent proposal concerning post-graduate students, if implemented, 'would cripple my department within 18 months'. I must respect the view that he put to me, but I believe he has reached a false conclusion because there will be the same ability for post-graduate physics students to enrol in that centre of excellence, the University of Adelaide physics department. The fear of a decline in research he alluded to in his letter to me is also ill-founded because the implication is that the number of post-graduate students will decline and hence the ability of the department to sustain its research will decline. Yet the post-graduate students without awards who are studying in that department at the moment will be all the more able, by receiving loans, to continue the physics research programs they are undertaking. I do not believe Professor Prescott's estimation is correct. I would like that to be noted in this debate so that in a year or two we will be able to see where we are.

I note that the Butcher committee's proposals were made on the basis of terms of reference given to it by the Fraser Government. They are summarised at page 10 of the Butcher committee's report in this way:

The Government's policy that all qualified students should be able to undertake tertiary education without hardship is specifically referred to in the Committee's terms of reference and the Committee accepted this as the starting point for its consideration of the subject and the touchstone on which all proposals should be tested.

That says that all qualified students should be able to undertake tertiary education without hardship. The loans scheme will provide additional finance for Australia's tertiary students. I believe it should be welcomed and will bring greater access to education for those students.

Let me put the situation with regard to fees into perspective. Undergraduate degrees, approved double degrees and degree-diploma combinations, students already involved in a second degree program, overseas students-who already are paying the equivalent of a fee for their studies-and post-graduate students with awards will not be subject to fees. The minority of tertiary students who will be required to pay an appropriate fee will have access to the loans scheme to pay it. The disadvantage they may suffer personally will be that over the 15 years after they graduate they will have to repay the loan.

I do not have time now to refer to the amalgamation of colleges of advanced education. I note only that these colleges will not be abolished. The Commonwealth will continue to fund 30 colleges and Murdoch University and the University of Western Australia but under new, more appropriate, better arrangements for the provision of educational programs in those places. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard section 5.30 and sections 5.42 to 5.52 of volume 1 of the Tertiary Education Commission report, because these sections directly set out the finding of the expert body on this matter.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
COMMISSION POLICY
5.30 The Commission proposes to adopt the following policy objectives in relation to higher education for the 1982-84 triennium:

(a) Resources to be reallocated from teacher education to other activities. This reallocation should be completed by the year 1984. To achieve these objectives, the Commission will be recommending in Volume 2 levels of funding for 1984 for CAEs involved in teacher education which will reflect their decreased teaching responsibilities; it will be recommending increased levels of funding for those institutions which are expanding their effort in the technologies and business studies.

(b) Institutions which are predominantly concerned with teacher education to be consolidated into larger units by their incorporation into multi-purpose or multi-campus CAEs or by integration with neighbouring universities.

The Commission believes that the policy under (b), which is already well advanced in some States, is a key element in the achievement of (a). The effect of it would be to reduce the number of separate institutions in the advanced education sector which are devoted principally to teacher education.
CONSOLIDATION

5.42 The second part of the Commission's policy relates to the consolidation of single-purpose teacher education institutions into larger units. Three main considerations have led the Commission to adopt this policy. The first of these relates to the adjustments which will be required over the 1982-84 triennium. The Commission believes that larger institutions, such as the proposed multi-campus institutions in Sydney and in Adelaide, will be better able to handle the problems associated with change than single-purpose institutions acting on their own. The larger institution should be able to leave positions vacant without the dislocation that this would cause in a smaller institution; it can redistribute workloads among the larger number of staff which are available to it in any one field; it has greater capacity to redeploy staff within the institution, especially if it is a multi-purpose institution; and it should also have a greater capacity to retrain redundant staff. Moreover, the greater absolute turnover of academic staff of the larger institution and its broader range of work provide opportunities for starting new academic activities. The Commission notes that considerations of this kind were important in TEASA's proposal for the development of the multi-campus CAE in Adelaide.

5.43 The second consideration relates to the range and quality of educational choices which can be offered to students. Larger institutions, especially those which are diversified, are able to provide a wider range of options for students in their choice of subjects and awards; ultimately, this widens their choice of occupations. Larger institutions are also able to offer better services to students and a wider range of teaching and promotion opportunities to staff and should therefore attract higher quality staff.

5.44 By providing a wider range of options for teacher education students, it will also be possible for institutions to meet fluctuations in demand for the various types of teachers, particularly in secondary education. While the Commission, in consultation with the States, has undertaken a broad assessment of the demand for primary teachers and secondary teachers, it has not undertaken a study of the demand for, say, secondary mathematics teachers or physical education teachers. The creation of larger and more broadly based institutions, even if some are entirely devoted to teacher education, should make it possible for States to plan more readily their intakes into specialist streams and for institutions to adjust to these demands within their total teaching resources.

5.45 The third consideration relates to cost. While significant economies are unlikely in the short to medium term, the Commission believes that there are economies of scale to be gained from the establishment of larger institutions. Institutions are funded on the basis that there are minimum overheads; these tend to inflate the operating costs of small institutions.

5.46 In taking this position the Commission has not adopted as desirable any particular minimum size for higher education institutions. The Williams Committee commented that teachers colleges can be both economical and small.(3) However, the Commission does not hold as an article of faith that 'big is better', and the issue of cost has been less important to it in formulating its policy than the considerations relating to flexibility and quality. It nevertheless believes that a staff of some size is an important element in providing depth and diversity in higher education.

5.47 In advocating consolidation rather than the abolition of some institutions, the Commission has recognised the inherent difficulties involved in such proposals. While it does not preclude abolition as the most appropriate solution in some cases, the Commission considers that consolidation is likely to be the more feasible and successful policy.
5.48 Consolidation may take three forms:
merger of one or more single-purpose CAEs with an existing diversified CAE (as is occurring between the former SCV Toorak and Prahran CAE):
merger of a number of single-purpose or largely single-purpose CAEs to form a new multi-campus CAE (as proposed in Sydney and Adelaide);
merger of a CAE with a neighbouring university (as has been proposed between the University of Wollongong and the Wollongong Institute of Education).

In each case, it is critical to the achievement of the objectives outlined by the Commission-greater flexibility and improvement of quality-that the institutions amalgamate under a single governing body. This body should be the employing authority for the institution. It should have the ultimate responsibility for the disposition of academic resources; in particular, it will need to have the capacity to allocate resources according to need.

5.49 The Commission supports the proposals to establish such governing bodies for the proposed multi-campus institutions in Sydney and Adelaide. However, it does not, in general, wish to prescribe particular solutions for local problems. State authorities are in the best position to take into account all the factors-educational and non-educational-which need to be considered in these matters. On the other hand, the Commission has to base its recommendations for funding on what it considers to be a rational use of resources. It therefore urges the States to give further consideration to the possibilities of consolidation as advocated by the Commission.

5.50 University/CAE mergers. The Williams Committee took the view that it had not been clearly established that there would be net advantages from amalgamation of the neighbouring universities and CAEs at Townsville, Armidale and Newcastle. The considerations which led to this conclusion were that ''the economic size of the colleges of advanced education involved is not large, and the problems created by different philosophies and different criteria and procedures for the appointment of staff are considerable''. The Committee recommended greater collaboration between neighbouring universities and CAEs, and in particular arrangements for joint appointments or part-time secondments of staff in the field of teacher education.(4)

5.51 The Commission supports the view of the Williams Committee regarding increased collaboration. It is concerned to ensure that the combined resources of neighbouring institutions are used to the maximum benefit of the region concerned, and it believes that sectoral boundaries should not inhibit this. The Commission therefore wishes to encourage the State authorities and institutions concerned in Armidale, Newcastle and Townsville to consider again possible forms of co-operation and association which go beyond informal arrangements. The trends in enrolments in education in the three cities would add weight to such moves.

5.52 In the Commission's view, the solution which would produce the best quality of education and widest range of choices for students is integration of the two institutions in each city under a single governing body. In this respect the Commission supports the steps which have been proposed in Wollongong towards such integration, and it suggests that the State authorities and institutions concerned in the other three cities should examine the possible application of the Wollongong approach to their situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this area not only have we acted upon the Tertiary Education Commission report but also in South Australia and Tasmania we have seen evidence of its being successful and leading to greater educational excellence, which is a pattern which the proposals that have now been brought forward seek to achieve. I do not believe that there is any educational damage, as the Opposition alleges. I reject the alarmist way in which the decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions have been described.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the damage done to the Australian education system as a result of the decisions of the so-called razor gang. Try as one might, one has to take account of the views of some people who think that damage has been done and analyse whether those views are accurate. I begin by saying that the Liberal Minister of Education in Victoria, Mr Hunt, speaking about the proposals for colleges announced by the razor gang, was reported in today's Australian as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of Victoria's consensus plan, 'a unilateral, blunt, insensitive and ill-considered announcement-which disclosed no appreciation whatever of the problems involved for staff, for students and for institutions-was released in Canberra last week,' he said.

'It was an unnecessary announcement, for the problems which it addressed had been virtually resolved and the steps necessary to achieve the results desired by the Commonwealth were already in course of discussion with the colleges concerned in a consultative way.'
Later in the article the Minister is reported as saying:
We have been unable to ascertain any rational basis for it, . . .

In the Canberra Times of 12 May a report appears under the heading-I apologise for speaking in these terms-'Torrid reception for Carrick'. That article reports the Minister for National Development and Energy Senator Carrick, as saying:
. . . most second or higher degree students already receive scholarships.
The response by the Vice-Chancellor of Griffith University was reported as follows:

The Vice-Chancellor of Griffith University, Professor F. Willett, told the conference that in view of the energy options and technological development outlined by Senator Carrick, he questioned whether this was the right time to discourage second or higher degrees by people seeking to further their education.
In that connection I draw the Senate's attention to the report of the Tertiary Education Commission for 1982-84, volume 1. Paragraph 3.21 states:

The trend away from full-time study for research degrees evident in recent years is likely to be a reflection of the decline in the numbers of scholarships available for research students both from the traditional source-Commonwealth Postgraduate Awards-and from the universities themselves.

One can go on with this exercise of digging up quotations from particular sources that suit particular people. I was very surprised to find that one of Senator Teague's sources was the platform of the Liberal Party of Australia at various election campaigns in years gone by. I think the important thing to consider is that the Liberal Party made promises about education as it made promises about health and all sorts of other matters, which have been abandoned. When considering education it is important to determine whether decisions about education policy are, in fact, a function of a committee like the so-called razor gang or whether they are a function of the education Ministers, the Department of Education and all those educational advisory bodies which the Commonwealth Goverment has to deal with.

Where I differ particularly with some of the things said by Senator Teague is that I had never heard it expressed as a promise and a policy of the Liberal Party, before Phil Lynch's razor gang got to work, that access to tertiary education in Australia should be restricted further as a matter of educational policy. The first time it was expressed was 10 days ago when this group of drop-outs from small business who were determining the fate of the Australian economy for the next few years got together and made decisions on educational matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did not express it; the Opposition expressed it.

—No, they did express it. It is quite clear that eligibility for assistance under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme is to be even further restricted. The sop for that is a loans scheme the details of which, as Senator Teague says, are not yet at all clear; they are to be worked out. The device is to introduce a loans scheme. Senator Teague almost said: 'Well, it will not matter so much about the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme because students will be able to get the money through the loans scheme'. That is a decision about access to education. A decision about access to education ought to be based on the Government's view of education policy and not on the deliberations of a committee such as the Lynch committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Fraser Government came to power we have been subjected to more volumes of reports about education than has perhaps any other parliament in the history of this country. The report of the Williams Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment made recommendations about, for example, Murdoch University. Sir Charles Court knocked those recommendations of the Williams committee about Murdoch University on the head very smartly. That suggestion of the Williams committee has now been suddenly dredged up again and recycled by the razor gang, as all decisions on education have been recycled in the last few years.

We can look at the Williams committee, the Auchmuty report and the undertaking of the Fraser Government to create centres of excellence in universities. What has happened to all those things? For years we sat in the Senate and had Senator Carrick tell us that he could not answer questions on education because the Williams committee was going to deal with all those matters. What has really happened as a result of the recommendations of the Williams committee? Practically nothing. What has happened-except in relation to single purpose colleges-as a result of some of the recommendations of the Auchmuty committee? Practically nothing. These are the reports by which the Government recognises that the way to determine education policy is by the expert advice of bodies of this kind. That has just not been done.

That is why the Minister in Victoria has described-to use the words of our matter of public importance-the decision of the razor gang as being 'ill-considered'. He used words much stronger in their purport than that. On all these matters the purport of the razor gang is that the capacity to take educational advice about educational matters, which we have ignored over a long period, is no longer to be relevant. What is to be relevant is the sort of macho politics of making stunt-like, tough-sounding decisions about the Commonwealth Public Service and about institutions which some members of the community do not particularly like.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the TEC report on the amalgamation of colleges?

—What about the TEC report? I have said nothing about that which disagrees with the honourable senator on that point. But I have pointed to the fact that the Minister in Victoria, a member of the Australian Education Council-another body which is kept going at considerable expense to seek agreement about relationships between the States and the Commonwealth on education matters-has apparently been totally ignored in relation to the decisions which have been made about colleges. Once again, the question is which body performs the educational advisory function. The question of student fees is one which concerns me in relation to education policy. People concerned about education policy are concerned about the next 20 or 30 years and not just about what will happen tomorrow, which is what the razor gang was concerned about.

SPEECH.PARA: Many examples are given in this document of the Government's total unconcern about what will happen 20 or 30 years ahead in areas such as education. The Government is concerned about the next election and about putting on a bit of an act for the electorate at this stage to try to retrieve certain damaged fortunes. The Government's decisions about research are a complete reversal of those made by this Government in 1976 and 1977. As Professor Willett points out, there is to be a winding back of this Government's involvement in educational research and research funding generally. Such a winding back is bad for the future of this country. A decision about access to tertiary education is a decision about the future of this country and about what will happen to young people who go into education now and in the future.

A third example which is of importance is the Curriculum Development Centre. I know that it is not said that the Curriculum Development Centre will necessarily be abolished. I think that will be the result of the razor gang's deliberations. I pointed out last week that only a month ago the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) opened the new building for the Curriculum Development Centre in Canberra. In the course of opening that building he went to great lengths to explain what a great body the Centre was. A month later its abolition was announced. Is that good government in terms of educational policy making? I would have thought not. The report of the Tertiary Education Commission and particularly the report of the Myers Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia express great concern about curricula in Australian schools and the capacity of curricula to adapt to technological change. That concern has been expressed by a national education planning body about an issue of national importance. The razor gang apparently did not take such matters into consideration. Apparently they are not relevant to education planning and the important thing is the short term consideration.

We on this side of the Senate do not say for a moment that there should not be greater accountability for money spent in some areas of education, as indeed there is in other areas of government activity. We are saying that the Government has gone about this question in totally the wrong way and has produced a rather bizarre set of decisions which really do not stand up. I shall give the Senate some examples. There is to be a restriction on eligibility under the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme to those seeking qualifications for employment. That is an extraordinary and important view about education. Adults can have the benefit of that scheme only if they are seeking a job.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not imply that. Education is for many things.
—Yes, it does. The statement says precisely that.
—But that does not mean that education is only for employment.

—I know that, but those are the implications of the statement. A decision about education has been made by people who do not know anything about education. That is the problem. It is a question of function. I have already referred to the Curriculum Development Centre. It is to be abolished unless the States contribute certain amounts to it. In the context of the Myer report into technology, which this Government commissioned, and in the context of the Tertiary Education Commission report, the decision to abolish the Centre was a silly and short-sighted one. That is what we object to. The same thing can be said about the decision to wind back research activities. That is a silly, short-sighted decision. Insofar as student loans and student fees are concerned, we believe the decision to introduce fees for second degrees to be, again, a short-sighted one. This Government has successfully created an environment in which there is much apprehension about the reintroduction of fees generally. The Government has created that environment on its own head. It has done that because of the terminology of the razor gang report on that issue. I do not know why the Government says that it will not now fund the university in the Northern Territory. It never said that it would do so. Why does that statement appear in the razor gang report?

SPEECH.PARA: One can work through the proposed cuts to various programs which in terms of money will amount to nothing but a piece of political stunting. On the other hand, the TEC report is concerned with educational priorities. We find a very severe comment at pages 30 and 31 of that report about the proposed Australian Defence Force Academy, which is to cost $80m. Nothing is said by the razor gang about that institution, although the Public Works Committee of this Parliament unanimously condemned the proposal as wasteful. All the problems in relation to student fees and post-graduates could be solved if the educational priorities were right and the $80m to be spent on that institution were released in favour of the sorts of proposals that I have indicated the Opposition regards as more important.

One could go on at length about this statement but the important quetion is one of priorities. I refer to educational priorities in terms of expenditure, not in terms of the sort of material which appears in the ministerial statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions, which is a very messy document in the light of the educational goals of this Government, which have been expressed over many years and which change from one report to another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button, as usual, has made an interesting contribution to the debate. I lament, however, that he has not done justice to his own case in all instances. I take one of his latter points first. That was a reference in support of his case to the Tertiary Education Commission report. He referred to the matter of the Australian Defence Force Academy and the comments on that subject contained in the Tertiary Education Commission report. I indicate to the Senate that the case which has been presented to the Senate by Senator Button was not advanced at all by his reference to that report. Under the heading 'Matters Outstanding' the Tertiary Education Commission refers to a number of items including the Australian Defence Force Academy. It outlines the progress of plans for that academy. It concludes as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The question of arrangements for the Commission to give advice on the academic activities and facilities of the Academy, first raised between the Ministers in 1977, is still under consideration.

That is not an expression of concern; it is a reporting to the public that the matter is still outstanding between the Tertiary Education Commission and others. So that reference did not support Senator Button's case as he might have liked it to do. We are debating a matter raised by the Opposition, which it claims to be a matter of public importance, namely, what it alleges to be 'damage to the Australian education system' resulting from what the Labor Party claims to be 'ad hoc and ill-considered decisions'.

Earlier speakers for the Government this afternoon-Senator Puplick and Senator Teague-have put a case for the decisions that the Government has made. Further, they pointed out that what the Senate was engaged in-this was possibly the case until Senator Button spoke-was an ad hoc debate ranging over a number of points relating to education. I think it was Senator Puplick who pointed out that all that was being said to the Senate today was that the Labor Party did not like certain items relating to the Government's education policy. The Labor Party is at liberty to say that it does not like them. It is at liberty to say that it would do something different, and to make its case to the Australian public. But it has not supported its own case that damage has been done and that the decisions were ad hoc and ill-considered. In fact, a number of the Government's decisions in the area of Australian education policy were not touched on and could not be argued against in the Senate this afternoon. So we have not had a case put to us in those terms.

We heard some interesting comments from Senator Button, who struggled rather vainly at the end of his speech to try to put up a case supporting the matter which the Opposition claims is one of public importance. He tried to put forward a coherent and logical case. He did his own case more justice by approaching it in those terms. He did not do his case any justice by voicing criticism such as: Decisions are being made about education by people who do not know anything about it. He made that statement in relation to certain assertions about the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme. A dispute was going on at the time between him and Senator Teague as to the significance of comments and conclusions that could be drawn about the Government's decision on a recommendation flowing from the Cabinet Review of Commonwealth Functions.

I do not believe Senator Teague said that it was his view or the Government's view that education was restricted only to the matter of qualifications for employment. The Government's decision is to the effect that this sort of assistance will be restricted to students needing qualifications for employment. I hope that we all know that education is related to employment. Certainly the case put to members of parliament by those who argue the case for education is that the community and the nation gains direct monetary and economic benefit from a more highly educated work force. That is one aspect of education, but it is not the only one. The Government does not claim it is by way of its policy decisions.

There are other aspects. A review such as this has to determine priorities. It is very easy for Opposition senators to say that all manner of assistance should be available to people in order to seek education for self-improvement and that it should be funded out of the public purse, but governments that have budgetary and total national economic considerations apply priorities to issues such as that just as they do to many other issues. Obviously the community would expect that first priority, given not unlimited budgetary capacity, in the matter of this type of education ought to go to those who are using that education in order to improve their qualifications for employment. Enough has been said in this chamber and around the nation in recent times about the urgent need for Australia to address itself to changing demands for skills in the work force. We must meet that urgent demand by meeting the first area of priority, and that is to enable those who want to upgrade their work skills through the education system to have reasonable access. That is not to make a case against adults being educated in order to improve themselves to get more out of life or whatever, but a case must be made for the public purse meeting that expenditure.

There has been much talk today on the subject of fees and loans. Much has been said about the recipients and whether they will be better off or worse off because of these decisions. No attention at all has been paid to the people who provide the funds that we are asked to give under the circumstances. I hope, in the course of my speech, to address a small amount of attention to that aspect. It is relevant to a general Labor Party case on education. Senator Tate is wrong when he says that the whole community is dismayed by the Government's educational decisions as a result of this review. The whole community would have grounds to be dismayed if it could not believe that after the massive amounts of funds that have gone into education within the last decade in Australia there was not some lessening of urgent need. The population of Australia is stabilising. The student population, in many areas, is stabilising. In a couple of areas, such as my own State and Western Australia, of course, the student population is continuing to increase, but that is because of local factors related to the attractiveness of conditions of life. However, the general Australian position is that the student population is stabilising. Governments are not trying to cope in the same urgent way that they were with the educational consequences and demands on facilities as a result of any sort of baby boom.

The Australian community could be dismayed if it were led to believe that the enormous amounts of money that have been spent on infrastructure and training in education within the last decade had not resulted in a lessening of the pressure for large sums to be spent. I think all of us-I include educational institutions-need to realise that the public expects the injection of funds not to continue at the same rate. Our nation has evolving and fluctuating needs. New needs come to the fore and areas of need in the past are now more demanding that they were. Education has to be seen in those terms and in terms of a national priority. We have never at any stage, as the Labor Party would like to suggest, stated that education is anything other than a high national priority, but priorities within education and the priority of education in terms of urgency have changed. The area of tertiary education is a good case. I would be interested to take up some of the detail of the points Senator Button raised in passing; time does not enable me to take up all of them. However, he made some reference to tertiary areas. The Opposition would have been very unwise at any stage to suggest that the decisions relating to colleges of advanced education were ad hoc or ill-considered. Senator Puplick and Senator Teague covered the aspect at some length; I shall not cover all of it. I would like to point out the alternative. If the States wish to pursue some existing institutions which have a limited rationale or wish in the future to pursue plans for new institutions which are not part of the national education policy that Senator Button referred to they may, but they will foot the bill. They will do so from their own resources and they will justify to their own voters and constituents their own priorities for these institutions as against more urgent local priorities. It is in that context that the Government has taken its decisions. Nobody can argue against following the Tertiary Education Commission's recommendation. The Victorian Minister for Education is arguing against it. I understand that the Queensland Government might venture a thought or two on the subject also. But the choices which are open are clear and the basis for the decision was certainly not ill-considered or irrational.

Time for the debate is running out and I want to say just a couple of words on the subject of fees and loans. The point that needs to be made is that we are not talking about all fees. Throughout this debate Opposition speakers, whenever they have referred to the subject of university fees, have mentioned only student fees. They have not distinguished between the non-imposition of fees for first degrees or for recognised combinations of bachelors degrees and further bachelors degrees which are not first degrees or higher degrees. I say something very briefly about this matter. Senator Button said that access to further education will be restricted after the report because of recommendations relating to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. Nobody would argue that some of the recommendations relating to eligibility for TEAS are restrictive, but not all are. I point out that one consideration in relation to TEAS makes the recommendations less restrictive, and that is the Government's decision that periods of registration for employment with or without receipt of unemployment benefit will be taken into account in determining the two-year qualifying period for independent status. That is a liberalising of the conditions for TEAS which will still be available to students in need. It will not be available to students who wish to make decisions of a personal or luxury nature. The loans will, of course, be additionally available, and this seems to me to be fair.

One should realise that those in the lower income earning strata of our society who are paying tax contribute to fees in the same way as do higher income earners. Students themselves need to understand that there are people who will never in their lives be in as privileged a position as they are and that these people have made a contribution towards the cost of their education. These people will continue to make that contribution towards the cost of the first degree. I do not think that those who are in a position to earn or who are in a position to take alternative sources of money such as loans which can be repaid because of higher earning capacity, ought to demand as a right that those who will never earn as much as the earning potential that they are acquiring for themselves ought to pay and that they ought to receive support from those people as of right. It needs to be remembered that not all people who feel the pinch are students. There are people working very hard who feel the strain of financial disability and who are themselves funding students in our tertiary institutions, and recognition ought to be given to that.

Debates on education in the Senate are almost invariably interesting, and in the range of issues covered this afternoon this also has been an interesting and I think a worthwhile debate, if only in giving the opportunity to canvass at length the basic issues related to decisions of the last few days. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
