SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before the Senate, the Census and Statistics Amendment Bill 1981, seeks to amend the Census and Statistics Act 1905 by incorporating a few, and I stress a few, of the recommendations arising from the report of the Law Reform Commission. Some of the provisions relating to secrecy or confidentiality are to be tightened up. In particular, the secrecy provisions binding officers of the department are to be extended to retired officers, the penalties are to be increased, and it is to be possible for a householder filling in the census form to by-pass the official collector and post in the information direct and anonymously. They are the only three changes which this Bill makes. More significant than the changes which are to be made and the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission which are to be adopted are those recommendations of the Law Reform Commission which are not to be adopted and for the ignoring of which, as is the custom with this Government, no explanation at all has been given. Indeed, the second reading speech of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) occupied just under one-half page of Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Very few of the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission are to be adopted. Most of the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission are ignored and the Government, in its customary contemptuous style-contemptuous, that is, of the Parliament and the public-gives no explanation at all for not adopting the other recommendations. It applies the same principle, or perhaps one should say lack of it, to the deluge of legislation which it brings before this Parliament to grant exemptions from various sections of the taxation legislation for various client groups of the Government and those who successfully lobby it. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) claims that he is zealously guarding public funds and that he is merely a trustee of taxpayers' funds. It seems to have escaped his attention that in offering tax concessions to his various cronies he is not in fact offering concessions from himself or from the Government; the tax concessions which he offers to his cronies and clients are paid for by all the other taxpayers in Australia. Some examples of this of course are the ridiculous provisions-the Malcolm Fraser pre-election special-for storage of fuel, originally on farms and now extended, and of course the notorious 14 April 1980 so-called drought relief provisions.

One of the more important of the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission not adopted by the Government, for which no explanation has been given, is the recommendation that greater provision be made for the questions which are actually placed on the census form being issued in the form of regulations and therefore subject to debate in Parliament. Most important probably is the recommendation that census information, the forms in non-identifiable form, be retained in the Archives for 75 years with a general prohibition on examination, but one which can under very special circumstances be breached. The very special circumstances which were cited by the Law Reform Commission were if the information is required for the purposes of medical research.

The Law Reform Commission quoted extensively from a report of the United States House of Representatives which drew attention to the unique information which census forms could provide in helping to determine causes of diseases which have been shown to appear in what are called 'hot spots'-that is, particular areas of the country where the incidence of a particular disease is very much higher than the national average and where the reason for its being very much higher has not been identified. Unless there is information about people, not with names attached, about movements of people throughout the country over a very long period, such cause and effect cannot be accurately correlated because of the long incubation periods for many diseases of this type and the mobility of the population. After the passage of this Bill, Australia will continue to destroy original records almost as soon as some of the information has been taken and placed on computer tape.

I refer to some other general deficiencies about census procedure in Australia which were noted by Ralph Willis in his customary lucid style in the House of Representatives. Some 27 categories of statistical material collected will be abolished as a result of the decisions of the so-called razor gang. There is no valid reason for continuing to collect that sort of statistical information. For example, the quantity of crayfish in cold storage in Western Australia at a particular time does not appear to have any particular value. I think Ralph Willis cited the number of eggs set and chickens hatched. We have no serious quarrel with the Government's abolishing the collection of the overwhelming majority of that information. There are very serious deficiencies in the type of information currently collected for which the Government ought to recognise and then make provision. Instead it is moving in the opposite direction.

Less information is being collected and collated about the degree of foreign ownership in various Australian industries. I have a question on notice about this matter, but as yet it has not been answered. To the best of my knowledge there is not and has never been any comprehensive information available about the degree of foreign ownership of land in Australia. From time to time various surveys have been conducted in limited parts of the country, but on a national basis there has never been an attempt to record the degree to which land is in foreign hands or the degree to which it is being accumulated by foreigners. This is a matter about which a great deal of concern is expressed throughout the country. No plans are in existence to remedy that information gap.

The information provided in the 1976 census was only half processed and half placed on record. The spurious reason given for that was that it was an economy measure. In the aftermath of the so-called razor gang's recommendations it is pertinent to remind the Senate that we went through a similar exercise in 1976 when the Government said that it was indulging in this ruthless exercise of cutting fat off government departments and eliminating unnecessary and wasteful expenditure. In 1976 we had the same sort of public relations campaign about government efficiency and wise husbandry of taxpayers' money that we have seen in the last fortnight. It had the same puny and often foolish results. One of the foolish consequences of that last specious exercise in cost cutting was the decision not to process much of the information from the 1976 census. Having incurred the major expense of collecting the information, the Government declined to incur the relatively minor expense of placing on record and processing the information. It was a particularly irresponsible decision.

I understand that the data on civilian employees is still collected, but by decree of government it is not published. Of course the reasons for that are political. The Government prefers a survey which is less reliable but more likely to present figures which are favourable to it in its political campaign. Likewise the household expenditure surveys which were last conducted in 1975, six years ago, provide an enormous amount of valuable information-valuable to those who are concerned particularly about income distribution and whether the effects of particular policies on income distribution have a regressive or progressive impact. The 1975-76 surveys were extremely good, but like all surveys of that nature they have become dated and will be less reliable as time goes on. As far as I am aware, the Government has no intention to update that valuable information. On behalf of the Opposition, I move as an amendment to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time:

At end of motion, add, ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill is deficient in that it fails to give effect to the recommendation of the Australian Law Reform Commission's report ''Privacy and the Census'' that identified census information should be held in archives with access forbidden for 75 years, except for strictly limited access for purposes of medical research'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Census and Statistics Amendment Bill 1981 is an important Bill. The Australian Democrats support some aspects of it, but other aspects worry us very much. The aspects that worry us are the heavy increases provided in the Schedule to the Bill regarding the penalties against persons who do not fill in census forms as directed and even heavier penalties against persons who provide information which is not true. I wonder how many Australians realise that if they provide false information in their 1981 census forms they will, as a result of this Bill, be liable for a fine of $1,000, six months in gaol or both. This will apply if the Bill is passed in its present form. The Australian Democrats do not believe it should go through in its present form. We believe it is absolutely fantastic that this Government should propose an amendment to an Act which provides a new provision, which was not in the old Act, that we will put a person in gaol because he did not fill in his census form correctly. I foreshadow an amendment to this Bill, in the Committee stage, to remove that penal sanction from the Schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: I implore all honourable senators, who have any conscience, to support us because this matter is quite disgraceful in a society in which we say there should be fewer penal sanctions, not more. That amendment is proposed to section 26 of the Census and Statistics Act. The Democrats point out the draconian increase in that penalty. The fine under the present Act is $100, with no penal sanctions-no gaol term. Of course I am aware that it has been necessary to increase these fines substantially because of erosion caused by inflation. I think the penal sanctions have got to the stage where they are out of reason. The amendments to sections 17 and 18 of the Act will provide a penalty of $500 for not filling in, strictly in accordance with the instructions, a census form. I contrast these sanctions with those applied to other crimes in the community, such as dangerous driving, which is a serious offence against a person and property. Where are we going with this legislation?

The Australian Democrats also find it disquieting that the penalties provided under section 24, for a census official who betrays his trust, a serious matter, and reveals information from the census forms are no higher than the same $1,000 fine, six months in gaol or both. We believe that penalty ought to be higher than that which applies to a person who does not fill in a form correctly. I would have thought the offence to society was greater in the second case. Here we have a Bill which provides the same penalty for both offences. I ask the responsible Minister to tell me at some stage the reason for that anomalous state of affairs applying in an area which is so controversial and which has such possibilities for injustice as the census. It touches every man, woman and child in this country. Section 12 of the Act demands that the name, sex, age, condition as to and duration of marriage, religion, birthplace, profession and occupation of all persons be given. I repeat that under the legislation names must be given. On the face of the new Bill now before us a refusal to give a name could attract a fine of $500. The giving of a facetious or false name such as Donald Duck or Karl Marx, as I understand has happened in the past, would, under the terms of this legislation, if it is passed, make a person liable to a fine of $1,000 and six months gaol. It is that possibility of gaol that the Democrats do not like. We do not believe it should be an option in this Bill. It was not in the old Act. It was not previously in the legislation. We are wondering why it has been put in this legislation. As I said earlier, in the view of the Democrats, penal sanctions should be used less in our society, not more. When it comes to introducing them in matters relating to the filling in of the census form we begin to wonder just what is going on.

The Australian Democrats applaud the new provisions in this Bill, which are intended to ensure that when the 1981 census is taken all collectors and interviewers handling the census process, even though they work on a casual basis, will be bound by the law forbidding disclosure of details of census information and be subject to penalty. I repeat that we are worried about the fact that an officer who betrays his trust in this regard, perhaps enormously and massively, would appear to attract only the same penalty as a person who flippantly or facetiously supplies wrong information. We also support other aspects of the legislation such as the use of a special sealed envelope by persons who wish to maintain the privacy of their census schedule by by-passing the census collector.

This Bill is very important for a number of background reasons. The first is that the fictional world of 1984, in which all details of a person's private life will become available to a big brother type government, is tending all the time to come relentlessly closer in terms of fact as well as actual calendar date. Citizens are right to fear the proliferation in the world of secret lists, which modern computer technology makes it so easy to organise and use, and citizens are right also to resist the incursions of that world into their private life. It is not only a tendency of government but also, as we are reminded disquietingly from time to time, a part of the commercial world and I think that tendency is to be deplored.

It is fair to ask the question: Is information compulsorily provided for the census by individuals necessary for the overall welfare of the state? I think we must assume it is and that the Government would be flying blind in many of its activities without statistics about the society. I would not like anybody listening to me in this broadcast to believe that the Democrats are saying that people should not take this responsibility seriously where they can. By filling in the census form they are contributing manifestly to the needs of society and to its greater objectives. However, there should be a process of the greatest restraint, especially now that penalties for non-compliance are becoming so high, to see that material is not included which persons would perhaps not wish to make available and which cannot be absolutely justified in the national interest. I use the word 'absolutely' advisedly.

There is great irony in the matter of the census legislation being brought before the chamber at this time when we have already embarked upon consideration in the Committee stage of the so-called Freedom of Information Bill which, as I have said at another time in this place, might better be described in its present form as the Official Secrets Preservation Bill. In other words, here we are this evening discussing the imposition of stiff penalties on citizens who do not give out information about themselves to government and at the same time the moguls in the high levels of the Australian bureaucracy-in many ways the secret government of Australia-are doing all they can, with the full support and connivance of the Government, to prevent any members of the public from getting lawful access to information about the Government. The irony of this contrast can be extended to the situation in which later today we will be speaking to the listening public on generalised first reading material at a time when we could be discussing the Freedom of Information Bill in the Committee stage. But that Bill may or may not come on tomorrow after a long delay and at a time when the public cannot hear our deliberations on that vital and significant Bill on the nature of Australian secret government.

There is a further matter of interest in this legislation. The Democrats are pleased that in this Bill the Government has implemented some of the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission. But we say: 'You have made a start. Why not do some more?' We support the Labor Party amendment which has been moved by Senator Walsh insofar as it relates to matters that have not been taken into account in this legislation, but there are other areas to be considered. Other significant reports that Mr Justice Michael Kirby and his team on the Commission have brought forward in recent years have been unpardonably delayed by this Government and we would like to see them brought forward. I mention just a few of them. The Criminal Investigation Bill was introduced by Attorney-General Ellicott on 24 March 1977-four years ago-and lapsed on 8 November 1977. Since then it has been in the melting pot in the Attorney-General's Department and an interdepartmental committee. The supplementary report on complaints against police dated 9 June is another example. We have seen the adoption of most but not all of the recommendations of the Commission in the Complaints Against Police Bill. That Bill was introduced on 26 February 1981-only two and a half years later. The defamation report of the Commission dated 9 June 1978 has seen no action. That admittedly has been the subject of controversy but both the Attorney-General and the Minister for Administrative Services announced proposed legislation. The matter apparently is sitting with the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, a committee whose track record does not at the moment inspire confidence. It has been with that Committee for nearly three years. There are other examples that I could mention. I do not want to delay the Senate unduly on matters which are not strictly relevant to this Bill but as the Law Reform Commission is in play in this matter I think some of these things are worth mentioning.

The Democrats would like careful consideration of the amendment that we propose to move in the Committee stage. I am sorry that I was unable to bring it to the attention of honourable senators earlier. We have been studying this Bill only today and the particular which is the subject of our amendment caught our attention. As a result, we foreshadow an amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise just to make a few comments on the remarks of Senator Mason. As he has focused most of his argument on the penalties that are set out in the Bill, I think it should be noted, firstly, that the penalties are of course maximum penalties and therefore in the general case they are not likely to be applied with their full rigour. The second point essentially is that the history of this kind of legislation is that very few persons have been prosecuted under its provisions. Consequently, in the main there has been a very good adherence to the law. We expect that position to be maintained under the new arrangements. I think Senator Mason ageed that it is reasonable that the penalties ought to be raised to a level in line with inflation and according to current community standards in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the most important point that Senator Mason sought to make and the one upon which he dwelled is the one which is the subject of the proposed amendment and that is in relation to section 26 of the Act which is referred to in the Schedule. He seeks to delete the words 'or imprisonment for six months, or both'. I draw the attention of the honourable senator to the fact that section 26 of the original Act refers to persons knowingly doing something in relation to any form or document, et cetera. The word 'knowingly' is the essential element of the section. There must be an intention on the part of the person in fact to mislead or make some incorrect entry and therefore defeat the purpose of the census. I think reasonable people would accept that a very tough penalty ought to be applied in that situation. Consequently, the Government adheres to the view that the penalty set out in the Bill should be maintained. On that ground, we reject Senator Mason's foreshadowed amendment.

I intend to refer to only one of the points raised by Senator Walsh. That is the reference to the Australian Law Reform Commission's recommendations with regard to the census schedules being kept for most purposes for 75 years. The Government has noted that the recommendation expressed by the Commission is at this stage only a provisional one and that its Chairman considers that it would be a matter on which the Commission should not put forward any recommendation. The Government has carefully weighed up the various arguments on this matter and has decided against accepting it.

The purpose of the census is to collect statistical information. The legal obligation on people to answer census questions is accompanied by strict measures to ensure the confidentiality of the information provided. It would be inconsistent with that purpose and with that guarantee of confidentiality to retain information on identified persons or households for the research purposes referred to in the Commission's report. There are, of course, other difficulties such as maintaining archives which include the huge number of records necessary in this particular situation and ensuring the confidentiality of documents kept in that kind of area for a period of 75 years. Not only would this be a tremendously costly exercise but also in practical terms it would be very difficult to achieve. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not deal with the matter again in detail; I simply wish to move the amendment circulated in my name. I reiterate that the purpose of this amendment is to remove the penal sanction of imprisonment for six months which could be applied to persons in Australia who supplied false information knowingly when filling out their census forms. The Australian Democrats' view is that the sanction of a $1,000 fine, which is provided for in the Schedule, is enough. It increases the previous fine of $100. We believe that penal sanction is improper and out of line with the state of penal law and other aspects of law in Australia, especially criminal law. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, Schedule, leave out 'or imprisonment for six months, or both' (second occurring).

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Government opposes the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -I have only just seen the amendment. (Quorum formed). Unfortunately the Census and Statistics Amendment Bill 1981 was called on a little earlier than either the Opposition or Senator Mason anticipated. Perhaps Senator Mason thought that the procedures which have been followed during the last week or so-the Notice Paper has been changed about six times a day-would again be followed today. For once, today we have stuck to the Notice Paper. I have only just seen the amendment that has been moved by Senator Mason. Its effect is to remove the risk of imprisonment for a householder who records false information on a census form.

SPEECH.PARA: After discussion with the few of my colleagues whom I was able to consult in the limited time available we unanimously agreed that this penalty seems to be somewhat harsh for a householder, a private citizen. Another clause provides for some risk of imprisonment in the case of an officer in a position of trust in the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It seems to the Opposition that in that instance the risk of imprisonment is not an inappropriate penalty but in the case of a private citizen it is inappropriate. The Opposition supports Senator Mason's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the position needs to be clarified a little more. The question is: What is a suitable penalty for an offence of this gravity? Much of the legislation we support imposes penalties of $1,000 or imprisonment for six months, or both. We must consider whether this is a very harsh penalty to be imposed on a person who has committed an offence by knowingly giving incorrect information on a census form-that suggests that it is done deliberately-to mislead the Australian Statistician. Unless a multitude of people engage in this practice the effect of such action would not be very serious. The figures relating to how many houses are in Australia, the earnings of the population or some other question might be out by a fractional point.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I think every effort should be made to ensure that the information given on census forms is honest and truthful, I think the penalty provided for in the legislation is a little hard on anyone who even knowingly makes a false statement on a census form or to the collector of that form. A fine of $1,000 can be imposed. Under the amendment that fine remains. Does the Government think it is then appropriate to imprison people for six months and to fine them $1,000 because they mistakenly or knowlingly made a false statement to the collector or on the census form? By all standards, I think that is a harsh penalty. Much discussion is going on at present about the effect of penalties. I doubt whether penalties of any sort are a useful deterrent. They simply make people more careful that they do not get found out. If a person intends to commit a crime he does not worry about the penalty. If the crime provides for a harsh penalty he may take extra precautions so that he is not found out. I do not think penalties imposed prevent other people from committing similar offences if they so desire.

A penalty is imposed when a person does something that the Act says is wrong. If a person has committed a wrong action I do not know that punitive action solves the matter. We know that penalties must be imposed to stop a person from deliberately doing such things and I think the imposition of a fine of $1,000 would be a good lesson. Of course, we also have to face the fact that very often the courts do not impose the maximum fine. We may only be playing with words. To give a court or a judge power to fine someone $1,000 and to imprison him for six months because he puts in a false census return seems to me to be a harsh step for a sympathetic, democratic government to take.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has examined this proposal involving sections 24 and 26. I am concerned about the proposed amendment to section 26 because I think it is here that the Committee ought to have some regard to protecting the rights of the citizen. Honourable senators will recall the way in which the census is conducted. It is conducted largely with casual labour. People distribute the census paper and then collect it and the census is then based on the information made available by the persons in each household. Are we going to tell each of those census collectors that they shall warn the persons filling in the census form that they are to be subject to a $1,000 fine or imprisonment for six months, or both? That seems to me to be placing a tremendous responsibility on the census taker as well as on the citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the Australian Democrats are correct in drawing the attention of the Committee to the harsh way in which this matter can be dealt with in the courts. Of course we do not condone the giving of false information in a wilful fashion by the person filling in the census form. Nevertheless, a tremendous responsibility is placed upon the court to adjudicate in cases where a fine of this nature and imprisonment of this nature can be imposed. Let us face it, it is a jurisdiction and a power which the legislation proposes to give the courts and it is very harsh so far as the average citizen in concerned. Whilst we do not want to see the Bureau of Census and Statistics put in a position of having no power to collect information, when it comes to the question of imposing a penalty upon millions of our citizens I think the Committee is entitled to say that this is a power of imposition which ought not to be given to the courts. After all, at the moment there is a $100 fine with no threat of imprisonment, but the Government is proposing that that $100 fine should be increased to $1,000. It is proposing that there be a $1,000 fine or a penalty of six months' imprisonment, or both. That is a very tyrannical proposition and one which ought not to be approved without a great deal of consideration by the Committee. I am sure that the Government itself has not realised the punitive nature of these particular provisions. They strike at the very heart of the rights of the citizen.

I just fail to see how any citizen could be warned about the consequences of being frivolous. Let us face it, there are plenty of people who see a bit of humour in filling in forms and who could place themselves in this invidious position whereby their livelihood could be affected, whereby a large fine could be imposed and whereby, in fact, they could find themselves placed at a considerable disadvantage by being put in gaol. Such a situation contrasts, does it not, with what happened about the doctor here in Canberra who quite clearly was found guilty of a very contrived arrangement to defraud Medibank. He was fined $27,000 yet he served a paltry six days in gaol. When one compares that sort of penalty with the penalty that is suggested in proposed section 26 in the Schedule, it seems to me that Mr and Mrs Citizen are placed at a decided disadvantage. To suggest that a citizen should be put in the same category as an officer of the Australian Bureau of Statistics who might wilfully divulge information concerning the privacy of the individual or of the census form seems to me to be totally foreign and repugnant. In that case we would be comparing a wilful action that might be taken by a public servant with an action by a citizen of this country who might be doing it just for a lark.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee, prior to the suspension of the sitting, was examining the amendments proposed to sections 24 and 26 dealing with punishments relating to the Census and Statistics Amendment Bill which is before the Committee for its consideration. I was canvassing the view which the Opposition has about these two new sections. The amendment to section 24 proposes to delete the words 'The Statistician, an officer, or the occupier of a dwelling' and substitute 'A person who is, or has been, the Statistician or an officer'. I was drawing the Committee's attention to the fact that in these circumstances an officer is invariably a casual member of the Statistician's staff employed for the purpose of collecting information from the householder or the occupier of the dwelling, as he is identified in the legislation. I was pointing out that we are asked to approve proposed section 26 which establishes the same sort of penalty for breaches of the legislation insofar as they are wilful acts by either the officer or the occupier of the dwelling.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to the Opposition, as indeed it seems to the Australian Democrats, that this cannot be sustained as being a fair and reasonable approach. Clearly, if the information relating to secrecy is breached by the officer, one can concede that that is an offence which is covered not only by this legislation but also by the Crimes Act and by the Public Service regulations. We submit to the Committee that to suggest that the same sort of penalty should be applied to the occupier of a dwelling-that is, citizen A or B-is harsh, tyrannical and unfair. Whilst it is conceded that in some instances the occupier of the dwelling may wilfully give false information, it cannot be said that the penalty for that should be equal to that for an officer who wilfully gives information relating to facts collected as a result of the Statistician's activities. Distinctions exist which ought to be recognised in the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. In fact, we probably ought to go a little bit further than that amendment. The amendment seeks to take out the penalty of imprisonment for six months or imprisonment plus a fine. I draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that we are talking here of a citizen being subject to a penalty of a $1,000 fine or six months' imprisonment or both. There is a discretion, it is true, that the judge can exercise. However, it is a very harsh punishment for some facetious, nevertheless wilful, disregard of the responsibilities of a citizen should these matters come to a point at which there is a dispute between the citizen and the officer acting on behalf of the Commonwealth Statistician.

We express grave disquiet about having the same type of penalty included in the Schedule, as suggested by the legislation currently before the Committee. We certainly urge that proposed new section 26, as far as it relates to the citizen, should have a different type of penalty. It may be conceded that there are occasions when the citizen, for a variety of reasons, is anti-authoritarian, unwilling to respond to governments, angry with governments or prepared to defy governments and authority because of some previous experience. That person should not be placed in exactly the same category as a person who is an employee of the Crown-that is, the Statistician or the officer appointed to represent the Statistician-who wilfully gives information knowing full well that it is in breach of this legislation, the Public Service regulations and, in some respects, a breach of the Crimes Act. We ask the Committee to exercise some discretion in this matter and not just blindly follow the Executive recommendation and the adoption of this proposition in the House of Representatives. To the extent that the amendment moved by Senator Mason removes that part of the penalty that suggests that there should be imprisonment as well as a fine, the Opposition is prepared to support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I exercise my right to speak again to the amendment because I wish to stress to honourable senators my conviction as to what I see as its deep and basic importance. I concede to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner)the significance of the word 'knowingly', but there again we have a difficulty of interpretation. Whether a person can be said to know that he is giving false information has always been a difficult legal principle to establish at the best of times.

SPEECH.PARA: The objection of the Australian Democrats is to the proposal that those who give such false information in filling in a form should be subjected to a fine of $1,000 or six months in gaol, or both. The existing Act provides for only a $100 fine. No gaol term has ever been provided for that kind of offence. Thus, the Government's proposal is quite new. Earlier the Minister in charge of the Bill, Senator Messner, made excuses for what I see as an intolerable provision by saying that the courts would interpret it lightly. I suggest that, as members of parliament, we have no right to shuffle off our responsibilities to the courts; that if we say that a certain thing can be done we should accept responsibility and not say: 'Oh gosh, probably, although we do that, the courts will be okay and will not injure people'.

Basically, as a matter of principle, we must decide whether it is right to introduce in Australia the principle that an Australian can be put in gaol for not filling in a form correctly. TALK.START.PARA: -I wish to raise two points only. —I wish to ask what penalty flows to a person who refuses to participate in a census.
—One who knowingly does not give any information.

—That is correct. He knowingly does not give any information. I ask that question because I wish to extend my query beyond the taking of the population census as such. Does the provision refer to a person who refuses to participate in any sort of census? I take it that from time to time investigations, inquiries or collections of fact are undertaken. Certain people are selected at random and asked to give information as to whether they are employed, how many people live in their house, what is the status of such people, whether they are employed, receive unemployment benefit and so on. From time to time a number of honourable senators receive representations from people who object to giving such information. Will the increased penalties catch people who refuse to participate in such surveys? If so, one would have to look very seriously at the amendment and seek to reduce the effect of the rather draconian measures embodied in the Bill. Perhaps the legislation does not cover the occasional, random collection of material. If it does, the proposed increase in penalties must be looked at in a more serious light.

—I wish to speak briefly in favour of the amendment, which is concerned to reduce the severity of the penalty to be applied to people who do not comply with the requirements of the census. Each time we have a census, certain members of this Parliament-one could name the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron) and Senator Townley-complain repeatedly, I believe misguidedly, both in this Parliament and in the media about the nature of the forms and the number and type of questions asked. If elected members of this Parliament are advocating that the census form is intrusive, that people should not be obliged to answer it-I repeat that I believe they are wrong in so doing-we have an interesting situation in which people who take their advice could be sent to gaol for six months. That is an intolerable situation. No matter how misguided our fellow parliamentarians might be, they are entitled to advocate their views in the Parliament. If people follow those views they are likely to be sent to gaol. I add that argument to the cogent arguments in favour of the amendment. Therefore I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address myself to two or three of the points raised. They are similar in nature. Firstly, in regard to Senator Mason's amendment I repeat the point that I made during the second reading debate: Section 26 of the substantive Act, to which the amendment relates, states:

SPEECH.PARA: No person shall knowingly make in any form or document filled up or supplied in pursuance of this Act or in answer to any question asked him under the authority of this Act any statement which is untrue in any material particular.

The two key words there are 'knowingly' and 'untrue'. They suggest that there must be intent designed to mislead or to provide false information. That would need to be proven for a prosecution to succeed under this legislation. I wish to make just a few other general points. Firstly, I refer to the whole question of upgrading the penalties. The penalties set out in the substantive Act were laid down in 1905.

TALK.START.PARA: —I mentioned that.

—Yes, Senator Townley mentioned that. There have been some increases in those penalties. The penalty contained in section 11 has been increased from $20 to $500. I have not done the sums, but I think it is reasonable to assume that that is not an unreasonable change when we consider the difference between 1905 money values and today's values.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 26 concerns an important issue. As I stated in the second reading debate, the section provides a reasonably tough penalty. However, it is a maximum penalty. I now point out that, of course, it relates not only to the census but also to the whole area of the collection of statistics by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. That is a very important point because, as honourable senators would know, the Australian Bureau of Statistics collects statistics on behalf of the Government from all kinds of organisations, including business firms, commercial enterprises and industrial organisations. That is very important information for obtaining correct forecasts and histories as to the direction of the economy, and so on. For that reason a rather stiff penalty has been written into the legislation. As I stated, it is a maximum penalty which is certainly subject to consideration by the courts when considering their judgments. I believe that to be an important area of concern in predicting trends in the economy of the country and in obtaining reliable information upon which government decisions and, for that matter, commercial and private decisions about the direction of the Australian community in the next few years will be made.

I draw the attention of Senator Lajovic to the point I have made that the relevant section refers to a person who knowingly provides untrue or false information. I am no lawyer, but I do not think it is by any means possible to draw the conclusion that people who by accident or by misunderstanding provided false information in a form, whether it be census information or information of a more general statistical kind, could put themselves in a position of being successfully prosecuted and imprisoned. I cannot give the honourable senator an assurance. Naturally enough, if such a thing occurred it would have to be considered by the courts, and that is a matter which I cannot comment upon. But it seems to me to be reasonable to draw that kind of assumption from the information before us at present.

Senator Townley asked why we needed to provide a penalty of this kind. Essentially we are seeking to get information. It is obvious that it is not likely that the penalties will be applied in most cases. We will be able to ensure that people comply with the law, in which case the penalties will not be applied. That is the main ingredient of this kind of legislation. That sort of provision is common throughout other legislation that this Parliament has decided upon over many years and it is a widely accepted principle of administration. In that sense I do not regard this as a draconian measure. I see it as a measure which tries to prevent the provision of deliberately misleading information in the gathering of statistics. I do not think we can look at it in any other terms. Indeed, the history of the principal Act is that since 1905 very few cases have reached the stage of prosecution.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it there for?

—Exactly. The fact it is there demonstrates that people are not breaking the law. That is the point I am making, and I hope honourable senators can see that. Senator Georges commented in regard to a number of matters. I think I may have cleared up one or two points in his mind by saying that this legislation concerns not only the census but also a broad range of statistical returns. Senator Georges cut across several points in relation to the census. Under section 11 of the substantive Act a householder not complying with the law would find himself subject to a penalty prescribed in the Schedule to the amending Bill.
—How much?

—A maximum of $500, with no other substantive provision. What I am pointing out to Senator Georges is that that does not bear in any way on the amendment which has been moved by Senator Mason because it does not touch on section 26, which provides that no one shall knowingly provide information which is untrue in respect of not only a census but also the whole range of statistical returns.
—We ought to move other amendments as well.

—That is Senator Georges's privilege, but I made that point only because he raised the matter during the debate. Earlier Senator Walsh made the point that this was a harsh penalty. I hope he would agree, as Senator Grimes, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, has already said, that the provision of information of this kind is important for government purposes. Indeed, Senator Walsh has just acknowledged that. I agree that the need for information of a statistical kind so that we can make proper judgments as to the direction of the Australian community is of the utmost importance. Accuracy is the next most important question. I believe that is what Senator Mason's proposed amendment is all about. Unfortunately I think he missed the point. On that ground the Government rejects the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I say that I am surprised that more Liberals are not objecting to the proposed new penalties.
—It is after dinner. They are not even here. That is how interested they are.

—They may be interested. Senator Walsh knows very well that there are many loudspeakers inside this building. He was straightened out once today when he said something to a Minister that should never have been said in this place.

—Senator Walsh knows what was said. It was the second most ridiculous thing I have ever heard said in this Parliament. It will put on the statute book something that I regard as being totally unnecessary, particularly in light of what the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has just said. In reply to one of the questions I asked a moment ago about how many people in fact had been fined under the $100 penalty, the Minister did not give me an exact number but he intimated to me that it would be very few. SPEECH.PARA: The point is that it is not known that thousands of people have been giving wrong information. To say what is proposed will be the upper limit of a penalty is just not good enough. Let us take the extreme argument which is what engineers often do when they are trying to analyse something. Let us look at the situation in which we could have imposed a $1,000 fine or the penalty of death. If a person were to go to court knowing that the maximum penalty was death he would have to have a much more expensive defence than if the penalty were just a $1,000 fine. People can perhaps survive a $1,000 fine, but not many people can survive the death penalty. I suppose that in these days in this country people can survive even the death penalty because of the crazy rules we have on our statute book. I am not prepared to support another crazy rule. I said a moment ago that I am quite prepared to see a higher amount imposed than $1,000 if the purpose is to make sure that we get accurate information. I agree that accuracy of information is important. The census will affect 14 million or 15 million people. I would be surprised if we had had 100 charges brought under the penalty of a $100 fine over the last 50 years. At this stage the percentage of such charges is just too small to bother working out. In other words, we are putting on the statute book for a future government or a future Attorney-General-we do not know what their attitude will be or how they will want to use this piece of legislation if it is passed as it is-something that is completely unnecessary and which may be used in a way in which we do not intend it to be used. If the Minister says tonight that the courts will treat these matters leniently that is all very well. But, as I have said, I would not be at all surprised if we had another Minister one day. They look at the words and sometimes one word can make all the difference between a very severe penalty and one that is more sensible.
