SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has applied himself to the fears of the Opposition in relation to section 26. I will respond to the queries that have been raised by Senator Townley and Senator Lajovic. I stress to them that in no way has the Minister's reply satisfied their concern or, in fact, our concern. I make a plea to those members of the Government who on many occasions have shown a concern for the civil liberties of the citizen to look at just what section 26 seeks to do. I also draw attention to the Minister's reply. The Minister is glossing over the fact that we have two distinct problems. In his reply he referred to the fact that persons who knowingly fill in forms in a false and misleading way are entitled to be penalised because of the importance of maintaining some reliability in respect of information. He is ignoring the fact that we are extending that provision to the average citizens of our country. Section 26 states:

SPEECH.PARA: No person shall knowingly make in any form or document filled up or supplied in pursuance of this Act or in answer to any question asked him under the authority of this Act any statement which is untrue in any material particular.

Obviously if we were to ask, for example, a big corporation about the degree of foreign ownership or the degree to which it engaged in trade or commerce and a person in that corporation knowingly withheld that information, it would be wrong to suggest that that person would not be entitled to be penalised. We do not make that assertion. But to suggest that that person should be placed in the same category as the six million householders in Australia-the persons Senator Lajovic and we on this side of the chamber are concerned about-is wrong, having regard to the fact that we are now a country of migrants.

A very substantial proportion of our citizens are migrants and a very substantial proportion of them do not understand our customs, our traditions and the way in which forms should be filled in. Who is to estimate whether they knowingly or wilfully mislead or make any statement which is untrue in any material particular? Who is to make that assessment? The census collector, the person appointed by the Australian Statistician's Office, could make that assessment based on the prejudice that that person may well have about a particular group of citizens living in a particular area, which is the way in which many of our migrants live in this country today. Let us face the fact that a residual racist and chauvinist position exists in many sections of our community.

I would not like to delegate, through the Senate, to a collector the right to make that judgment in respect of the way in which a person responds to the six-yearly census that is to be carried out under the terms of this Act. I would not like to put that person, therefore, in the same category as the manager of a major corporation, a large industrial undertaking or a company in our agricultural sector if, in the judgment of the collector, that person has wilfully withheld information. If that person had come from a country whose customs led him to fear authority-that is the position in respect of many people who come to Australia-one could understand his reticence and his desire to withhold information because of the environment in another land.

It seems wrong to give, as this legislation seeks to do, to a person appointed by the Crown-a statistician or an officer-the right to make that subjective judgment in respect of that person and then, as the Minister has sought to do, to equate it with a more wilful act taken by someone who is Anglo-Saxon and who wants to withhold from the Government for a whole variety of reasons information about the way in which our society, industries or commerce are operating. One would have thought that rather than leaving it to Senator Townley and Senator Lajovic to be concerned, those members of the Government parties who from time to time have shown their desire to be associated with protecting the rights of the individual would have entered the debate. We are protecting those rights, I believe, if we at least take the step of supporting the amendment moved by Senator Mason. One would have thought that more and more Government senators would come in so that we could let them see the trap into which we are being led in being asked to give approval to the provisions of the Bill before the Committee.

After all, no explanation that is acceptable to the Opposition has been given by the Minister as to why imprisonment is needed. People associated with criminology, people associated with our penal institutions and people concerned with the welfare of our citizens have already pointed out that there are too many people in gaols in this country and that imprisonment is not the form of punishment that ought to be imposed for misdemeanours committed within the community. The Government suggests that the fine should be increased from $100. That is the figure in section 26 of the Act as it now stands. There is no evidence that that fine was inadequate. Senator Townley was quite correct to raise the point. Where is the evidence that the present fine does not act as a deterrent? If it is argued, in the effluxion of time, that $100 is too small a fine or penalty and that the fine ought to be raised to $1,000, we will not quibble with that. We do quibble with the inclusion of a provision for a penalty by way of imprisonment as well as by a fine, which penalty is to be determined in some court based on the subjective analysis or assessment made by an officer acting on behalf of the Commonwealth Statistician.

It is not a minor question. I think it is a major question. The Parliament ought not to be taking steps that are likely to inflict further punishment upon the citizens of Australia, having regard to the great variety of citizens that now go to make up Australia. We have a completely new type of population make-up from what we had at the end of World War II. Those of us who have anything to do with our communities know a great deal about Australia's new citizens and their fear about authority and their inability to comprehend all the forms and formats upon which our society operates today.

I think that in all the circumstances the Minister has failed to understand the concern of the Opposition. He has failed to take into consideration the fact that we believe that if section 26 of he Act has to be amended, the form of penalty imposed on citizens who unknowingly supply misleading information in filling out census forms ought to be different from the form of penalty that is imposed on citizens who wilfully and knowingly supply misleading information to the Statistician in respect of ordinary census activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gietzelt has raised the question of whether there is some lack of even handedness in the treatment of those who commit an offence in filling out census forms compared with those who commit an offence in supplying statistical information provided to the Government as required under the Census and Statistics Act and at the direction of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. In regard to his argument I make the point that there will be no special extension as a result of these amendments to cover those who provide information for the census at 30 June this year. The substantive provisions that applied previously apply now. They have applied since 1905. The Act was originally drafted in that form. All that are to be changed are the penalties. Senator Gietzelt has queried whether there ought to be any change in the amount of the penalties. He claimed that no substantive problems have arisen as a result of non-compliance with the Act and that therefore the $100 penalty ought to apply. The fact is that the Australia Law Reform Commission in its recommendations has stated that the penalties ought to be upgraded. Consequently the Government is--
—We do not disagree with you on that point, but we are suggesting that there ought not to be imprisonment as well.

—In that case, I fail to observe the difference in our arguments. I fail to see that there is any debate between us. I answer the points made by Senator Gietzelt in those terms. Senator Gietzelt sought to make a major point in relation to those who might, by accident or through misunderstanding, in some way provide false or wrong information. I put it to him that quite clearly the substantive Act in section 26 speaks of knowingly providing information which is untrue. That is the specific point on which I sought to answer Senator Lajovic's remarks earlier. Naturally that is what the Government would be concerned about but clearly that will be a matter for the courts to decide in the event of any prosecution being launched. As I sought to make clear in response to Senator Lajovic's remarks, I believe that where genuine misunderstanding was clearly stated in evidence in any court it would be very difficult for anybody to prosecute a person under that section. It is these penalties about which we are talking. Of course, whatever I have said in this area is in no way an assurance. As I have pointed out to Senator Gietzelt it will be a matter for the courts to decide. A maximum penalty is provided. It will be a question for the courts, in the proper exercise of their judicial powers and their judicial rights, to determine penalties as they judge particular issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to the response of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) to my earlier queries, I am now inclined to oppose the Bill. We have discussed the Bill in the party room. I think we considered it only in relation to a universal census. The Minister has said that the penalty provisions of the Bill will also apply to the collection of random information from time to time. I believe that he has admitted that the provisions cover the gathering of statistical material, including random sampling at any time. I would like the Minister to explain exactly what random sampling is. How does one arrive at the guidelines for random sampling? My understanding is that the Australian Bureau of Statistics decides that it wants certain information from a certain area. It then selects at random from, say, 30,000 homes in that area a sample of, say, 30 homes. Having selected those homes at random it compels the occupants to give certain information. Using that information it comes up with some statistical data.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand from the Minister's response that the increased penalties will cover any person chosen for such a random sample who refuses to give the required information. There is considerable difference between a random sample and a universal census. Everyone is required to participate in a universal census but only some people are required to participate in a random sample. The same principle applies in relation to small businesses. So the Bueau will say to a certain number of people selected from the community: 'Give us this information. If you do not do so or wilfully give false information you will be up for a fine of $1,000 or six months' imprisonment'. No person is prepared to give false information in a random sample. My experience is that if a person refuses to give that information, the statistician will say: 'You must give the information'. If the person asks 'Why me?' the statistician says: 'You and you alone must give this information. If you withdraw you wreck the whole sample'. That occurs quite often. A young person is confronted at the door by a member of the Bureau who says: 'We want this information, and we are going to call in a fortnight's time, and thereafter again in a fortnight's time, and you must give this information'. The person says: 'I do not want to give it. It is personal, it is private. I am not working. I am on unemployment'. Who knows? He may be afraid of officers of the Department of Social Security.

We know the practices of officers of the Department of Social Security who try to establish some de facto relationship. They can go through a house, look in the various rooms and cupboards, see whether there are double beds or single beds, and whether the double bed has been used. People in depressed, underprivileged, disadvantaged conditions make their own arrangements these days. Maybe they are ripping off the Department, but they do not want to expose themselves to the statistician. Possibly the statistician will say that all the information is confidential, but the person who is asked to provide this information is not certain of this. Therefore he says: 'I do not want to participate'. Then the statistician says: 'You will be fined'. The person says: 'I will risk the fine'. Previously the fine was $22. Some people are prepared to risk a fine of 22 bucks rather than have their privacy invaded. What has the Government done now? It has increased the fine to $500. It has not been increased 10 times, it has been increased more than 20 times.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact it is twenty-five.
—Thank you. My arithmetic is not the best.
—Over 75 years.

—I am not concerned about 75 years. To a person who is in a deprived situation, $22 is a vast sum. It is relative. If we frighten a young person with the threat of a $500 fine, we intimidate and harass that person. What happens if that person gives wrong information knowingly? For instance, he may be in a de facto situation which he does not want to disclose, so he does not disclose that information. Further, if the person gives wrong information which is subsequently checked and found to be wrong, that person is liable to a fine of $1,000 or six months gaol-a person who has been chosen at random to give information for statistical purposes. The Minister may smile-
—I am not smiling. I was trying to attract someone's attention.

—I thought the Minister might be smiling in understanding rather than in disbelief. It is a serious matter. I think we ought to do to the Government what we did once before. We ought to report progress so that some of us can look back on this matter. I do not know whether anyone has reasilsed that these increased penalties cover the gathering of all statistics, aside from the national census. Even from the national census point of view, these measures are rather harsh. Nevertheless the penalty falls on us all. The random sampling, whether it be of an individual or a small business, falls on some who are specially selected. For that reason the penalty becomes exceedingly harsh.
—Wouldn't Senator Mason's amendment cover that random sampling?
—No, it would not.
—It covers all of section 26.

—It covers section 26, but it does not cover section 11. Section 11 refers to a person who refuses to give information. My experience is that many young people-not only young people, for that matter, but also pensioners-may not wish to answer.
—Widows, too.

—Of course, people living in extraordinary situations. There is an intrusion which stimulates fear. These people are now faced with the added harassment that a person can say: 'You will give the information and you will give it correctly. If you do not give the information you are subject to a penalty of $500'. Now $500 is a lot of money, and it is of no use the Minister's saying: 'Look, leave it to the magistrates. We give only an upper limit, $1,000 or $500'. The person would be at quite a disadvantage if he faced some of the magistrates in Queensland. One other honourable senator whom I can see in this chamber has faced a magistrate in Queensland.
—You have.
—Yes, I have. The chairperson has faced a magistrate in Queensland. She would know how cold-hearted and cold-blooded they can be.
—They treated you leniently by not imposing the maximum penalty available, however.

—The penalty was severe enough. If they had imposed the maximum penalty, I would possibly still be in Boggo Road Gaol, especially since there were continuing penalties for refusing to salute the warders. So it went on in a catch-22 situation. If it were not for the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia, I would still be there.
—Why blame that union?
—I am not blaming it. I am supporting it. Its members refused to man the ships.
—Senator Georges, confine your remarks to the Bill before the chamber.

—May I finish my story? Since they refused to man the ships, the ship owners found it cheaper to pay the fine and let me out than to let me rot. If it were left to Bjelke-Petersen I would still be rotting there.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the matter before the chamber. If we are to depend on magistrates, we could get a magistrate who for the moment may be ill-disposed towards or may not like the person before the court and may be somewhat displeased by the appearance of that person. Who knows? He may not take the oath, he may make an affirmation. In Queensland if one makes an affirmation instead of taking the oath, the penalty can be tripled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or if you are in Canberra you might get only six days in gaol.

—Instead of a fine of $27,000. Let me get back to the Bill. We cannot leave a discretion to the magistrate or give the magistrate scope to the extent that we have in this Bill-that is, $1,000 or six months in one instance; or, in the other instance, $500. I am getting very close to the point of opposing the whole proposal, because the Minister said there have been only a few occasions since 1905 when people have been taken to court. If that is the case, why change? Who imposed this change? Was it the statistician who is having difficulty collecting the information that he wants? In any case, the razor gang has decided that the statistician is collecting too much information. Perhaps it would have been better for the Government to impose further restrictions on the statistician rather than increase his power.

SPEECH.PARA: I seriously suggest to the Committee that these penalties are far too great. We have now had it revealed to us that this section catches not only those involved in a national census but also those involved in a random sample. That makes it most unfair. I would suggest that the Government take another look at the legislation and not persist with these heavy penalties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) a question about section 26, about those people who have given information, knowing that the information is untrue, and about the penalties that may be imposed. The Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, of which I am a member, currently has a reference on Australia and the refugee problem. We have been interviewing a number of refugees all around Australia. The majority of those refugees are Vietnamese who have come from camps in Thailand or Malaysia or refugees from eastern Europe who have come from Vienna. It is quite obvious to all of us that a number of them gave false information which facilitated their entry into Australia. These refugees come from the two largest groups of refugees. I refer to Vietnamese and people from eastern Europe. These people in particular are often very wary of officials and official forms but they are especially wary when somebody visits them at their home and asks for detailed information. The danger that I see and what worries me is how this information that is collected could be used in the future. If a person gives information to a Government department in order to get into this country and years later on a census form gives different information, can the Minister tell me what penalty he will receive under section 26 or whether the provisions of that section apply to him?

—In response to Senator Georges I think the point must be made, as he would quickly acknowledge, that if penalties are set out in an Act of this kind in order to bring about actions by people against whom the penalties may be levied in the future by courts, the success of the legislation may be indicated by the lack of prosecutions. I sought to make that point earlier. There is substantial compliance with the law as a result of penalties being provided in legislation. I think Senator Sibraa would acknowledge too that all census information and other statistical material provided is confidential between the Australian Bureau of Statistics and those people who provide the material. In respect of the census, which seems to be his particular concern, the forms would be destroyed as soon as possible after they were processed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Census and Statistics Amendment Bill 1981 provides evidence as to why the business of Parliament should not be conducted in the way in which increasingly it is being conducted and in which in the last few weeks it always has been conducted, that is, the practice of the Government, followed in the case of this Bill, of bringing legislation into the House of Representatives one Thursday night and having it forced through the House the next Thursday night. In retrospect I recognise that the penalties question was not given adequate consideration by the Australian Labor Party. I will explain why that happened. The Economics Committee of the Party which handles taxation legislation meets at lunch time on Thursdays. This Bill was introduced on the night of Thursday, 30 April. The Party Executive had to make a recommendation on the Bill the next Tuesday and the Caucus had to make a decision on Wednesday. In other words, there was no opportunity for the Economics Committee to meet in its normal fashion and discuss the legislation prior to a Party decision being made. I say that partly because of the comments made by Senator Georges. It was not the practice, when I first came into Parliament-I do not think it was the practice for many years, if ever, before that-for legislation to be rammed through the House of Representatives in less than one week. But this year under the Fraser Government that has become standard practice. It is now the norm.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to the first speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) in the Committee stage of this Bill, let me state that these penalties do not upgrade the penalties of 1905. In section 26, to which Senator Mason's amendment refers, the financial penalty is updated by the provision of a fine of up to $1,000. The six months' imprisonment is added. This is not a question of updating 1905 legislation. It has been updated and a term of imprisonment of up to six months has been added.

Senator Messner said that there have been few prosecutions under this legislation. I accept that statement as being true. I cannot say that I have not heard of a prosecution under section 26 of the principal Act against a person for knowingly supplying untrue information. If there have been almost no prosecutions the logical argument which flows from that is that there is no need to increase the financial penalty, let alone impose for the first time a possible term of imprisonment. The argument that it is necessary to have severe penalties such as this in order to collect accurate information to assist with economic forecasting is revealed as humbug coming from a government which decided to defer, for a considerable period, the processing of much of the information that the last census produced and indeed to abandon processing some of it altogether on the spurious grounds of economy.

When we look at the penalties imposed in this Bill compared with penalties imposed in other legislation other very serious inconsistencies are revealed. Some breaches of the Income Tax Assessment Act carry a penalty of imprisonment. An amendment that went through the Parliament last year concerning the destruction of company records in association with tax evasion schemes is one example which comes to mind. I do not believe that there are any breaches of that Act relevant to putting inaccurate, untrue or false information into a taxation return which carry the possibility of imprisonment as a penalty. The motives of people who submit false information and understate their income on their tax return are obvious. They aim to cheat the Government of revenue. That is theft. But they do not risk imprisonment.

For a wide variety of reasons people may insert false or inaccurate information in census or other Bureau of Statistics data collection. For example, people have inhibitions about previous marital or reproductive experiences which may or may not seem to be rationally justified so they supply information that they know to be inaccurate. Surely that is a peccadillo especially when compared with the deliberate understatement of income with the intent of defrauding the Australian Taxation Office of revenue. That is theft. Other examples have been given by Senator Lajovic and several of my colleagues of people who have had unhappy experiences with authoritarian regimes in other countries and who are reluctant to supply personal details. For example, it is easy to imagine someone of Jewish ancestry being reluctant to supply personal details given that Hitler went back three generations to see whether he could find a Jewish ancestor before someone was declared a Jew and exterminated. Obviously such people would be reluctant to supply information, given their unhappy experiences, yet are we saying that for a peccadillo which does no serious harm these people ought to be imprisoned for six months?

Nothing that the Government has put forward justifies the penalties which the Bill proposes. Indeed the arguments presented by Senator Messner, who is handling the Bill, not only strengthen the claims which are made in this amendment that the penalty of imprisonment ought to be waived, but also could quite logically be held up as an argument in favour of reducing the substantial increase in the financial penalty imposed. Nothing that has been said in this debate persuades me that the Opposition ought to do otherwise than support the amendment that Senator Mason has moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I need some further information which has not been given. I asked how the Australian Bureau of Statistics carries out random sampling. I would like the Minister to explain to me how it is done. I want to press home the point that people who are involved in random sampling against their will are subject to the full measure of the penalties provided for in the legislation. How does the Bureau carry out random sampling?
—Obviously that is a matter of detail which would need to be the subject of a briefing for Senator Georges and I would be happy to arrange that for him with the officers of the Bureau.

—That is not satisfactory. I want to know how it is carried out so that I can decide how I will vote on this amendment. So how about giving me the information now? If you cannot do it straight away, perhaps you can--
—I would be happy to arrange that.
—Can we have that information before we complete the Committee stage? I want to ask further questions on it.
—No. I am unable to provide that information at this time but I will be happy to arrange an interview for Senator Georges with officers of the Bureau.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has not replied to my satisfaction in respect of the issue that I raised about the universality of section 26 as it is applied to Part IV of the principal Act. Section 16 provides:

SPEECH.PARA: The Statistician shall, subject to the regulations and the directions of the Minister, collect, at least annually, statistics in relation to all or any of the following matters:

The section then defines the matters as vital, industrial and social; employment and non-employment; imports and exports; interstate trade; agricultural; banking, insurance and finance; and so on. The point I raised with the Minister concerned the fact that the provisions that apply to people who withhold information or who give misleading information wilfully ought not to apply to the members of the six million households in Australia. I think we ought to have some assurance from the Minister because we are dealing with two classes of people. Yet, as Senator Walsh correctly stated, section 26 puts into the one area these people who can act in such a way as to prevent economic forecasts being made, for example, and who therefore play a wilful role in providing misleading information and those citizens who do so unknowingly. Because of ignorance or fear of authority or for any other reason these people are placed in exactly the same position as those who may wilfully give misleading information under that section of the principal Act. I would like the Minister to concede that these far-reaching effects ought not to be part of the Bill before the Committee. Therefore, there is some sense in the way in which the amendment seeks to rectify the obvious injustice and unfairness in respect of these two different categories of people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am again drawn into this discussion not only on the question of penalties but also on the question that was raised by Senator Georges in relation to random sampling. It was mentioned that this penalty applies to any false statement that is made under the provisions of the legislation which include the gathering of statistics at any time. My knowledge of random sampling relates to a case that was brought to my attention. A householder rang me because the person was very concerned that the collector of statistics had called around to the home with the intention of asking the members of that household to fill in a form on the day. As the people were not home a card was left asking the householders to fill in the particulars. They did not think they should have to do this, so they refused to fill in the form. They got from the department a letter which said that under the Act it was essential that they fill it in and which threatened that legal proceedings would be taken against them unless they did so.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time I made representations to the Minister. The people involved were a working-class couple who had no interest in the statistics; they resented the intrusion into their privacy and they did not want to participate in the survey. As they said, the majority of the people who lived in their street would willingly give the information that was required by the Bureau of Statistics. I was informed in the reply I got that under the Act the people were compelled to fill in the return. I was told that if the Bureau had accepted my suggestion and did not insist on getting information from this couple but instead had gone to another house to get the information it would then be a case of getting statistics from selected people, that as the Bureau had picked that household at random it was obliged to get a reply from that household. As I said, in this instance the couple were not interested in statistics; they did not know what it was all about; they did not know how to reply and there was a good deal of resentment. If they had expressed their resentment by saying, 'I will not help. I will give a wrong statement', I could see the justification for the operating methods of the Bureau and I suppose people in this situation must be subject to some penalty. But surely it is not necessary to fine them $1,000 and to impose a penalty of six months imprisonment.

On a consideration of the application of these provisions, as the Minister has failed to give a satisfactory reason to justify the retention of this provision, he should take the matter back to the Government to see whether it insists on retaining this draconian penalty, particularly as it appears to divide the members of his own party. I should think the Liberal Party in its present state would not want any more divisions within its ranks on minor questions such as this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to include Senator Cavanagh in the offer I made with regard to discussions with the officers of the Australian Bureau of Statistics on this matter. Clearly, we will be able to provide some information for the honourable senator in regard to that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Normally I would object to having to wait till after we make a decision on a Bill for information which might be relevant to my and other people making a decision on which way to vote. Nevertheless, it seems to me that tonight we have to be satisfied with the amendment which has been proposed. I do not want to be accused of delaying this legislation wilfully. It is not a matter of being wilful about it; it is just that the position that some individuals will find themselves in under this legislation has been overlooked. But the amendment now before the Committee which seeks to remove the imprisonment penalty is one that is worthy of support. If by delaying the legislation by further consideration of the amendment and by seeking further information I might prejudice the acceptance of this amendment I would prefer not to press my arguments tonight-I will take them up at another time-to ensure that the amendment gets the support that it deserves. Nevertheless, the Minister should not come into this place again with the proposition that if I see him privately at some time subsequent to the debate he will give me the information. It really is not good enough. The normal procedure is, if a Minister does not have the information but is prepared to send for it, he should then report progress. But I will not persist with the argument.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Mason's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that this Bill stand as printed. Those of that opinion say aye, against say no. I think the ayes have it. The question now is that this Bill be reported. Those of that opinion say aye, against say no. I think the ayes have it. I ask honourable senators to resume their seats.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. You put the question on the rest of the Bill when the Committee was still divided which gave no opportunity to any honourable senator from this side of the House to rise to his feet to speak further to the Bill.
—Mercifully.

—Perhaps mercifully. Nevertheless I wish to pursue a couple of matters such as the information that I have not received. By putting that question to the vote while the Committee was still divided you, Mr Chairman, robbed honourable senators on this side of the Senate of the opportunity to speak.
—I put the question. If the honourable senators were slow in getting to their feet--
—How could I speak from the other side of this chamber?
—Does the Committee wish to recommit the Bill or discuss any further part of it? This is the last question on the Bill. We have dealt with every item down to the last question.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. We have been discussing the Bill as a whole. An amendment was moved to the latter part of the Bill but that does not mean that honourable senators who want to speak to the first clause of the Bill should not have the right to do so after we have disposed of the amendment which was moved. It is not a question of recommittal. It is a question of whether you, Mr Chairman, put the question that the Committee report to the Senate at a time when no one could query you because honourable senators were out of their places. Therefore, I think we must negative the decision that you report to the Senate and return to the Committee stage of the Bill.
—I again ask the Committee: Is it the wish of the Committee that this Bill stand as printed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the Committee is back to order. I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) exactly when the information that I seek will be given. I am concerned about the manner in which the random sampling is carried out and the number of people involved. What is the extent of the select few about whom mention has been made? I ceded my time and did not pursue the matter previously because it was suggested to me that the amendment was worthy of support and that no further delay should be allowed before it was put.

SPEECH.PARA: I again ask whether the Minister can give me the information now. He has two advisers with him. They should be able to give me some idea of how and the extent to which the random sampling is carried out. The chamber would then know exactly what it is about to agree to in relation to the individual people who are specially selected for the purpose of gathering statistics. The Minister indicated that if these poeple refused to participate they would be liable to a $500 fine. If people agree to participate but, because of the sensitivity of their circumstances, are not able to give all the information which is sought, they are liable to a $1000 fine and six months imprisonment. There is some concern in the community. I have a telephone message in my hand to which I cannot respond. The message is from a person who says: 'Please phone me urgently re debate'. I would like to phone that person but I will not have an opportunity to do so. This is the first time when I have been speaking that I have receive a telephone message from a constituent who wants to give further information. The person has probably been disadvantaged by the legislation. Senator Evans may have some views he wants to put to the Committee. By all means let him do so. Perhaps he would be prepared to support me when I say that individuals caught in a selective situation may be penalised as outlined in the legislation. All I am asking is for the Minister to use his advisers to give an example of what happens. The Minister told me that he could give me a briefing; a briefing is not good enough.

That progress be reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say a few words on the third reading of the Bill. The chamber has been treated in a shameful way. Genuine questions were asked. Honourable senators were concerned about the ramifications of the Bill and the heavy penalties imposed. We want to know about the application of the penalty. Does it apply to some random selection concerning the gathering of statistics? There may be many examples that would justify false information being given. Possibly we would be better briefed by that method, but the information is necessary now so that honourable senators can decide how they should vote.

SPEECH.PARA: We consider legislation which is binding on the whole of Australia. The information we seek should be made available now. Perhaps legislation in a certain form would not be agreed to if information which is to be given at some future time were available at the time of making the decision. It is unfair that honourable senators, without the knowledge of the full facts, should have to make a decision binding upon all the citizens of Australia. That is what happens under this Minister. It simply is not good enough. Many opportunities were given to the Minister to report progress and to seek leave to sit again. The debate could have been adjourned until his officer could give him the information. He refused to do so. When an honourable senator moved that the Committee report progress the Minister opposed the motion. I think the Government should ensure that we are better informed on the decisions that we have to make in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the Bill be now read a third time. All those in favour say aye, against say no.
—No. I ask, under the Standing Orders, that my vote against the third reading of this Bill be recorded in the journals of the Senate.
—It shall be so recorded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 May, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill arises from the beef industry incentive payment legislation of 1978 which introduced a scheme under which, for a variety of prescribed and usually trivial treatments, cattle producers were entitled to a Government payment of $10 per head of cattle to a maximum of 200 head. This legislation retrospectively legalises the system which has been used by the Department of Primary Industry to assess eligibility for payments to producers both in an individual capacity and as members of a partnership. The Department of Primary Industry has processed these claims in a way which has maximised the payments to the individual.

SPEECH.PARA: This scheme, promised in 1977 and legislated for in 1978, has been plagued by maladministration, fraud-this attracted the attention of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee and the police-and finally advice from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that the procedures followed in assessing the magnitude of claims were illegal. Hence this Bill. It is not surprising that this happened because the original legislation was a Malcolm Fraser National-Country Party pre-election special, an off-the-top-of-the-head political response to the strident demagoguery of Barry Cassell and the Cattlemans Union of Australia. The legislation was as ill-considered as other Malcolm Fraser off-the-top-of-the-head specials such as the 14 April assistance for farmers affected by drought which provided tax concessions for water conservation which were supposed to help those whose problem was that they had had no rain. Overlooking that fundamental defect, the scheme provided tax savings of up to $105 for every $100 invested in certain types of water conservation and distribution. It was the sort of scheme which was guaranteed to induce a gross misallocation of resources and a gross distortion of rational investment decisions. Since then one of the last pre-election specials of the same calibre was the immediate write-off for fuel stored on farms, on the grounds that this could provide a strategic reserve. It has been extended beyond farms since then. As a result of this scheme it will cost approximately $174m to provide the tanks to store six months supply. The cost to the Government because of the concession will be $78m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh, refer to the Bill.

—I am dealing with the sort of background from which schemes such as the Beef Industry Incentive Payments Scheme are generated. That was one of the pre-election specials. The couple of others which I have cited and the one I am referring to now which I am about to finish will provide storage for a quantity of fuel at a cost of $174m in total, at a cost to the Government of $78m, when under a more rational system the same quantity of fuel could be stored for a total cost of $38m.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the Bill, the rationale for the original legislation in 1978 was that it would help struggling beef producers. Certainly at that time a large number of beef producers had very low incomes. A rational government, looking at that situation and anxious to help, would devise some sort of assistance which was related or tied to income. Not so governments of the Liberal and National Country parties. The irrational tradition of the Liberal and Country parties decrees that one treats an income problem by subsidising something other than income and by relating the payments to some criterion other than income. In this case the method chosen was the per capita subsidy for doing almost anything to do with cattle. One of the procedures which qualified a producer for the $10 a head subsidy was the speying of heifers. Speying is a form of sterilisation. At the time-this is, September 1977-the scheme was announced I put out a Press statement, extracts from which I will quote, with regard to the subsidisation of the speying of heifers. I stated:
With this panic move, the Country Party has maintained its record of aggravating booms and slumps with ill conceived myopic policies . . .
Herd numbers in Australia and overseas have been falling rapidly in the last two years . . .
There is a near certainly of a major beef price recovery within two years-perhaps even a boom approaching 1973 dimensions.
The heifers which the Government is sterilising should be mated now so their offspring will be able to catch the high prices two-three years hence.
During the last boom-just before the crash, Mr Anthony foolishly stated 'demand for beef will rise so fast we'll be flat out trying to keep up with it'.
Now that the industry is about to emerge from its slump, the same people are subsidising the destruction of the industry's foundation-its young females.

I observe for the record that within nine months of that statement having been issued beef prices rose appreciably and the boom in 1979 approached 1973 dimensions. Not only was this a stupid policy, and not only was it predictable at the time that it was a stupid policy, but also it was in fact predicted. Because the payments were not related to income, although they were rationalised on the grounds that they were providing assistance for beef producers who had low incomes, the system was of course extremely inefficient. The specialist beef producers, of whom the greatest numbers are found in Queensland, who might have herds of several thousand cattle and who were incurring heavy annual operating losses because that was their only source of income, were restricted to obtaining $2,000 from the scheme. On the other hand, wheat farmers in Queensland and in all the other mainland States who had very high incomes were able to collect a windfall of $2,000 for the couple of hundred cows they happened to have. Again, of course, it was not surprising that a policy which was supposed to treat a low income problem but was related to something other than income, and indeed something which might have almost nothing to do with income, was ineffective in meeting its proclaimed objectives.

The procedures for application for the grant were so loose that an employee of the Department of Primary Industry who had no cattle, realising that this was virtually an invitation to raid the Treasury, decided to do just that and submitted a false application for payment. This employee was caught-there may have been some others who were not caught-and was ultimately charged and convicted. Prior to being charged, as soon as he was under suspicion of having completed a false declaration, he was suspended from his position in the Department of Primary Industry. I am not criticising that procedure. I just observe that a completely different rule applied to his Minister at that time who also was under suspicion but was not stood down from his position.

Questions regarding this scheme are still unanswered. Precisely who received money from it? In particular, which, if any, Ministers who introduced what was a grossly inefficient and a very expensive scheme-it cost $118m ultimately-obtained any financial benefit from it? On 6 March last year I addressed, except for the changes of names and designations, identical questions to Mr Hunt, Mr Anthony, Mr Adermann, Mr Street, Senator Scott who was a Minister at the time, Mr Fraser and Mr Nixon, which asked whether they or any company in which they were a director or shareholder received any payments under the Beef Industry Incentive Payments Scheme. With the exception of Mr Nixon, identical answers came back on 18 September. The answer from the responsible Minister stated:

The Prime Minister did not receive any payments for the operation of his property under the Beef Industry Incentive Payments Scheme. My Department has no knowledge of any company of which the Prime Minister is a director or a shareholder and is therefore unable to provide answers to those parts of the honourble senator's question.

In short the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) did not receive any payments for his property in the Western District. He may have had an interest in some other company which received payments, but the Minister was not in a position to say whether that was so. The same answer was provided from all the other Ministers I have named, except Mr Nixon. Mr Nixon's answer was different. He said that he did not receive any payments for the operation of his property. The answer went on to state:
No payments were received under the Scheme by any company of which the Minister is a director or a shareholder.

In other words, that was a more complete denial of the possibility of any payment having been received. That is not surprising because the Minister is in a position to know his own business-or one would hope he is. He is not necessarily in a position to know the business of the other Ministers about whom questions were asked. Mr Nixon, prior to that time, in response to a similar question concerning the former Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Sinclair, which was put on the Notice Paper on 3 March 1980 and answered on 19 March 1980, stated:
No payment was made to the Sinclair Pastoral Co. Pty Ltd or any of its directors under the Beef Industry Incentive Payments Scheme.

So he went further with Mr Sinclair. It was not just a question of no payment being received by the Sinclair Pastoral Co. No payment was received by any of the people who were directors of the Sinclair Pastoral Co., said Mr Nixon. In the case of the other Ministers he did not go that far.
As a result, I put the questions on notice again on 26 November 1980 and added to 'company' the word 'partnership' so that the question then read:
Did any company or partnership of which the Minister is a Director or shareholder-

In other words, I extended the scope of the questions. On 25 November I put a similar motion on the notice paper under General Business. That motion was due for debate on 9 April of this year. On that night, prior to the Senate's resuming after dinner, I was asked by a senior official of the Department of Primary Industry whether the answers to those questions had come through. The Opposition does not oppose this legislation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Bill, which is purely and simply one to tidy up the Beef Industry (Incentive Payments) Act 1977. That measure was originally passed to assist the meat producers of Australia at a time when their industry was in a very heavy state of over-supply, had experienced a series of very bad seasons and was trying to sell meat on a hopelessly depressed world market. Their situation in those days was extremely difficult. The measure made a great deal of difference to a tremendous number of small producers who had completely run out of carry-on funds, because it allowed them to proceed on a basis that kept them in business.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian cattle industry, because of its size and diversity, quite often runs into trouble. If it is not one part of Australia that is in difficulty, it can easily be another. That is largely attributable to the nature of the continent itself, which creates differences in weather and seasonal conditions. However, many of the problems of the industry in the last 20 years have been caused by over-stocking. Farmers generally have pushed further into marginal country, further than the country would stand. Considerable areas of new land have been brought into production. Often the land has not been able to stand the grazing or cropping to which it has been subjected. This has also brought with it the scourge of the ferral invader. Whereas a few years ago we used to talk very largely about the rabbit problem alone, we now have an impressive list which includes rabbits, goats, buffaloes, camels, donkeys and pigs, all of which are making severe inroads into the fringe development area of Australia. In addition, the kangaroo population is now estimated to be approximately five times the size it was 200 years ago when the white man first came here. Parts of this country which have been over-grazed and over-cropped may take 100 years to recover. In some places the ground cover has been destroyed and it will take a long time to get it back into production.

One is also quite safe in saying that the wheatlands, which also have pushed into what was traditionally sheep and cattle country, are unlikely to contract. It is also unlikely that much more new land will be opened up. But largely the fault is with the farmers themselves. They saw that there were opportunities to be taken and believed that the country would support development. Regrettably, in some areas that has not proved to be the case.

Much research has been done into the type of stock, the type of country and the methods of management that are necessary, but much more research is needed if we are to assist in getting the cattle industry on a more regular and stable plane. I have been especially impressed by the work that has been done in Queensland by Richard Wilson of Banana Station. He has undertaken extensive cross-breeding programs and research into various types of cattle that are more appropriate for the climate and conditions of that part of Australia than are the more traditional breeds. I have read a great deal of the material that he has produced and have seen some of the work that he has done. Although he is often controversial and is always trying to do something new, he is also very often right. He is seldom popular with many of the traditionalists with whom he associates.

The general program needs all the help we can give it. It is unlikely that beef numbers will increase appreciably. I cannot see that in the foreseeable future we will be able to reach a cattle population which is in excess of 30 million. Its numbers are far more likely to remain at 27 million or 28 million. This means that if we are to see an improvement in the meat industry it must be achieved on the basis of the quality of the meat itself. Each animal must be better than the comparable animal we are now talking about. Breeding must develop-we must look for the optimum growth for age and the optimum meat for feed, and we must produce the carcasses which the market wants. We also have to produce livestock that is easy to manage and easy to reproduce. Whilst I naturally have my own preferences in that regard, it is not a matter of choosing any particular breed but of how each breed copes with a particular situation.

I think a kill in excess of 5 million a year is quite unlikely. Accordingly, at the moment there is a vast overcapacity in the processing industry. I heard recently that in many parts of Australia the processing industry is working at about 40 per cent of capacity. Naturally that provides excessive overheads, much higher costs and, in turn, lower returns for the producer. That will require a conscious effort to bring about adjustment. There is no question of resorting to the 'she'll be right' complex, because she will not be right.

Whilst production in the meat industry is important, it is not nearly as important as the selling of the product. As over 50 per cent of the total production now in our market has to find a home overseas, traditionally the United States and Japan, we need to consider diversification very much and we must at all times be aware of the difficulties that can arise if anything goes wrong with one or other of the major markets. We consistently look to such places as the European Economic Community and Korea and even the Middle East and Eastern Europe as possible markets. But wherever meat is to find a home, diversification in the meat industry is very desirable and certainly needs to be fostered.

Marketing methods is one area I believe we need to work on as a means of cutting cost, improving returns and getting better education for the growers of the meat. If we want to have a good argument at any time in the meat industry we can start to discuss the methods of marketing livestock. So that I may pick my own adversaries, I can say quite openly that I dislike saleyards. I believe they provide the worst method of selling livestock. That method is expensive and inefficient. It produces unnecessary handling and it produces bruising and discomfort for the stock. All in all, I believe a negotiated on-the-hoof price is the best method possible.

I do not know of anybody in the industry who wants support. Everybody wants the total industry, growing and processing, to operate free of help and hinderance. The processing industry is very troubled at present and I am afraid that, having had a very bad year this year, it looks as though it will have another very bad one next year. We certainly do not see a happy picture when we look at the great many processing companies which have had far more bad years than good ones over the last decade. The beef production industry depends very heavily on having a sound and stable processing industry as part of it. Without a sound and stable processing industry growers can never be sure of the best returns. I think we may still have far too many disasters in the processing industry in the years ahead.

We have to rationalise our meat inspection, and the Federal Government will have to take a lead if the States are not prepared to take a reasonable attitude. We have to cut costs and we have to make them fit in with the requirements we are actually looking for. There needs to be more directional assistance in breeding, in feeding, in recording and in processing-all the way through. I am pleased to support this Bill. I hope that by tidying up the 1977 Act, we will never need legislation of that type again.
