SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1981, although we will move an amendment expressing our concern with projected changes to the quarantine procedures in this country which have emerged during the time this legislation has been before the Parliament. The Bill is comprehensive. It introduced many changes, but further changes foreshadowed in the report of the so-called razor gang are not mentioned in the legislation. That causes us some concern.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill extends the application of the principal Act to provide for the operation of a high security animal quarantine station in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. It implements some of the recommendations of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources on the inadequacy of the quarantine services in this country. It changes the law to enable the apprehension, detention and forfeiture of foreign vessels landing in Australia without authority and it brings Australia into line with international practice by removing the liability for Australia to pay compensation for imported livestock and other animals which are destroyed in accordance with the Quarantine Act when such animals have been in quarantine since importation.

We do not oppose these measures because they tighten the Act and because quarantine is important to our national security. It is clear that if anything is clearly a national responsibility it is the protection of this country from the importation of exotic animal and plant diseases. We have been blessed, as we have said in similar debates on this matter, with the absence in this country of some of the great scourges of mankind. One can think of plague, rabies, foot and mouth disease and numerous animal and plant pests and disorders. The fragility of our fortunate state is demonstrated by the isolated but frequent cases of cholera which have appeared in recent years and the odd outbreaks of exotic animal diseases, particularly fowl diseases, which have occurred.

Unfortunately, there are those who put our country at risk through the illegal importation of animal products or animals themselves, as occurred in the recent instance of the hamsters and gerbils which were introduced for gain, for profit. These people, in fact betray our country. They are potentially the cause of enormous economic loss and social damage. For instance, if foot and mouth disease got into this country we would be very fortunate if we could confine it or, in fact, wipe it out. The introduction of a disease such as rabies, which is increasing in its incidence in countries nearby, would mean an impossible task for the authorities in wiping it out because of the ample supply of native and feral animals which would act as vectors for the disease in this country.

The economic and social sabotage by people who would put us at risk is inexcusable and such people should be dealt with accordingly. But even without such idiotic behaviour we are at risk because of our vast coastline, our vast unoccupied areas and a shrinking world which allows access to this country in hours rather than days or months as was the case in the past. The increasing volume of visitors, many of whom do not understand our unique position and our need to protect it, adds to the risk. Therefore, it is of great concern that we see in the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions-the so-called razor gang-that:

The Government will also explore with State governments the appropriateness and feasibility of transferring to the States the remaining Commonwealth operational elements of the administration of quarantine. That would leave policy matters in relation to quarantine with the Department of Health for people and the Department of Primary Industry for animals and plans.

This reference is the reason I will move the amendment in the name of the Opposition. We will do this to flag the risks we see to this country. There is no need for the national security of this country to be placed in jeopardy because we insist-because of some blind, ideological views-that the States, wherever possible, should have powers over things such as quarantine. Viruses, bacteria and animal pests recognise no boundaries-certainly no State boundaries-and we should recognise this fact. If this statement means-and it is not obvious just what it means-that the quarantine service is to be spread around the State governments with local views and local prejudices it is a step backwards. It is clear that such a step backwards would not benefit the present privileged position we have with quarantine.

It is clear that we cannot, without a huge work force and without draconian powers, completely insulate this country from the various threats in this area that we will be talking about. For instance, we cannot alter the wind, the effect of the habits of the birds, and the tides. However, we can increase the efficiency of our surveillance and we can give those who supervise our quarantine services better support. It is my understanding that the people who will be following me in this debate will be emphasising this matter. There can be few, if any, countries which put surveillance procedures out to private tender without the control that such a process requires.

No country views the efficient surveillance of its borders as a suitable function to be performed for a limited time in the week or as a function to be sold out to the lowest bidder. That is not security at all and it is open to all sorts of abuses. We must ensure-I am sure the people who follow me will emphasise this-that we have adequate facilities for the interception of offenders, for the detection of offenders and for the diagnosis and the elimination of diseases when they arise. This cannot be done if the function of quarantine is hived off to the States which have differing interests, differing values and differing priorities. I emphasise that this is a national problem, that quarantine is a national function and that we should keep it as such.

The legislation, as far as it goes, certainly assists our quarantine services. Therefore, as I have said, we do not oppose it. Because of the lateness of the hour and the delay in the program I have no desire to go into the legislation any further. Others who follow me will do so. In view of our concern about this short and undetailed remark in the report of the so-called razor gang, I move:

At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the maintenance of efficient and comprehensive quarantine arrangements is vital and that any transfer of remaining operational responsibilities to the States would jeopardise this and therefore should be opposed'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I support the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1981 and the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition. It is a fact that Australia is remarkably free of those plagues and diseases which could ravage our agricultural industry, as has been pointed out by Senator Grimes. But it is also a fact that the legal and administrative structures under which our quarantine arrangements have been constructed were, until very recently, based on a turn of the century concept whereby the introduction of exotic human diseases was the paramount concern. That has changed considerably. Now, of course, the introduction of diseases which might ravage our agricultural, pastural and plant industries is of prime concern. In that case, of course, human beings could well be the vector for the transmission of such diseases into Australia. For that reason the Opposition-indeed, I think most senators around the chamber-has welcomed the various changes to the principal Act which have been introduced since 1979 in order to give a legal and administrative structure which is more in keeping with the new appreciation of the exact danger we are facing.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no need to emphasise greatly the absolute urgency and paramount need for all Australians and all visitors to Australia to take note of our favourable disease-free status and the enormous impact this makes on our trading position in agricultural products around the world. Of course, freedom from exotic disease is an absolute prerequisite for access to many, if not all, of the markets with which we would want to trade in agricultural goods. It is not only exotic diseases which could create very severe illnesses within an animal population or a severe retardation of growth within a plant population with which we are concerned. The introduction of any disease which might hinder the otherwise good growth prospects of animal or plant material and which might create uncertainty in the minds of those who would import our products is of considerable danger to our trading position. Therefore, I support entirely Senator Grimes's remarks that what is needed, amongst other things, is such an administrative program as has been occurring in recent times-it is to be commended-whereby all those coming into Australia are fully warned and briefed as to the dangers of introducing some material which could be a carrier or vector of disease.

It is my task to look at the Bill a little more closely. The first section of the Bill deals with the creation of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands facility and the application of the Quarantine Amendment Bill to that Territory in order that it may, in its operation, be safeguarded in the same way as is mainland Australia and, indeed, Tasmania. I mean by that the more traditional area of Australia as opposed to these far flung Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The facility for the quarantine station was purchased some time ago from Mr Clunies-Ross.

The fact is that the existing quarantine facility is totally inadequate in that much genetic material of great potential value to our pastoral industry cannot be imported into Australia. This means that there is a prohibition on the import of cattle, sheep, pigs, deer and goats from almost all countries. If Australia is to handle the import of such animals and genetic material in order to improve the quality of our livestock industries, then the speedy completion of these facilities-I note in the second reading speech that it is hoped that they will be completed in September 1981-will be of great benefit to the Australian nation insofar as it is dependent on a viable, prosperous and improving pastoral industry. Of course an integral part of those quarantine functions of Cocos Islands and something which will enable them to be more extensively used will be the completion of the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong which, I believe, is taking somewhat longer to complete than was originally anticipated. Nevertheless, the Opposition very much welcomes the construction and completion of the Cocos Islands facility insofar as, as I say, it would enable the importation of genetic material from those countries where direct importation into Australia would have too high a risk factor. The fact is that we need to be able to import particularly, for example, tick resistant and heat resistant strains of cattle, and the Cocos Islands facilities would enable us to do that.

The application of the Bill is appropriate and sensible and therefore is to be welcomed. What we do not see here is any establishment of priorities in regard to the application by importers to enable them to use the facilities on Cocos Islands. It will be recalled that the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources thought that some 50 per cent of the facility ought to be available to national and State agricultural agencies, which would work out their priorities between themselves, and that the other 50 percent should be available to private importers of genetic material. I think the Committee thought that a committee should be established in order to enable priorities to be sorted out amongst those private importers. The Opposition certainly welcomes the creation of the Cocos Islands facility as being extremely important to Australian agriculture and, as I say, looks forward to the completion of the facility in 1981.

The second major section of the Bill deals with the practice of granting pratique to vessels as they come within Australian jurisdiction. Pratique is a technical term which refers to the permission granted by quarantine authorities to a vessel which is deemed to be free from infection to unload cargo and passengers. Australian usage has permitted quarantine authorities to take some steps in relation to materials on such a vessel even after pratique has been granted. Very serious questions were raised before the Senate Committee, I think particularly by the New South Wales Department of Agriculture, as to whether in fact quarantine authorities lost their jurisdiction over the vessel once the certificate of pratique-that is, pratique as opposed to freedom from infection-had been granted. The amendments to the Quarantine Act do make it clear that despite the fact that pratique has been granted there will be an opportunity for the quarantine authorities to exercise their powers in relation to the vessel. As I say, that was a legal difficulty which was put to the Senate Committee of which Senator Andrew Thomas is the Chairman. That Committee recommended that the amendment before the chamber be introduced and to that extent, of course, it will have the support, I believe, of the whole chamber. The granting of pratique by radio was also a matter which our Committee suggested ought to be undertaken in order to avoid delays. We found that on balance this could be undertaken without any great risk to the Australian quarantine situation. That, too, has been provided for in the Bill and therefore is to be welcomed.

A further large section of the Bill deals with the conferring of extra powers on officers in the quarantine service. Once again, this is totally in accord with the Senate Committee's recommendations and, in fact, is a follow up to some amendments which were made in 1979 to ensure that the quarantine officers did have sufficient powers and were able to exercise them and were backed up by a system of provisions of offences and penalties which adequately expressed the community's concern that quarantine be regarded as a matter of paramount importance. We found, for example, that there was a lack of powers to inspect and confiscate after entry. We found that there was a great reliance on the Customs service to provide many of the powers which should have been and which would be well vested in the quarantine service. It was felt that quarantine officers ought to have as much power as is necessary to discharge adequately the responsibilities which the Australian people intend that service to have.

For that reason, new powers have been put in the Bill for the examination of imported animals, plants and goods before and after release from quarantine and the ability to take samples and to make tests. The quarantine officers also are able to ask questions, to require documents or samples and to undertake tests in relation to goods which are subject or which are suspected to have been subject to quarantine. There are powers to enter premises under warrant for the purpose of examining goods. Finally, there is a power to order imported goods, animals and plants, into quarantine on disease grounds in a way which is clarified and expanded. Once again, I think the whole chamber would welcome this strengthening of the powers of quarantine officers.

One section of the new Bill which gave me some concern is the retraction of a situation which was achieved in 1979 whereby compensation was payable to those who had goods, including animals or plants, destroyed under the Act for disease reasons. Those arrangements were introduced in 1979 and were then justified, I thought properly, as a means of encouraging co-operation from owners and to facilitate prompt action in exotic disease eradication operations. Certainly the Senate Committee found that in relation to an outbreak of exotic disease within Australia there was an absolute need to have such compensation arrangements clearly understood by all persons operating within the agricultural community, including veterinary officers and the farming community in order that there would be no hesitation on their part in notifying a suspicion that such an exotic disease existed and so that they would be confident in doing so, knowing that they would be compensated for any destruction which would follow the confirmation that, indeed, such disease did exist. Therefore I was somewhat surprised initially to find that the provision for compensation for goods, including animals or plants destroyed when in quarantine was to be removed from the Act. The explanation given by the Government is that an importer of such animals or plants can insure against the risk of the animals or plants being found either to be diseased or to be a carrier of a disease, and that that insurable risk ought to be part of an importer's costs of bringing material into Australia. On balance, but only on balance, the Opposition has decided not to oppose this provision.

One notes that the Government has certainly not taken on the wrath of ordinary pet owners in Australia. Compensation will still be paid for cats or dogs that are brought into the country and are destroyed while in quarantine. Those who introduce materials for more commonly understood agricultural reasons will have to insure against the risk of destruction by the quarantine service. It should be noted, of course, that many, if not most, of the cats or dogs introduced into this country would not be household pets but would be imported by a business enterprise which was concerned to ensure that it had breeding strains which would enable it successfully to engage in commercial transactions in relation to those animals. So it is a little difficult to understand why the distinction should be drawn unless, as I have said, the Government thought it was not worth tempting the wrath of pet owners throughout Australia by doing away with compensation in that instance.

I shall deal very briefly with the question of coastal surveillance. I know that Senator Sibraa will deal with this matter by illustration of events within his knowledge. It is true that quite a number of unauthorised landings in Australia have been reported from time to time. Quite often they involve small fishing vessels from areas to the north of Australia. The powers of the quarantine service to deal with these intrusions have proved to be inadequate and in fact have been able to be legally more or less ignored or rebuffed. This is obviously an intolerable situation. The Bill goes some way to create a legal situation within which the powers of the quarantine service to deal with such intrusions are clarified and made firm. On the other hand, the question is whether surveillance will be adequate to alert the quarantine service to the fact that such an intrusion has occurred.

I remember very well that we on the Committee were shocked to have brought to our notice the instance of quarantine officers in or just out of Darwin who, after being notified of a possible intrusion by a vessel which had perhaps landed on a beach some miles from Darwin, were forced to hire a helicopter from a private contractor who landed them on the beach without a radio because there was not the weight capacity in the helicopter to enable them to take a radio with them. They were left there for some 36 hours before they were able to make contact once again with the private contractor who had gone off to fulfil other duties under the various arrangements for charters that he had already entered into. In other words, it is a question not only of legal power but also of an adequate surveillance mechanism and follow-up facilities. That will involve money being made available to the quarantine service. My anecdote was not meant to reflect on the skill or concern of the quarantine officers involved but on the inadequacy of the present provision of facilities to that service by the national Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes that helicopter is not even available.

—I am alerted by Senator Sibraa to the fact that at times the private helicopter is not available. I can imagine that in that instance the alleged intrusion would go without any inspection by Australian authorities. Of course, who is to say whether the intrusion is merely that of a fishing vessel which is harbouring on some beach, perhaps bringing onto the Australian coast a couple of chooks or some small animal which carry some disease, or whether it is by drug runners, refugees or some other persons? I am sure that Senator Sibraa will follow up this matter in his remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Many Opposition senators are still of the view which finds expression within the Senate Committe report, that the location of quarantine services within the Commonwealth's administrative arrangements needs again to be seriously looked at by the Government. This matter is brought up from time to time. We acquired some support from the razor gang report which states at page 35 that policy matters in relation to quarantine should be left with the Department of Health for people and with the Department of Primary Industry for animals and plants. One would want some comments from the Minister about the exact intent and perhaps even the timetable behind that rather vague sentence. In other words, it was the contention of the Committee, as I remarked at the beginning of my speech, that because human disease introduced from abroad now manifests itself within the community and not at the quarantine barrier, so short are the travelling times from the lands where the disease might be present, the question of exotic disease control really becomes one of general community public health. In fact, the Commonwealth Department of Health has an overall policy role and, indeed, a managerial role in relation to the Fairfield Infectious Diseases Hospital for the extremely rare and uncommon exotic diseases which might be introduced.

In relation to animal, plant and general quarantine the argument is strong for such matters to be handled by the Department of Primary Industry in a way which does not impair the integrity of the quarantine service. The lines of responsibility must be such that the head of the quarantine service within the Department of Primary Industry has direct access to the Minister and not be subject to a legitimate fear by some people within the community of pressures arising within that Department to do with the maintenance of our trading position vis-a-vis other countries. The integrity of such a service has to be assured and maintained. On balance, the Committee and, I believe most honourable senators, would take the view, as do most State departments of agriculture and the majority of members of the Australian Agricultural Council, that reponsibility should be within the Department of Primary Industry so that there is a comprehensive, integrated care for Australia's agriculture in relation to the possible introduction and spread of disease throughout the animal or plant population of Australia. I simply raise that matter. I note the amendment moved by the Opposition. I would perhaps not go as far as Senator Grimes went because there may be some operational areas in which State departments of agriculture could be usefully involved, as indeed they are in many instances. The Committee saw a good example of almost total identity of operational and Commonwealth responsibilities in the Northern Territory. The extent to which that can take place with the States is a matter for debate.

What the Opposition feels is that it would not be right for the Commonwealth under the razor gang report to transfer operational elements of administration of quarantine to the States without first making the larger administrative changes by shifting responsibility for animal, plant and general quarantine from the Department of Health to the Department of Primary Industry. I also affirm the Senate Committee's confidence in the integrity and concern of the officers presently within the Department of Health and engaged in the control and running of our quarantine service. Our proposal is simply to place that service within, as we see it, the more appropriate Commonwealth department. With those remarks, and while supporting the amendment, I once again emphasise that the Opposition very much welcomes this further improvement to the legal structure relating to our quarantine protection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in favour of the Quarantine Amendment Bill, and congratulate the Government upon its introduction. The Government is concerned mainly with the health quarantine station for the Cocos (Keeling) Islands but also with many other matters. Almost all the provisions are precisely in line with the report on the adequacy of quarantine measures by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, which I had the privilege to chair. We have heard a quite detailed account from Senator Tate, who was a member of the Senate Committee. I believe that that investigation was the most exhaustive, lengthy and detailed investigation of quarantine that this country has ever seen. I am pleased to say that the Government has accepted almost all the recommendations contained in that report.

SPEECH.PARA: The importance of quarantine to Australia cannot be overemphasised. It is of absolute importance to the export industries of our country. Although mining and other export industries are growing in importance, the rural exports of Australia are still worth, in round terms, $5000m a year. It takes only a small scare like the blue- tongue scare in Queensland recently, which turned out to be no threat at all to our rural industries, to persuade countries that import many of our products to ban the importation of those products for a long time. We had the ridiculous situation of the People's Republic of China, which was importing quite a lot of our wool, stopping its imports of wool from Australia, although the wool itself had no relationship whatsoever to the bluetongue disease. Not only stock directly affected by the outbreak of a serious disease, but also the whole agricultural export industry in Australia would be affected because of the suspicion which would be created in the minds of overseas countries in relation to the risks involved in importing our products.

As I said, the changes contained in this Bill are in line with the Senate Committee's report, and I do not intend to deal at any length with those changes. Senator Tate made the point that the Cocos Island facility is an important link in our chain of quarantine protection. He also made the point that the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong is intrinsically tied up with the Cocos Island facility. Each member of the Senate Committee has encouraged the Government to complete the building of that facility at Geelong with all possible speed.

I would like to address myself briefly to the amendment moved by the Opposition. I am sorry that Senator Grimes, who moved that amendment, did not consult his colleagues who were members of the Committee, because it is totally unrelated to the matters that I am sure his colleagues would have talked about. The amendment reads:

At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the maintenance of efficient and comprehensive quarantine arrangements is vital and that any transfer of remaining operational responsibilities to the states would jeopardise this and therefore should be opposed.'

There has not been any suggestion of moving the ultimate responsibilities for quarantine from the Commonwealth to the States. Senator Tate dealt at some length with the Review of Commonwealth Functions, and he quoted a paragraph from its report. It did not talk about the abrogation of responsibility by the Commonwealth in transferring quarantine matters to the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —The policies will still be determined by the Commonwealth.

—Exactly. The policies will still be determined by the Commonwealth, and the responsibility will still be with the Commonwealth. As I said, I am sorry that Senator Grimes did not confer with his colleagues, the Australian Labor Party members of the Senate Committee, before he introduced this amendment, because I am sure that they would have straightened him out on that point.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise now that one matter that has not been dealt with to my satisfaction by the Government. It concerns Cocos Island and the priorities committee. One of the recommendations that was made by my Committee-and I know it is only a small matter, but I consider it to be rather important-states:

The Committee recommends that access to a portion (say 50 per cent) of the Cocos Island Animal Quarantine Station should be offered to recognised Commonwealth and State government animal research establishments, and that an Expert Committee on Import Priorities be established to apportion the facility between those research establishments.
The last sentence of that recommendation is the important one. It states:
The Committee further recommends that access to the remaining portion of the facility be by strict order of application.

I briefly explain the reasons why the Committee came to that conclusion. We believe that there are research facilities and organisations and State and Commonwealth government breeding stations in Australia which need access to overseas genetic material, and we believe that a priorities committee could allocate the animals to those facilities. There will be a considerable demand on that Cocos Island facility by private inporters. And why not? It will be an expensive facility, and the importers will have to pay the full cost for the time that those animals spend at the Cocos Island station. I believe that that should be so. Why should the other taxpayers of Australia supplement that cost?

Imagine being a member of a review committee that decides the priorities first of all between varieties of animals. Who would say that it is more important to introduce a pig into Australia than it is a goat? Secondly, who would be game enough to make the decision that a particular breed of cattle is more important to Australia than another breed of cattle? Senator Archer is a very successful breeder of a particular breed of beef cattle in Tasmania. I am sure that he would say that his breed of animal is more important than other breeds. But we get conflicting views. We are told that there is a need in Australia for a different breed of cattle suited to the tropical areas. We have breeds of cattle that do very well in the tropics and I believe that the economic return for Australia would be greater if we could import for the more temperate zones breeds which are superior to the animals we have now.

That is only part of the argument. This review committee which has been established will not only have to do the things that I have suggested, but also decide between individual animals. I have been interested in genetics almost all of my life. I have spent my lifetime in stud sheep breeding. I know that to try to test animals overseas to determine which have the superior genetics is impossible. These animals need to be tested in Australia under local conditions. So this Government is placing the review committee in an impossible position in deciding which varieties of animals and which individual animals within a variety should be important to Australia. As I have said before, with the exception of a portion of the facility which should be devoted to research, the whole of that facility should be available according to strict order of application.

The details of the Bill have been covered in some detail by Senator Tate. I am sure that Senator McLaren, who was also a member of the Senate Committee will make a valuable contribution to the debate as well. The Committee was investigating an interesting subject. As I have said, we are pleased that the Government has adopted further of the recommendations contained in its report. I strongly commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The broad purpose of the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1981 is to incorporate the Cocos (Keeling) Islands into Australian quarantine arrangements so as to provide a secure off-shore quarantine station, to extend quarantine powers and activities provided for in the Act, to remove the liability of the Commonwealth to pay compensation for imported livestock and certain other classes of animals destroyed in accordance with the Act, where those animals have been in quarantine since importation. The Bill also draws together changes resulting from the decision to establish an off-shore quarantine station on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands which is expected to be completed in September this year, changes resulting from the 1979 findings of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in its report on the adequacy of quarantine, and various other measures which the Government considers necessary to continue Australia's geographic isolation from many of the worst human, plant and animal health risks found in nearby and distant countries. Mass international air travel, Australia's participation in large volume international trade and the unauthorised landings in Australia of refugees and others have contributed to the growing quarantine risks that face this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak briefly on this Bill because I feel strongly about the absence of an efficient, thorough, highly skilled coastal surveillance system, especially in northern Australia. The basic substance of the Bill is totally worthless if proper coastal surveillance measures are not enforced. Therefore, I strongly support the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in its report on the adequacy of quarantine which states:

That some aspects of the coastal surveillance program be reviewed immediately, particularly in regard to the training of observers, the need for staggered flight times and the provision of the necessary facilities to respond to surveillance sightings.

It is a shame that the Government has not seen fit to implement this recommendation by including it in the Bill. When one looks at the current coastal surveillance program, the importance of the Committee's recommendations become even more obvious. As Senator Grimes pointed out, the situation today in northern Australia is that coastal surveillance is carried out by private enterprise through a tender system. The ridiculous nature of this sytem is best described in an article in the Australian Financial Review of 13 April 1981 which referred to a dispute concerning which aircraft company should get the contract to patrol the coast. I seek leave to incorporate that article in Hansard. I have checked it with the relevant Minister.
Leave granted,
The article read as follows-
CONTRACT ROW HALTS PATROLS
By JOHN LOIZOU

THE three specially-equipped Nomad aircraft used to patrol about 500 kilometres of coastline north and east of Darwin have been grounded for the second time this year for want of a decision by either the Territory or Australian Government.

The aircraft, which carry an observer, and patrol from Darwin to Bathurst and Melville Islands and as far east as Milingimbi, usually make three to four patrols a day. They have not been in the air since midnight in Friday . . . less than 24 hours after the crew of a Nomad spotted the first Indo-Chinese refugee boat to arrive off the Territory in two years.
That vessel has since been escorted into Darwin by the crew of a navy patrol boat.
The aircraft were first grounded in early February with the closure of Northern Airlines.

Northern Airlines wanted to sell its contract to patrol the coast to Transecutive, of Melbourne, a subsidiary of Edward Souery and Co Pty Ltd. The contract was awarded to Northern Airlines by the Federal Government.
The Territory Government agreed to a 50-day probationary licence but the Nomads were grounded until Transport Australia and the Foreign Investment Review Board gave their approval.

Since then, however, the Territory Government has agreed that Ansett Airlines should inherit the major routes within the Territory formerly flown by Northern Airlines. It also agreed that Ansett should get the surveillance contract.

Transexecutive has objected and the Australian Government, which has ultimate authority as to who gets the contract, has yet to announce its decision. So the 12 pilots and 12 observers who crew the aircraft are having a rest and the eight engineers who maintain them are catching up with non-essential tasks.
Most of them worked for Northern Airlines, then Transecutive-now they believe they will work for Ansett.

Meanwhile, the gap is being filled by Arnhem Air Charters, the company which flew the surveillance zone for two years, as its proprietor, Mr Ossie Osgood, says without 'missing a day' until the Australian Government stipulated that the Australian built Nomad had to be used.

TALK.START.PARA: —Northern Airlines, which was originally awarded the contract by the Federal Government, wanted to sell its contract to Transecutive but the Northern Territory Government wanted Ansett Airlines of Australia to get the contract. At the time that the article to which I have referred was written the three specially equipped Nomad aircraft used to patrol about 500 kilometres of coastline north and east of Darwin had been grounded for the second time in 1981 owing to this dispute. Even though the coast was being patrolled by another airline company, the whole tender system is obviously in need of some drastic changes.

SPEECH.PARA: The private enterprise nature of the system is itself an obstacle to an efficient coastal surveillance program. The airline company involved is determined to make a profit from the contract, which in turn leads to cost cutting measures, which can only reduce the airline's efficiency. I pose to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) and Government senators the question: Why would somebody, under this contract, fly an extra patrol if he thought that he had sighted something when really the whole basis of the contract is a profit motive? Also a matter of great concern to me is that private airline companies have no special security clearances for their employees such as those that exist for staff employed by the Department of Defence or the Northern Territory police if they carried out this surveillance work. Senator Tate referred to the possibility of people associated with drug running being able to infiltrate private companies that were carrying out surveillance. I believe it would be unlikely that anybody who had been associated in any way with drug running would be able to get a job in the Department of Defence or with the Northern Territory police. I think those two organisations would have much better internal security than any private firm that is carrying out surveillance work.

What is particularly ludicrous about coastal surveillance procedures to the north and east of Darwin is that surveillance is done on a five-day, eight-hour basis. I believe, therefore, no surveillance is carried out during the weekend. Recently I was working in Darwin on a Senate committee. Everyone in Darwin that I spoke to knew what time the planes flew and what routes they flew. Consequently one does not need to be a genius to work out that a person could land in Australia outside the surveillance times. It would not be very hard to find out the airline routes if a person wanted to come into Australia. When one learns of these facts it is amazing that so many people have been caught. The scope for the importation of prohibited goods, whether by boat or plane, is alarming. I will quote from the second reading speech of the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) in the House of Representatives. He said:

During coastal surveillance operations, a number of unauthorised landings in Australia have been reported. In the main, these breaches of quarantine legislation have been by foreign fishing vessels. These quarantine breaches by small craft in remote areas of Australia pose grave threats to the introduction of major exotic diseases.
Further on in the Minister's second reading speech, he said:
Quarantine actions of this type have highlighted serious practical deficiencies in the relevant enforcement and penalty provisions of the Act.

The Minister went on to detail new measures to enforce penalty provisions of the Act. That is all very well but the person who commits the offence must be caught first. Since the surveillance system works on a roster of eight hours a day and consists of a run down the coast and back, which everyone in Darwin seems to know about, I cannot see the Government using this Act very often to prosecute many people.

I refer again to the Minister's remarks as far as unauthorised landings are concerned. Not only should these unauthorised landings never occur but also the Minister has wisely chosen not to mention the number of unauthorised landings that are never reported because of the sloppy coastal surveillance procedures which I have already detailed. The ease of landing in Australia, or something coming very close to it, can be seen from a recent episode involving an Indonesian boat, supposedly supplying Indonesian fishing vessels, which was spotted very close to Darwin but was some hundreds of miles away from the fishing vessels that it was supposed to be supplying. I say 'supposed to be supplying' deliberately. The fact that it was hundreds of miles away from the fishing craft must raise great doubts about the real purpose of this boat being in that area. The fact that the supposed supply ship was so near to Darwin is a serious question but the events leading up to the searching of the boat raise even more serious questions about Australia's coastal security procedures.

After the boat was spotted attempts to board it were anything but swift and organised. I believe the Royal Australian Navy took eight hours to arrive at the site. I am not criticising the Navy. I realise that it was not possible for it to go directly to the Indonesian fishing boat because of the tides involved, the amount of time it took to get up steam to get out of Darwin and because of the reefs in the area. Those factors made it fairly arduous to reach this vessel.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Northern Teritory police then went to the area and they were the first to reach the Indonesian fishing vessel. They went to the area in a flat bottomed surfcat type boat. Even though when the Northern Territory police left Darwin to carry out this mission the seas were not particularly rough I believe that their lives could have been placed at risk in this exercise because they did not have the right type of boat that was needed to carry out the surveillance. Senator Tate mentioned the fact that a helicopter had been hired and used in the past for surveillance purposes but on this occasion the helicopter could not be hired because for a start it belonged to a private company and further it was undergoing repairs. What a farcical situation this is. This surveillance work is work for the Department of Defence. It is work for a proper coast guard. It is not work for the Northern Territory police. Even though I realise a very good argument could be made for the Northern Territory police having helicopters it may be that if the police had helicopters they could be required to be used in times of flood or when searching for a missing person in the Territory. Of course there could be instances of Northern Territory police helicopters not being available for coastal surveillance work. That is the main reason I say this sort of work should be the work of the Department of Defence.

SPEECH.PARA: No wonder we have so many foreign fishing vessels coming into Australian waters. They are fairly secure in the knowledge that our coastal surveillance procedures are totally inadequate. I think this has been proved by the fact that refugee boats have been able to turn up very close to Darwin and very close to the Australian coastline completely unannounced. Therefore I was stunned to read the so-called razor gang's statement on quarantine operations which reads:

The Government will also explore with State governments the appropriateness and feasibility of transferring to the States the remaining Commonwealth operational elements of the administration of quarantine.

I ask the Minister: Does this mean that the Federal Government will be taking even less interest in coastal surveillance than it does at present? I believe it is imperative that the Federal Government take full responsibility for proper coastal surveillance procedures. I repeat, coastal surveillance is not a job for profit making, cost cutting private enterprises. It is a job for the Federal Government to undertake seriously and efficiently or else, as I said at the beginning of my speech, the quarantine regulations under debate tonight might just as well be thrown out of the window.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Quarantine Amendment Bill I concur with what my colleagues Senator Sibraa and Senator Tate have said. Senator Tate and I were members of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources which inquired into quarantine matters. I am somewhat disturbed to say the least that it has taken such a long time for the Government to introduce legislation to put into law some of the recommendations that Committee made. Its report was tabled in this Parliament on 21 November 1979. Quite a lengthy period has passed since that date. The legislation is only now before the Parliament. I was reminded by Senator Sibraa, who spoke about coastal surveillance, of the occasion the Committee visited Thursday Island. I was astounded at the very slipshod method of coastal surveillance in that part of Australian waters. We saw a coastal surveillance plane taking off one day. The two observers on that plane were a couple of school teachers on their honeymoon. They were supposed to be looking for people involved in the smuggling of drugs or whatever else might be coming into the country. I leave it to the imagination of honourable senators what that couple would be doing when they are on their honeymoon. I am sure they would not be looking for any contravention of the law. That is an illustration of our slipshod coastal surveillance methods. My colleague Senator Sibraa has outlined a few of the other matters which were brought to his attention on a recent visit to Darwin. These sorts of things need to be tightened up very rigidly.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Committee was visiting Darwin we also saw some of the hulks that are beached in the backwaters of Darwin harbour where the boat people arrived. The hulks are still there. They have not been destroyed. They have to be fumigated regularly at great expense to the Australian community. When I asked some of the officers there why the hulks were not destroyed I was told there was some conflict with foreign policy, that we might offend some government, the owner, the people who have bought the boats or those who charged these so-called refugees for passage to Australia. I was told that the Australian Government might find itself in some international problem if it were to put a bomb under these boats to destroy them. In my view, as I said to the officers there, this is what ought to be done with them and it ought to be done pretty quickly if it has not already been done. I have not been to Darwin recently to have a look at this area but perhaps during the Committee stage I might ask a question of the Minister for attention by his officers as to whether those hulks are still there and if so what is the cost to the Australian taxpayers of having them fumigated regularly, and what risk do they still pose to the Australian community. Irrespective of whether the Government may tread on the toes of some foreign country, in my view these hulks ought to be destroyed, no matter who owns them.

Senator Thomas mentioned the National Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong. As I have said in this Parliament on many occasions, the laboratory was a brainchild of the Whitlam Labor Government. When I was at Geelong just a few weeks ago with a Senate committee inquiring into the aluminium industry we passed very close to the laboratory. I was very pleased to see that it is nearing completion but I was disappointed to think that it is not yet operational. Had it not been for the monetary strictures placed on the construction of this laboratory by this Government when it came into office the laboratory would now have been fuly operational and we would have been seeing the benefits from it. But because of the financial strictures placed on it by this Government in its wisdom-a very poor sort of wisdom in my view-that laboratory is not yet operational and we are now witnessing some scientists-I do not agree with them-putting the point of view that this establishment will not be of any great benefit to Australia. I do not know why they say that because all of the people with expertise to whom I have spoken have pointed out that it will be of great benefit to Australia. I think in time to come the primary industries of this country in particular, will be very proud of the laboratory and very grateful that the Whitlam Labor Government had the foresight to initiate the construction of that laboratory.

At the beginning of my remarks I made some criticism of the Government for its delay in introducing this Bill. I want to quote from the Adelaide Sunday Mail of 20 January 1980, some 15 or 16 months ago. The article was written by a journalist by the name of Kevin Love. The articles is headed 'Vets urges action on imported diseases'. The article reads:

The nation's veterinary surgeons have urged the Federal Government to take urgent measures to protect 'the health and financial well-being of every living Australian' under stricter quarantine measures.

That was said way back 16 months ago and we have this Bill in the Senate only this evening. As I said, it has taken a jolly long time. Dr Fulton was the veterinarian quoted by Mr Kevin Love. Dr Fulton was quoted as saying:

. . . his organisation's 2500 members hoped the Government would move quickly to implement the full recommendations of a Government Standing Committee report on the Adequacy of Australian Quarantine Resources.
Dr Fulton went on to say:
. . . the report, tabled in the House of Representatives in the final week of last year's Parliamentary session, ranked in importance with reports on Australia's future military defence.

How right he was because quarantine is of great importance to this country, not only to the human race but also to the agricultural industry on which we depend so greatly. We in the Labor Party are fully aware of that importance. I am disappointed that while the Minister in his second reading speech said that this Bill is embodying most of the important recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee it does not go far enough in my view. Once again while one arm of the Government is doing one thing another arm of the Government is doing something else. As I said in the Senate yesterday, it is quite apparent that the Government's left arm does not know what its right arm is doing because a recommendation in the razor gang's report stated:

The Government will also explore with State governments the appropriateness and feasibility of transferring to the States the remaining operational elements of the administration of quarantine. That would leave policy matters in relation to quarantine with the Department of Health for people and the Department of Primary Industry for animals and plants.

In my view, that is where it ought to be. This Bill contains no real mention of animal quarantine being given to the Department of Primary Industry. That is why I say that one of the two arms of government-the people on the razor gang, and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) is one of them-is not taking cognisance of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. I do not know how many other Bills which come before this Parliament will be at odds with the recommendations and determinations of the razor gang's report.

The Senate Standing Committee made a recommendation on the structure of the Australian Agricultural Health Service. In its report it set out a suggested organisational structure by way of diagram. I have shown this diagram to the Hansard officer who was at the table earlier. He said to me that he did not think there would be any great problem in having that diagram incorporated in Hansard. If it is possible I should like incorporated in Hansard the one page diagram setting out the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee in regard to the Agricultural Health Service and the suggested organisational structure. If it is incorporated in Hansard people can be aware of what the Committee recommended in relation to the setting up of the Australian Agricultural Health Service. The recommendation of the Committee is somewhat different from the recommendation in the razor gang report that the Government will explore with State governments the appropriateness and feasibility of transferring to the States the remaining operational elements of the administration of quarantine. In view of what the Minister said in his second reading speech I think the Government should have put something concrete in this Bill so that the Committee's recommendations in this sphere are in actual fact put into operation. I seek leave to incorporate that one page diagram in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The incorporation will be subject, of course, to the ability of the Government Printer to incorporate the diagram.

—I thank the Senate. I thought I made that qualification earlier. I sought its incorporation on the condition that it could be included in Hansard. The Hansard official at the desk at that time said that there should be no problem with its incorporation because the Government Printer has printed this particular diagram previously and the size of the page to be incorporated is about the same size as the page of the Hansard record.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point which attracted my attention in the Minister's second reading speech was his statement that clause 35 of the Bill would insert a new section. The Minister stated:
Finally, I draw the attention of honourable senators to clause 35 of the Bill. This clause inserts a new section which relates to the provision of quarantine information to travellers to Australia.
He went on that certain things are intercepted at international airports. He raised a most important point when he said:

Accordingly, proposed section 74AA requires the masters of all vessels travelling to Australia, including aircraft, to advise everyone on board of our quarantine requirements. The content and form of such advice are to be in accordance with approvals of the Director of Quarantine.

With the Minister having said that, I hope that the Government does something to police this new provision. I have said in this Parliament previously and at the inquiry of the Committee that on several occasions on my return to Australia from overseas I have filled in the necessary forms to indicate that I have visited farms. I have visited poultry farms, pig farms and cattle farms overseas because of my intense interest in agriculture. When I returned to Australia through Sydney airport on one occasion, the officer looked over the counter and said, 'Your boots look pretty clean, off you go'. That was after I filled in the form.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is a new clause. That is the point.

—I take note of what the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs says. I hope this new clause ensures that stricter measures are taken in respect of people entering this country to see that when they fill in the appropriate form at least they are fumigated and the proper procedures are carried out to make sure there is no danger of introducing any disease into this country. As I say, I have had personal experience of this not being done. It is just not good enough. If I and many other people to whom I have spoken are prepared to advise that we have been on farms but then are not put through the fumigation procedures, what is the position with people who do not fill in the forms properly? How many people come into this country and put our agricultural industries at risk?

SPEECH.PARA: My remarks are backed up by Press reports of recent times in which there is reference to very minimal fines. I am pleased to see under this legislation that the fines have been increased. In my view, no fine can be too great for those people who put primary industry in Australia at risk. An extract from the Brisbane Courier-Mail of 13 September indicates that a Mr Evans, SM, in handing down a reserved decision in a case involving a number of botanical specimens, fined a man $200 and ordered him to pay $250 professional costs and $18 court costs. That is a very small amount to fine any person for bringing into Australia specimens that could have spelled the death knell of our cereal industry, one of the mainstays of Australia's primary industry. Yet, this person got away with only a minimal fine being imposed. It concerns me how this material gets into Australia in the first place. There is not proper surveillance and there is not proper supervision. An article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 31 October is headed: 'Smuggled sausages cost wife $261'. That is another example of people being able to get things into the country. I am only referring now to the people caught. A report in the Brisbane Courier-Mail of 13 December states:
The quarantine division's senior port inspector for Queensland, Mr Max Schmidt, yesterday showed a storeroom of prohibited imports at the Eagle Farm quarantine station.
As I have said, these are only the goods that have been found. What about all the goods smuggled into this country which have not been found? The article went on to state:
Last year, there was a 70 per cent rise in containerised shipping and a 37 per cent increase in airport workloads in Brisbane, but no additions to quarantine staff.

The Government was falling down on the job. Despite the fact that we have a big increase in containerised shipping and a 37 per cent increase in airport work loads, there has been no increase in staff to survey this extra quantity of goods coming into the country. The report continued:
A big staff increase was expected next year but, for now, it was a case of working a great deal of overtime.

After the report of the razor gang I am worried that instead of there being an increase in staff, there probably will be a decrease which will put primary industry at risk, all because of the financial cuts brought upon us by this Government. The Brisbane Sunday Mail of 14 December reports:
A 120-tonne consignment of South American nuts has been impounded by Federal quarantine officials at a wharf at Newstead, Brisbane.

How did 120 tonnes of nuts get into the country? That consignment should have been looked at before a permit was given to import it-before the nuts were put on the vessel. Probably it was like a great heap of sorghum which we saw in a wire netting enclosure in Brisbane some years ago. A barge owner brought it into Australia and it was lying around for in excess of 12 months because the departments concerned were fighting between themselves in regard to whose responsibility it was to destroy it. For all I know, it may still be there. This is where the quarantine system in this country breaks down.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was in Darwin.

—It was in Darwin. Senator Teague saw it. He was also a member of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. Because the departments could not decide who would pick up the tab for destroying the sorghum, it was still there. These things need to be tidied up. I could quote ad infinitum reports of these cases.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter I mention is a Press statement which was issued on 12 May-just this week-relating to an Italian woman in Adelaide who brought in seeds and potatoes in her luggage. She was fined a miserable $140. What was her excuse? She told the court she had not understood the law and that the person on the aircraft who had helped her to fill out the Customs form said nothing to her about plants or seeds. If one can believe the woman-I prefer not to believe her-there again is a breakdown in communications between Customs officials, quarantine officials, and the people in charge of the aircraft. She did not say whether it was one of our aircraft or an overseas aircraft. These are things to which we have to give due consideration. The sooner it is done the sooner primary industries in this country will be fully safeguarded.

A joint Press statement by Mr MacKellar, the Commonwealth Minister for Health, and Mr Moore, the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs makes astounding reading. It is headed 'Children and parents asked to find hamsters' and states:

Children and parents throughout Australia are being asked to help Quarantine and Customs Officers track down two varieties of rodents-hamsters and gerbils-which have been smuggled illegally into Australia.

How do these live animals get in here? There must not be strict surveillance. That is the only way in which they could get in here. That Press statement was put out under the dateline of 28 April. Another news release from the Minister for Health, Mr MacKellar, under the dateline of 6 May-last week-is headed 'Minister offers compensation to aid rodent eradication campaign'. It states:
People who hand in hamsters and gerbils which they have acquired recently will receive a refund of the purchase price, the Minister for Health, the Hon. M. J. R. MacKellar, said today.

It will not be much assistance to Australian primary industry just because the Minister for Health has decided he will pay some reward to people who hand in hamsters and gerbils. He might get a few. The refund will provide pocket money for some child, but what about all those which they do not capture? They are a rat-like rodent and they breed like flies, and Australian primary industry could be-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is how people make a profit.

—They might be farming them. I do not know for how long this offer will apply, but I well remember years ago when I was a boy a rabbit plague during which rabbit trappers would never kill a baby rabbit because it was their bread and butter. They would let them go if they caught them in a trap. It could well be the same with these hamsters and gerbils. Kids are not stupid. If they think they will make a profit they will even breed them in cages and then they will hand them over to the Minister and get some pocket money for Christmas. I say again that this shows how weak surveillance is in this country. It is high time, as was pointed out in the course of the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, that something was done to prevent it.

SPEECH.PARA: I received a letter from a person who gave evidence to the Committee. He is the only person who has contacted me as a member of that Committee and expressed some concern about what has happened. It is Mr Murray Fenner of 30 Keyes Street, Ashburton, Melbourne, Victoria. He is a pigeon fancier and breeds racing pigeons. He referred to some of the chapters in our report dealing with pigeons and Cocos (Keeling) Islands. He quotes chapter 6 and page 37 of the report, under the heading 'Animal Quarantine'. He goes on to quote also chapter 7, and the comments on 'the Inadequcy of Existing Quarantine Facilities.' I wish to quote only part of this man's letter because I think the Government ought to take cognisance of what he suggests to assist these people who engage in the racing pigeon sport in Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —In common with all honourable senators who have preceded me, I welcome the second reading debate on the Quarantine Amendment Bill, which I will be supporting. Most of the proposals in the Bill-they are substantial-flow from the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources inquiry into quarantine matters. As a member of that Committee, I am even more happy to see that our recommendations have been implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity not to address the precise clauses of the Bill, all of which I support, but rather to note that quarantine can be improved by means other than the use of direct legislation. I refer, for instance, to better consultation with the States. In the administrative field even bigger steps towards effective quarantine measures can be taken.

I wish to refer briefly to three areas: The report of a fortnight ago which followed the Review of Commonwealth Functions, and especially page 35 thereof; contingency plans in various primary industry areas; and the importation of aquarium fish. These three vital areas, in which quarantine is important, do not depend on new legislation being brought before this Parliament or upon any amendment being made to the Quarantine Act. Rather, they require effective consultation by the Commonwealth with the States to ensure that the procedures followed are totally adequate and well prepared.

Recommendation No. 34 of the Senate Standing Committee states that detailed contingency plans should be discussed publicly allowing full debate and involvement of those affected by the plans. Recommendation No. 35 states that the Bureau of Animal Health should take the initiative in organising exercises to test the efficiency of contingency plans. In the event of an outbreak of an exotic disease in Australia can we be sure that the industry, the State authorities and Commonwealth authorities are fully prepared to eradicate and limit that outbreak?

I am still not convinced that there are adequate contingency plans for each primary industry in Australia. There are in the poultry industry. This very cohesive industry has discussed this matter with State authorities and worked it out very carefully. But I have yet to be persuaded that there has been adequate consultation with members of the beef industry in all States and that there is a clear line of action in the tragic event of, say, foot and mouth disease occurring in one area of the industry. This is not a matter for legislation. It is an urgent matter for administrative action. It requires consultation with the States. Whilst the Commonwealth is responsible through its quarantine provisions to keep exotic diseases out, the eradication of any outbreak is the responsbility of the States.

The second area which I wish to deal with relates to acquarium fish. For over three years the Australian Fisheries Council has discussed ways of improving the procedures and standards within Australia for the importation of aquarium fish. The current pitch of this debate has come to a disagreement by some of the States on the list of fish species which the Commonwealth is prepared to accept. At the Australian Fisheries Council meeting which was held last September in Darwin the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and the Minister for Science and the Environment (Mr Thomson) both indicated their support for a quote long list of fish species that could be safely imported into Australia without damage to indigenous species and without the danger of exotic disease being carried by these fish.

The aquarium fish importation industry is a very responsible and representative industry. For all of these years it has been most co-operative in discussions with the government authorities in determining a revised list. It has been able to convince Commonwealth Ministers that the list ought to be approved. I am afraid that some very conservative State public servants have been able to advise State Ministers that a very much more restricted list-only 100 species rather than 400 species-be the list that can be approved for importation of aquarium fish species. I believe that it is time for this matter to be exposed in this Parliament and not just to be tucked away in a small agenda item to be discussed by the Australian Fisheries Council so that the consultations which have been so thorough and good between the industry and the Commonwealth can now be accepted by the States.

My final point relates to the Review of Commonwealth Functions. Not only will the Government now be exploring with the States the appropriateness and feasibility of transferring to the States the remaining Commonwealth operational elements-I stress the words 'operational elements'-of the administration of quarantine but also the Government has indicated that the responsibility for quarantine policy matters relating to animals and plants will be transferred to the Department of Primary Industry. This major remaining recommendation of the Senate Committee now appears to have been acted upon. I welcome that. I believe that the superintendence of policy for quarantine will be better placed with the Department of Primary Industry. The operational elements of quarantine will be transferred to and administered by the States. This is only underlining the important State role in the present operational elements of quarantine.

Of course this matter is directly the subject of the Opposition amendment, which was initiated not in this chamber but in the House of Representatives. The amendment is inappropriate and is not supported by honourable senators on both sides. The Opposition amendment has been not well thought through and is, in fact, in total contradistinction to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee. I think it is in opposition to what is good practice in maintaining quarantine operations. I take the opportunity not only of supporting the Bill but also of stressing, in the three examples I have given, the important, vital and urgent administrative matters that I believe must still be undertaken by the Commonwealth.

Since the reference of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources to the predictability of the routes and times of coastal surveillance aircraft-this important matter has been raised by honourable senators-substantial flexibility has been built into the system over 11 of the 12 sectors flown. The opportunities for variations in routes between Darwin and Kununurra, which is the 12th sector, are very limited because of the coastal configuration. It should be noted that no coastal surveillance system-not even that of the United States Coastguard-can intercept all possible unauthorised landings. But the quarantine task is to detect any unauthorised landings and to respond as quickly as possible. This is done. Nevertheless, the points that have been made by honourable senators during the conduct of this most notable Senate inquiry and in the debate tonight are taken on board.

Senator Grimes, Senator Sibraa and Senator McLaren talked about the quality and extent of coastal surveillance. These comments formed part of the valuable content of the Senate report. The only other surveillance matter was raised by Senator Mulvihill and it related to the question of patrol boats. SPEECH.PARA: Over many months I have received submissions from such bodies as the Mersey-Leven Committee, the Tasmanian Council of State School Parents and Friends Associations and, more recently, from the Devonport Regional Catholic College Parents and Friends Association as to the level of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance and the point of parental income at which some sort of allowance becomes available. All these bodies emphasised the fact that families in the region are finding very real hardship in sustaining the tertiary education of children sent away to Hobart or to Launceston. But perhaps-this is why I rise very briefly on this occasion-I can make the matter somewhat more personal by quoting from a letter from Mr and Mrs Evans of Devonport, Tasmania. They wrote to me saying, amongst other things, that they had sent a young son to the University to Tasmania. They said:

In our case we are not entitled to any allowance, the cost to send our son to University in Hobart will be $3,200 this year. With only one income this will not be easy. It is of immense significance that smaller numbers of North West Coast students continue with Tertiary education than in other areas. Unless Students win scholarships parents can't afford to help them to go on with their education.

That very plaintive cry from those parents is, I believe, merely one parental voice amongst many in the north-west and on the west coast of Tasmania. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 3 March 1981:

(2) Did he or she request that the last item on the Nationwide program of Wednesday, 15 October 1980, should be an interview with the Treasurer, Mr John Howard; if not, why was an interview with Mr Howard screened as the last political item of the program before the electronic media blackout took effect before the election three days later.
(3) What did Sir Talbot Duckmanton tell a deputation of Australian Journalists Association members who waited on him to complain about this incident.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 5 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What plans have been made by the Minister to deal with the possibility of any State or States seeking to avoid the agreement concerning the introduction of lead free petrol at some future time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: At the February 1981 meeting of the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC), Ministers recognised and endorsed the importance of a nationally uniform approach to motor vehicle emissions control. The ATAC resolution is welcomed and fully supported by the Commonwealth as reflecting its own position on the subject of emissions controls.

ATAC noted that the New South Wales Cabinet had adopted 1 January 1985 as the introduction date and that the New South Wales Minister for Transport undertook to inform the New South Wales Government of the ATAC resolution. ATAC also noted that while Western Australia had reservations, the Western Australian Minister agreed to put the resolution before his Government mindful of the benefits of a nationally uniform approach. I have now been advised that Western Australia has agreed to accept the terms of the ATAC resolution and I welcome that decision. I am still awaiting advice from the New South Wales Government regarding its final position on the ATAC resolution.
Should circumstances envisaged by the honourable senator arise, they would be addressed through consultation at ATAC and, where appropriate, through direct consultation between governments.
