TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1981 (Hansard, page 77) Senator Walters asked me a question without notice as to whether the Federal Government recently undertook an experiment which proved that private contractors could do road construction work for about one-third less than it would cost with normal day labour by the Department of Main Roads.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following additional information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The former Bureau of Roads examined in 1969 the feasibility of undertaking a study which might enable firm conclusions to be drawn about the comparative costs of the two methods of construction. This examination was undertaken following a request to the then Minister for Shipping and Transport by the Australian Federation of Civil Engineering Contractors.

The Bureau considered that such a study would be feasible if the full co-operation of the States, where most road construction is undertaken, was obtained. However, it pointed out that the study would be complex because of the number of difficulties involved in attempting an objective assessment. These difficulties included, for example, the problem of finding road projects which would be sufficiently similar as to provide an adequate basis for comparison and the likelihood that variations in costs between individual contractors could be as great as those between contractors and day labour. In the event, the Bureau concluded that the results to be obtained from such a study were unlikely to warrant the costs involved.

The Department of Housing and Construction undertook a very limited study in 1976 which compared maintenance expenditure undertaken over a four-year period by private contract on a Commonwealth stores building with maintenance expenditure by day labour in other years. Neither Capital Works expenditure in general nor road construction works were considered and hence no conclusions can be drawn from this study about the relative cost of road construction work undertaken by private contract and day labour. Moreover, the conclusions from this study would not be relevant to a comparison of road construction methods.

It is therefore not possible to conclude, on the basis of available information, that private contractors will always do roadworks at a lesser cost than day labour. The relative cost efficiency of each of these methods of undertaking roadworks would be established on a project by project basis where day labour and private contractors are free to compete by tender for the work. From the viewpoint of achieving value for money, this is the very reason for the Government's decision to make grants to the States and the Northern Territory for national roads conditional upon the application of open tender arrangements.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Qantas Airways Ltd: Flights Between Perth and the Eastern States

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 February 1981 (Hansard, page 154) Senator Sibraa asked me a question, without notice, concerning the utilisation of spare seats on Qantas flights between Perth and the eastern States.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

The utilisation of empty seats on Qantas flights was examined by the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review Committee which reported in 1978. The report recommended that domestic airlines be allowed to charter spare Qantas seats for the use of domestic passengers. Following the review, discussions with the airlines highlighted a number of difficulties with the proposal. These included health, immigration and customs requirements, problems of interconnecting domestic flights and possible industrial implications.

The recent report of the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares also referred to difficulties associated with such a proposal. The report pointed out that the availability of seats on international flights for domestic use would almost certainly reduce the frequency of flights to and from Perth offered by the domestic airlines thus reducing the choice available to travellers. Moreover, the availability of seats on the international flights would depend upon the seasonal demands for seats to and from foreign ports.

The inquiry also noted that while schedules originating in Melbourne or Sydney for westbound services may follow a timetable, there would be no avoiding the likely interruptions and delays with incoming international flights eastbound to Perth towards the end of their journeys. Thus the regularity of eastbound services from Perth might be less certain than is now offered.
However, the Government is prepared to facilitate negotiations between the airlines in an endeavour to achieve a satisfactory solution to this issue.
